What winter? :I', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'What winter? :I'}]
text: This Tiong Bahru Bakery is located on the first floor at Tangs Departmental store (near to the Whoo beauty counter). I have walked past here many times in the past, always seemed so crowded. So I never get to check out the place. <br><br>This morning I arrived at 10.30am at m&#39;pir nail place located on the 4th floor. I was thinking my appointment was either 10.30am or 11.00am, only to be told it was really 11.30am :~) Don&#39;t ask me why didn&#39;t I put my appointment in my calendar, once a while I can be a scattered brain :D After all,  I am only human. <br><br>So I have an hour to kill. I decided to go check out Tiong Bahru Bakery. I saw a few empty seats, yippee!!!<br><br>I looked at the huge variety of baked goods, oh my!! Since Tiong Bahru Bakery is supposedly famous for their croissants, so Croissant would be what I am ordering today. I ordered a croissant and a hot chocolate.<br><br>FOOD 4/5<br><br>Croissant 5/5  - omgoodness!! The croissant was to die for. It was buttery, flaky and airy inside. To be honest, it was not the most esthetically pleasing croissant I ever laid eyes on, but oh wow, what a pleasant surprise! The croissant was absolutely heavenly! It was perhaps one of the best, if not The Best, croissant I ever eaten. You know I am coming back here again!! <br><br>Hot chocolate 4/5 - I definitely have better hot chocolate. It was not bad, not the worst. I am a sucker for anything esthetically pleasing and this was the first time someone actually served me a cup of hot chocolate with design on it as if this is a cappuccino. I like that :) <br><br>AMBIENCE 4/5<br><br>The shop is really tiny, so space is a premium. The chair I sat on was not the most comfortable. It was a mini stool. I do not particularly like the design of the plate here. Looked old-fashioned :P Other than that, I like the place. It is a cute little bakery/café.<br><br>SERVICE 5/5<br><br>The staffs were wonderful. They were friendly and attentive. The staffs tried to clear the table as fast as they could so patrons who arrive have clean tables.

text: Famous bakery in Singapore, it&#39;s everywhere and serves good bread, pastries, and sandwiches. Coffee here also not bad. Fast and efficient service. Very busy in the morning and lunch time.

Lunch set includes a salad for $12.', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Lunch set includes a salad for $12.'}]
text: You have to eat the croissant or pastries here or on the day you buy it. It is way better than if you have it the next day. <br><br>The flat white is still too bitter and strong for me as I prefer those with a creamy and smooth aftertaste. <br><br>The tarts and cakes are ok to below average. I have yet to try the sandwiches, and frankly I still don&#39;t see what is the draw to this place. It can get very crowded even on weekdays late mornings. Don&#39;t people need to work?<br><br>The only reason I come here sometimes is because I can get a 10% discount with my Club21 card and I might as well get some use out from it. Otherwise I doubt I will be here. I think The Providore Cafe on Level 2 has better cakes and food options.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/-fKzpKxXU2ATVOIZNcGDgA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/tiong-bahru-bakery-singapore-3?reviewid=0JeTdSbZ-hu3ScRZQ4SSBA&select=-fKzpKxXU2ATVOIZNcGDgA', 'altText': 'Photo of Tiong Bahru Bakery - Singapore, Singapore. Salmon bagel, brioche, and chocolate au pain', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Salmon bagel, brioche, and chocolate au pain'}]
text: Fabulous baked selections on a Friday morning breakfast with the sis! We took the MRT here from Clarke Quay and walked in with our large duffels before waiting to check into our hotel in Orchard.<br><br>TB Bakery was a &#34;must&#34; on our list as foreigners, and this location in Orchard was conveniently located near TANGS and also equipped with strong wifi. We treated ourselves to delicious coffee and tea (I had the lavender, although the lavender was not very evident, the tea was very refreshing) as well as a selection of baked noms: mini croissants, salmon bagel, and the delicious kouign amann. My favorite was the kouign amann, and I&#39;ve had a couple in various other cities and this might be one of my favorite because of its softness and fresh quality! The salmon bagel was just because I wanted something savory to cancel out all the sugar, but it was mediocre for the high price. My sister loved the croissants and found them to be very fluffy and crispy!<br><br>Service was incredible: from the immediate greeting upon entering to the fabulous and quick food runners/bussers, we felt enlightened that morning which is always a great feeling to have! Hats off to the crew at this TB Bakery. I&#39;ll be sure to stop by again if I find myself in Orchard in the future.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/calSneLNwIvsi7WVgYJMiQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/tiong-bahru-bakery-singapore-3?reviewid=6OZ9FpqYnOvsDCThRbGJPg&select=calSneLNwIvsi7WVgYJMiQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Tiong Bahru Bakery - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Recently I received an email about 1-for-1 promotion for certain tarts and loaf cakes at the bakery and decided to visit the orchard outlet as it was nearest to me. There were also 2 more outlets, one in Tiong Bahru and another in Raffles City Shopping Centre.<br><br>The outlet was located in the first floor of Tangs department store. The place was crowded during lunchtime, but the queue moved quickly. I was able to redeem the promotion smoothly and swiftly. Food was already placed on the table before I came back from the cashier. Such fast service.<br><br>Lemon Tart ($6.50)<br>There was 3 different levels of sourness for lemon tart. I had selected the lowest which was first level. It was slightly sour. The texture reminded one of Jello. The crust was too hard.<br><br>Pandan Flan ($6.50)<br>It reminded one of a certain kueh, not the kind of traditional flan which I was expecting. A bit too jelat after a few mouthful. Best share with someone else.<br><br>Latte ($5.50)<br>It tasted slightly chocolaty.<br><br>Overall food was average. Service was great. There was free wifi from the department store too. Great choice for a place to rest after shopping.

Not over done very balanced chocolate flavor."}]
text: OMG good. Coffee was on point! And the pastries are delightful. Eating here I felt the equivalent of if breakfast at Tiffany&#39;s was at a coffee shop, maybe even the equivalent of if Tiffany &amp; Co had a coffee shop. Loved it. If you&#39;re not from Singapore then you shouldn&#39;t miss this place.

text: I followed so many food blogs here and was not disappointed! The croissant and kouign Amaan was delicious. The amaan is a hard glazed pastry. Very crunchy and sweet. They have jam and water in the back. The orange jam goes so well with their baked goods. I love that jam I need to find out what kind it was. If you go and see this review please ask them for me and let me know. I would put that on everything. Really cute bakery with coffee and sandwiches.

Finally going through many of my drafts from 2 months ago, yay!<br><br>Delightful corner shop in a mall complex. Hm, what did I get:<br>-Fiji water<br>-Ham butter baguette<br>-Mini choco-croissant<br><br>Nice snacks! The baguette may have been hard so they could&#39;ve warmed it up or I forgot to ask. Lots of eye candy to try &amp; eat. Friendly, kind staff. And cool interior decor.<br>Worth a visit.

A convenient, small space to get your mid-day brunch or rest your legs from shopping. This place serves decent coffee and pastries and is relatively empty on a weekday afternoon, filled only with your fellow Tai tais bored from shopping at Tangs. I had the large flat white ($7.50++) as well as the coconut cheesecake-a delightful combination of cream cheese and coconut flakes with a crumbly lotus biscuit base. The salty and sweet mix allowed us a good umami experience but could get a little cloying after a while. <br><br>Overall, a pleasant experience if you&#39;re in the area, but I wouldn&#39;t recommend travelling down just to have this. If you wouldn&#39;t mind traveling a bit more, their outlet at raffles city would provide a better spacial experience with a more carefully designed interior.

text: My fav coffee joint in town.<br>The coffee is really good, I like the aroma and the taste of it, beats Starbucks and Coffee Bean hands down. It helps me to fight hangover while hanging out with bestie who was in town after a night of partying prior to that. <br><br>My only problem is this joint is forever busy on the weekend, to the point that I couldn&#39;t get a seat at times and just left in frustration. <br><br>What could they do better?<br>Perhaps open another one in the Somerset area so I don&#39;t have to walk to Tangs for coffee!!

text: Excellent little croissant place. High quality. Good service. A bit busy and cramped inside, but they keep it clean. I enjoyed the tea. The smell of the croissant dough baking inside the place sets up your appetite. A good place to take a break from the fast pace on Orchard Road.

text: I tried their chicken hot dog and almond croissant. Chicken hot dog was OK but the croissant was amazing with lots of almond paste. I  have never tried any croissant that rich in US.

text: Frequent visitor here and I have always enjoyed all their pastries.I really like the matcha croissant but they also have really good brownies and rolls as well.The place itself is almost always crowded but if you don&#39;t mind the noise,then it&#39;d be a great place to do work too!

text: This wasnt my first time to drink coffee with my friends here, we all like it coffee here. Yep coffe always good, service fast and friendly. Cakes is good, love their chocolate lava. But the place is bit too small  so crowded, and noisy so difficult to talk inside.

Accidentally walked into this bakery.  What a wonder aroma.  I was full from lunch but the matcha cream with rum croissant pulled me in. What a delicious treat.  Wish they had one closer to our hotel!

text: Tasty, buttery pastries and a wonderful, friendly staff. My vote for best bakery + coffee on Orchard.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/tO91lX21HQCEgfwMKQFqPw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/the-coffee-shot-singapore?reviewid=2frGukNWTWroXabzdTi9BQ&select=tO91lX21HQCEgfwMKQFqPw', 'altText': 'Photo of The Coffee Shot - Singapore, Singapore. Roasted beef charcoal bamboo sandwich and vanilla frappe', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Roasted beef charcoal bamboo sandwich and vanilla frappe'}]
text: Stumbled upon this cozy little café near lavender and was totally entranced by it. It had a really nice ambience to it and I would love to go there again soon! <br>I had a Roasted beef charcoal bamboo sandwich and a vanilla frappe for $17.90 which was a tad too overpriced. But after I took a bite out of the sandwich, it was totally worth it as the beef was roasted nicely (not too well done) and the bread was quite good! The vanilla frappe was splendid and it had a biscotti that came along with it! <br>Roasted beef charcoal bamboo sandwich- 8/10<br>Vanilla frappe- 7.5/10

I was walking towards Chye Seng Huat Hardware when I happened upon this place. My last visit to Hardware wasn&#39;t the most memorable so I decided to give this place a try. Went in for a quick breakfast and coffee. <br><br>I had the salmon and eggs on toast, which they nicely amended from poached eggs to scrambled, and hollandaise sauce on the side. Service was friendly and quick, food and coffee were good. Wifi is free! Seating is comfortable and airconditioned. Cakes / pastries looked good, but I didn&#39;t try them so can&#39;t comment on the quality.<br><br>Only complaints -- <br>- The toast (which was topped with the salmon and scrambled eggs) was heavily buttered which was very unnecessary and I tried to scrape it off when I noticed.<br>- The tiny side salad was overly dressed, so I left it mostly uneaten.<br>- $20 for a small americano and breakfast...sigh...it&#39;s Singapore...<br><br>Overall I enjoyed it and would return, probably en route to do my grocery shopping (it&#39;s just 2 blocks from the new Fairprice by Lavender MRT!).

text: While waiting for my friend to be done with work, decided to come here as her office was located opposite this store.<br><br>Came here the second time before writing in this review. The first time I came, I had savory bread - Bacon Focaccia. It looked good on the display section and it was even better after they used the oven to heat it up. It was also filling and I just had one piece of that for dinner. When I was about to leave, I bought the lemon meringue. It wasn&#39;t as good as I thought it will be as I consumed it hours later. <br><br>The second time I came, I had the Raspberry Croissant. The server also heat it up before serving. I asked for a to go bag (brown bag) so that I am able to taste the croissant in bites instead of using fork and knife. The raspberry filling was so amazing. On top of the croissant there were powdered sugar and almond which made it sweet and crunchy. The texture of the flakes was just done perfectly. <br><br>Service was excellent. The servers will repeat the order of what you are getting one more time for accuracy. They also greet you upon entering this cafe. Every time I come here, people also started to rush inside here to buy other kinds of breads or pastries. They also serve main courses as well as soups. Definitely a good place to hang out during the rainy days or during tea time. Will be back for more soon :)

text: Small café on Keong Saik road (home to one of the highest concentration of great eateries in the city), which serves up some of the freshest baked goods around. We tried the rum and raisin croissant with their iced lemon tea and a cappuccino (small order because we were waiting for our turn for lunch at a nearby place). The coffee was really good, lemon tea was very refreshing and the flaky pastry reminded me of Paris. Ah well, we can&#39;t travel now, so have to travel via food. I&#39;ll be back to try more of their baked goods for sure!

Menu', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Menu'}]
text: Small cafe that bakes a wide variety of bread every day. I tried the croissant  (plain), the baguette, and an Americano. All were tasty, but I would say the baguette was most impressive especially because I had it when it had just come out of the oven  (still warm)! <br><br>Seating here is limited and the tables and stools are small. Best for solo or duo seating.  Terrible place to come with a large group.<br><br>The employees were very friendly and helpful and I liked their music selection too. Would come back again next time I&#39;m in the area!

Almond croissant ($3.50) - 2.5 stars<br>I suppose I was eating it right after lunch... But honestly it was nothing special - not much almond filling. They even warmed it up. Probably wouldn&#39;t get it again.<br><br>Ambience - 3 stars<br>Clean but tables are small. I got my croissant to go.

Croissant', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Croissant'}]
text: I was staying down the road and craving some food in the evening, but I felt too lazy to walk far or actually sit down at a restaurant, so I happened upon Bread &amp; Hearth. I had asked for something that they didn&#39;t have because it was so close to closing time, so I chose a ham and cheese bread and a focaccia instead. They were delicious! They warmed up the food for me to take back to my hotel, and I also got a free croissant because I had bought 2 breads. Everything was absolutely delicious and the service was prompt and friendly.
Good pastries and a great basic latte here. After pastries stayed for seconds of a bacon ham and cheese on bread.  Small place with good service on the late Sunday we were there.
Delicious food and great service! I would definitely recommend visiting for breakfast!

text: Raspberry croissant is buttery, crunchy and not too sweet with the light raspberry filling. I thought it was delicious. You can smell the baked goods from a few steps away. The place is small and cozy, does have a feel of a bakery with tables so it&#39;s easy to grab a fresh pastry or bread with a coffee and enjoy the ambiance in air con.

text: the 3 of us went here for breakfast. small menu but good for a quick quality bite. café latte was good and the croque monsieur tasty. fresh orange juice at SGD$3. great! the bacon sandwich was also good. the baquette was crispy and fresh with butter and jam, simple but great! the raspberry croissant was a bit different and worth to try.

text: While waiting for my friend to be done with work, decided to come here as her office was located opposite this store.<br><br>Came here the second time before writing in this review. The first time I came, I had savory bread - Bacon Focaccia. It looked good on the display section and it was even better after they used the oven to heat it up. It was also filling and I just had one piece of that for dinner. When I was about to leave, I bought the lemon meringue. It wasn&#39;t as good as I thought it will be as I consumed it hours later. <br><br>The second time I came, I had the Raspberry Croissant. The server also heat it up before serving. I asked for a to go bag (brown bag) so that I am able to taste the croissant in bites instead of using fork and knife. The raspberry filling was so amazing. On top of the croissant there were powdered sugar and almond which made it sweet and crunchy. The texture of the flakes was just done perfectly. <br><br>Service was excellent. The servers will repeat the order of what you are getting one more time for accuracy. They also greet you upon entering this cafe. Every time I come here, people also started to rush inside here to buy other kinds of breads or pastries. They also serve main courses as well as soups. Definitely a good place to hang out during the rainy days or during tea time. Will be back for more soon :)

I have only tried the almond croissant, sliced bread and latte here but this three items have won me over! I cannot wait to try the other pastries at bread and hearth. And a bonus, the staff here are super helpful and nice!

You have my heart at baked anything, and i can never say no to freshly baked breads, pastries, cakes, you name it. It&#39;s the smell of butter and sugar probably, both of which i cannot resist and that resulted in a shopping spree when i stumbled into Bread and Hearth, a new artisanal bakery in the Keong Saik/ Chinatown/ Ann Siang area. <br><br>Bread and Hearth prides themselves with using pure butter and quality ingredient. There is absolutely no shortening used, as highlighted by the friendly staff. French Normandy butter and flour goes into making these quality pastries.<br><br>The Matcha Orange is a bread roll with a nice matcha fragrance and the flavor is lifted by the refreshing chunky orange peel. The Honey Chocolate bread ($3) was porous and very bouncy. Even though it said Honey Chocolat, it wasn&#39;t sweet at all and it actually had a salty taste. That said, i still like how it was flavored nicely with the dark chocolate chip bits. Do add some honey to it after you toast it. I swear it&#39;s divine.<br><br>The Bacon Focaccia ($6.50) is exactly that kinda bread that i&#39;d want for a breakfast. The fragrance was taunting me during work the whole afternoon and i finally succumbed to my weakness and took several bites and boy was it satisfying. It&#39;s the perfect savory snack. I would eat the foccacia even if it didn&#39;t have bacon on it. <br><br>The Cream Cheese Sesame ($2.80) turned out to be a sweet treat instead of a savory one! Think dense creamy cheese with a nice sweet pastry crust peppered with smokey sesame seeds. Yummy! Another must try is the Bostock which is more than 50% cake i swear. <br><br>Bread and Hearth also does sandwiches and coffee and they do have a nice enough spot for lunch/tea.

text: Good breakfast venue to start a day. Breakfast plate, including scramble egg, simple salad, juicy sausages and croissant with coffee is bit too much volume. I prefer simple combination of croissant and long black. Long black is quite good.

Best cold brew I have ever had! They add coconut oil to the Signature Cold Brew Coffee and its incredible - not too sweet, but still very creamy/milky. They also deliver on uber eats. <br><br>The food is good but the toasties are very bread heavy since the toast is over an inch thick and not that good.

Free the robot signature ($6+)', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Free the robot signature ($6+)'}]
text: A comfortable cafe with all the vibez on point. It has a rustic hippie feel with darker benches near the entrance and beautiful sunlight (perfect for that gram!) For the bar seats. <br><br>While the atmosphere did not disappoint, their signature free the robot coffee did not impress. While the cold one had a decently even taste of coconut-reminding you of ondeh ondeh-throughout, the hot version was, as mentioned by another foodie, but a normal cuppa with a layer of coconut oil floating on top. <br><br>What was bad was their vanilla coffee, which did not blend at all with their beans and left a rather pungent taste in the mouth. My food buddy even found a piece of paper in her drink, which was honestly unacceptable. <br><br>What made the visit rather unpleasant was the staff which kept hovering around our seats and were swift to clear our cups even when the cafe was rather empty. That being said, credit must be given for their somewhat enthusiastic service. <br><br>Overall, a place worth a visit. Whether it warrants a trip back depends on your personal preference! I&#39;d say no for the coffee, but I haven&#39;t tried the food so that might make up for it. There&#39;s also a really cute dog named Baileys there on most days!

Free the Robot Signature with coconut, espresso and milk; $6', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Free the Robot Signature with coconut, espresso and milk; $6'}]
text: Get the &#34;Free The Robot&#34; Signature.<br><br>Yes, it&#39;s one of the more pricier drinks at $6. However, I found it quite unique: coconut, espresso, and milk. The coconut really makes a difference! I can&#39;t say that I&#39;ve ever tried that combo before in a coffee, and this one really worked well.<br><br>I hosted a CMYE (community manager Yelp event) here and what I didn&#39;t realise was how small the space was. It&#39;s also very dark inside, as they purposefully cover the windows. It was very stuffy during our visit; even though they had air conditioners and fans running, I wasn&#39;t sure if they were actually working.<br><br>Bottom line: Great place for takeaway coffee or for grabbing coffee with a friend... any more than 4 people would already be a crowd during peak hours!

text: Nice place..love the cool interior. <br><br>However, I don&#39;t quite like the coffee. Macchiato is sour and flat white tastes too milky. Could hardly taste the coffee. I&#39;m disappointed.

Art house bohemian vibe.', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Art house bohemian vibe.'}]
text: I used to frequent Sarnies cafe a few steps away until recently when their part time staff blew me away with their lousy attitude. <br><br>So I ventured out into the unknown and hit up Free The Robot a few steps down the road. Boy, am I glad I did! Coffee they serve are from Toby&#39;s Estate and are pretty on point. Fantastic atmosphere. Loving the nook they&#39;ve created by blocking out most of the outside, so you feel like you&#39;re in a Melbourne alleyway. <br><br>Tiny gripe is that with gst(?) my average latte from $5 came up to about $6.40. Pricey for 2 shots of coffee and some milk. <br><br>I work around the area so that adds up pretty quickly.

(+)<br>Vibe of the place is on point  my favorite one so far in telok ayer!<br>Cold brew amazeballs<br>Sensible prices on the menu<br>Burger was tasty and relatively cheap at $12<br><br>(-)<br>Limited space, not great for meeting that needs privacy<br><br>Update: been here a few times now and it continues to be amazing. Their menu is reasonably priced and coffee is amazing! Plus they have a super cute friendly dog. Hope they stay this way.

Grungy hole in the Wall Cafe (bright red rain awning at front door is how you know it&#39;s this cafe). Coffee offerings include oat or soy milk. I had former but it wasn&#39;t that great (quite sour) -- should use Oatly! Avocado toastie was amazingly yummy but way overpriced for three slices for $10 including a bunch of undressed salad leaves (!!)<br><br>Weekday morning and sufficiently empty and calm to find tables. Tad dark at some spots making reading difficult.

text: We visited Singapore for a week and ate here most mornings.  The food and beverages were great.  Foods of a good size and everything made fresh to order.  Take your time looking at the menu as there are options for breakfast is a couple places.  The folks who work there are great!

Robot is a good, solid, comfortable place.<br><br>Many items at Robot are made in-house.  This includes their light, buttery brioche, their flavoursome meatballs, and even their pesto, redolent of basil.  The food is one manifestation of the pride and effort the folks behind Robot put into all they provide; the warm hospitality is another which you won&#39;t fail to notice.  Attentive yet unobtrusive, always eager to share more on the provenance of their edibles - these guys are wonderful hosts.  This, despite its low prices for the area.  <br><br>I wouldn&#39;t necessarily speak in hyperbole about Robot*; it&#39;s more a &#34;consistent, high batting average&#34; kind of place.  It doesn&#39;t have &#34;the absolute best salad!&#34; I&#39;d head to Salad Shop with its dozens of customisable options, though then I&#39;d have to deal with massive lines and sometimes surly staff.  Nor does it have &#34;the absolute best coffee!&#34; For which I&#39;d trek to Nylon at Everton, where the excellent folks do beautiful coffee, and only coffee.  But whatever does Robot serves they do do well, and I&#39;m always very pleased to get my salad and coffee from them. <br><br>Also, take note of the quirky, hand-painted murals. There&#39;s so much to spot!  Visiting Robot is like hanging out in the home of your cool, arty, ultra-foodie friends.<br><br>*Actually, Robot has the best cafe ambassador in the form of four-legged Baileys

text: I&#39;ve been here a few times and I want to go back again soon. They serve coffee, cold pressed juices and an all day menu of sandwiches, eggs, salads, a pasta, burger and cake. Bread and cakes are all homemade, down to the small English muffins. Small menu and portions on the petite side but the prices are noticeably less than others in the area.<br><br>- Latte. Consistently well made and they do it better than another place I go to regularly (the Lokal), I think I had the woolloomooloo blend $5. Yes they do skinny or fat milk here. <br>- Smoked salmon muffin, I didn&#39;t realise till it arrived that this was served on a homemade English muffin. Super yummy but I really need a bigger muffin to soak up that yoghurty sauce. $8<br>- Sous vide egg is $3, add $2 for truffle oil and a piece of jamon with a tiny piece of toasted brioche. Again, the brioche needs to be upsized so do what I do and order their white bread for dipping ala kopitiam style. We loved the truffle version, truffle flavour was clear.<br>- Toasted white bread - this is really good white bread and really toasted lightly with butter. They need to add some jam as a condiment for those who want it. $3 for 3 pieces<br>- Tuna toastie $6 - same white bread, simple fillings but tasted quite fresh and not like how tuna can sometimes get a smell if opened too long.<br>- fruitcake made by the owner&#39;s mom. He told me his mom is health conscious and he worried it wasn&#39;t sweet enough but for me this was perfect because it was light, fragranced delicately but clearly with spice and didn&#39;t have that greasy feel leaving your fingers all oily. Very moisty, I might have to go back to get a loaf. Loaf for $12 but you can get it per slice.<br><br>I love the look of the place, the handpainted wall murals, little cubby hole window and the name Free the Robot. Yes, my robot definitely needs to be freed more often.<br><br>At night this turns into the bar Bitter and Love so they close shop at 4:30pm.

text: Solid four starts. Went early on a Saturday and two of us racked up a nearly $40 brunch. That was the only downside of the trip. Food was good,  coffee was better, great music, nice staff, cool ambiance. I will definitely go back. Loved it. Not sure if we caught a one-off experience but it wasn&#39;t too crowded which was a plus.

text: What a beautiful and modern Japanese bakery. Their decor is mainly white with clean lines. The buttery scent of fresh baked goods greets you when entering in. There&#39;s lots of seating and greenery plants placed on some tables. <br><br>This bakery offers baked bread, pastries, ice cream, tea, and coffee. I&#39;ve come here several times, and enjoyed some of their pastries. My favorites were their salted caramel banana almond croissant and the coffee danish. You can taste all the flavors described and the butter. The coffee danish had a lovely flaky texture as well. I only had a chance to drink their earl grey tea, but it was strong and flavorful. <br><br>If you&#39;re ever in Singapore, this is a bakery to check out. Especially if you&#39;re close to this bakery from your hotel.

text: The 82-year-old bakery is brought in by Tan Chong International, which is well known for its car business in Nissan and Subaru. The bakery origins from Japan and this outlet is its first branch outside of Japan. The bakery takes over the 5,000 sq ft space that used to be a car showroom. The bakery has dining in area with its own restrooms at the back. There is free wifi offered at 30 minutes period, with login ID and passwords from the staffs. Besides offering breads, it also offers light set meals and ice cream. Credit cards are accepted here.<br><br>Salted Egg Croissant ($4.50)<br>Crossiant with salted egg custard filling.<br>The croissant was buttery and soft, easy to slice through, although I wish it could be crispier. The filling was a bit too little.<br><br>Salted Egg Cube ($4.50)<br>Unique cubed shape bread filled with salted egg custard with a crispy sable top!<br>It was more difficult to slice compared to the croissant but the filling was much more than the croissant. <br><br>Maple Walnuts ($3.20)<br>A french dough mixed with walnuts &amp; special maple butter made with 100% pure Canadian maple syrup. <br>Sweet and nutty but a bit too tough after some chewing.<br><br>Chamomile Mint Tea ($6)<br>The tea was served in pot, and tasted light and smooth.<br><br>Asanoya Ice Mint Tea ($4.20)<br>A non sugar added minty drink, which was great for such a hot day.<br><br>Americano ($4.50)<br>Served with a piece of biscotto.<br><br>If you take a photo of the food and post online with #LoveAsanoya and show it to the staff, you will be rewarded with a coffee or ice lemon tea.

text: Yummy Japanese bakery with very creative pastries. Quality is not that good but the concept is there.<br><br>The Royal Milk Tea Loaf is soft and fluffy. The croissants and cinnamon buns are not soft, even when heated so kind of disappointing.<br><br>The lattes are good.<br><br>Lots of seats but it does get busy during the weekend.

text: Woke up this morning, saw on Instagram that a friend was here having yummilicious salted egg croissants and BAM, 3 hours later I&#39;m chilling in a white muji-like chair enjoying my tray of treats at Asanoya.<br><br>Verdict:<br>- Matcha Salted Egg Croissant: This is simply divine. I&#39;m not a fan of salted egg confectionery so I was kind of hoping that the matcha taste would overpower the salted egg and I was right! If you&#39;ve ever eaten &#34;boulou bun&#34;, the chinese version of salted egg buns, the Matcha Salted Egg filling is similar in texture to that while the croissant was light and fluffy - just the way I like it! I ordered this as a takeaway but after a while, I decided to have it right there and then. I was too lazy to ask the staff to heat it up for me but I bet that it will taste even better if it&#39;s warmed up. Will remember to do that next time.<br><br>- Bacon Pizza (Popular choice): I picked this because it was deemed as the popular choice and I wanted some meat. However, in my opinion, nothing really special about this except for the 4 tiny cheese cubes on the Bacon Pizza. The cheese cubes could be bigger though but otherwise, I would choose other pastries to try next time.<br><br>- Chicken Miso salad: It looked better in pictures then it actually is. Priced at $3, it&#39;s a good stomach filler if you&#39;re not so hungry and yet want something savoury besides bread to go with your coffee or juice.<br><br>- Cold pressed carrot juice: $5.80 for freshly cold-pressed juice? A tad pricey in my book but I was in the mood to indulge. They only have 4 types of fruits to choose from - apples, orange, carrot and watermelon.<br><br>I am really not a bread person but today, I had bread for lunch (enough to last me a month) and I feel quite satisfied. Says a lot about Asanoya right? Spotted lots of Japanese ladies and men having lunches and tea breaks there and it sure added to the whole jap muji-like feel of the place and that is why this place has 5 stars from me (plus the clean washrooms and plugs too)! All of their breads are gorgeous in presentation and it was difficult to decide which to try. Will be sure to return within the next few days as it is right next to SMU!<br><br>Also, Asanoya is currently giving away 10% voucher for your next purchase with a minimum spend of $10.<br><br>Tip: The places gets a little bit crowded during the lunch hour but it is still bearable. Best to avoid lunch times between 1-2pm. The seating area is peppered with lots of power points so it&#39;s a good place to chill and surf net/charge phone/play games or write reviews! Plus, the toilets are really clean and nice so plus points there.

A Japanese bakery located just off Bras Basah Road is a gem find especially when attending art/museum events in the evenings.  A wide spread of bread is available from caramel apple cube to curry donut.  I had the cafe&#39;s house special, tea bread, which is flavoured with earl grey tea leaves and condensed milk. I can&#39;t wait to revisit and try the other breads. There is also a gourmet shop that sells jams, spreads and dips.

Something that bewildered me is the sheer popularity of the Cube Loaf--cream filled cube-shaped bread available in Yuzu cheese, Caramel apple, Matcha, Chocolate, etc. Perhaps due to our nation&#39;s fetish for something goeey or flowy in the centre (think Liu sha bao or molten lava cake), this has been the most featured item on any media platform. <br><br>However, I suggest we try to manage our expectations as the Matcha is just a chewy chocolate bread filled with sweet matcha custard that is resistant to flow. Perhaps the chef did not intend to make it flow in the first place. The problem wasn&#39;t whether it flowed or not, but that the cream was too sugary, to the extent that it overpowered the demure tea taste. At a hefty tag of $4.50, I&#39;m hesitant to invest in another one. <br><br>The Cinnamon Danish ($3.20) called out to me with that attractive dark brown sheen but it was more chewy than crunchy, as the sticky caramel goo clung on stubbornly to the knife .....and my cavities the more I chow on it. <br><br>Though the Sweet Potato Yuzu Cream Danish is constructed on the similar danish base, the main ingredients helped to distract us away from the mediocrity. Yuzu is not only visibly detected as peels on top but also in the white cream base, which imparted a lovely tanginess that complemented the warm sweet potatoes. I was glad we stood by this &#34;less-popular&#34; option instead of the all-too-common blueberry custard danish. <br><br>The other autumn-inspired bread named &#34;Harvest&#34; ($4.50) was also excellent. The texture of the bread is chewier than an average European baguette but the subtle honey flavour crawled out as one slowly bite into it. The earthy sweetness from the candied sweet potatoes, chestnuts rode upon the savoury cream cheese to create another wonderful dimension in this humble stick that is easily overlooked on the shelf. <br><br>I love the Signature Curry Bun, which tasted like any orthodox non-spicy Japanese curry bun with the mellow sweetness. We were lucky to get one from the batch that was hot out from the deep fryer so it was crunchy and not too oily. <br><br>The Mushroom Quiche ($6) is indeed a very straightforward quiche with plenty of mushrooms. While there could be more salt in this, there was enough that it registered for me. This was good but the Potato French was even better. <br><br>At $3.20, one get an entire potato with skin intact, snugged tightly within the crusty French bread under the luscious blanket of butter and mayonnaise. Have it warmed up and one would be greeted by mini billows of steam from the soft potato. Genius.<br><br>Despite the liberal amount of icing, I was not assaulted by a blast of sweetness in the Caramel Apple Croissant ($3.90). The tartness of the soft-but-not-mushy apples cut through the dense almond paste. Also, the flaky pastry here managed to salvage my impression of their weak Danish dough. <br><br>The signature Karuizawa Green Tea Loaf is sold here in grams at $2.60/100g, which is about the weight of one slice. Blended with white chocolate, the bread has a tinge of milky sweetness, which was slightly different from the taste when I had it in Japan. Nonetheless, the texture is still spot-on; soft stretchy with a crusty brown shield. Would be great if they can also introduce the Coffee loaf in future.<br><br>Overall, the savory items were more remarkable than the sweet items, even though the price across all items was not very pocket-friendly. I was quite disappointed by the sweet bread but maybe to think on a positive note, the cube loafs are something exclusive to Singapore market. Nonetheless, there is still room for improvement before both the quality of the food and the service standards here can match up truly with the level in Japan.

text: Japanese bakery, originated from Karuizawa, Japan. There are variety of breads there. We can enjoy them  for breakfast, lunch and dinner.

It&#39;s been a couple of months since Japanese bakery chain Asanoya Boulangerie opened its first-ever outlet outside of Japan in Singapore but i wasn&#39;t too quick to join the queue at the Queen Street outlet. Well i guess that&#39;s a good thing since when i recently visited, i found the place quiet and peaceful (also empty) during brunch time on a Saturday. <br><br>Well i guess the hype kind of died down when people realised that Asanoya is first and foremost a bakery, not a cafe. Hence, unless your idea of brunch is a small sandwich, pastry or cake, you may be disappointed when you visit. Thankfully, Asanoya&#39;s offerings are perfect for this petite bread lover! Also, do not come expecting artisan coffee. My flat white was nothing like a flat white and it was burnt, but i was wise not to have any expectations.<br><br>Before i could get started on my order, i was distracted by the freshly baked loaves on display. Of course i had to sample them before i can decide on what to buy home!<br><br>The signature Karuizawa bread comes in various flavors and i tried the blueberry and green tea ones. The bread has the typical European crust (though not too hard) and the interior of the typical soft chewy and airy Japanese bread. Each loaf is pretty big, weighing more than 1.2kg but they price it by slice/weight as well, so you can easily grab a few pieces in your preferred flavors. The breads are lightly sweetened and perfect on their own.<br><br>Asanoya also has the smaller earl grey tea loaves ($4.20) which everyone should get their hands on (i would walk away with all in fact). First flush earl grey tea leaves are used and flavors such as orange and blueberry are also available. I would have gotten the original but the blueberry was a nice match with the tea (orange was a little overpowering).<br><br>On to the savories, the Bacon quiche ($6) had an asian flavor to it (onions) and tasted a little like those zi char fu yong omelette. The egg custard was still satisfying, that it until you hit the extremely salty cheese bits. The crust needs more work as you can see from the thick, undercooked and hard edges.<br><br>Other hot savory favorites include the Potato French bread which encased an entire potato in it, with butter and mayonnaise. Comes highly recommended by fellow food bloggers. Carb in carbs anyone? <br><br>The Campagne cranberry and cheese bread would be my choice for brunch if i could stomach more food. Just look at those chunks of cheese! Other than that, i also would not give the maple walnut pretzel a miss.  <br><br>As for the sweet stuff, Asanoya is known for their lava Cube Loaf ($4.50) which comes in chocolate and green tea. Do not expect it to ooze like a lava cake. I was under the impression that the wait staff would warm it up for me (he said he would) but the center was still cold. Well, the custard was sufficiently milky, with a light sweetness. I did enjoy the slighty chewy bread and i could it on its own. <br><br>Overall, Asanoya Boulangerie is a nice spot to enjoy some tea bread with tea (skip the coffee please). I would consider popping back to stock up my breads if i&#39;m in the area. You can also get spreads, dips and oils which will complement the breads from the on site gourmet shop. Set lunches are available too.

text: The newly introduced food menu is really interesting and value for money ! I&#39;m happy they have gone from just a bakery to a cafe finally ! I can&#39;t just eat bread for lunch. At least there is some interesting lunch meals to try now !

text: I stay for two weeks every year from Christmas through New Years at the Royal@Queens Hotel which is right next door to Asanoya so I stumbled onto it by luck. The building is set back from the street a little bit so don&#39;t miss it. Inside, the whole place is pristine clean with fantastic lighting and a fresh, new, modern look. The displays of shopping goods like their teas etc. are very nice and inviting. The main thing though is the pastry and bread counter. Everything looks so delicious and fresh that you just want to try each one. I felt like I was in a real French Boulangerie. I had a blueberry Danish with my coffee that was so good that I had to go back and get a second one before my coffee was finished. I saw that they had lunch items as well so on another day I had lunch there. I don&#39;t remember exactly what I had now but I had the potato salad with it and it was fantastic. The double cappuccino was perfectly made. The staff was enthusiastic, cheerful and polite. I will see you again on December 27th or 28th!

text: It&#39;s been on my radar for a while now to try the almighty Arabica coffee in Asia. Finally got a chance during our visit to Singapore. This particular location is located in the 313 Somerset mall next to Orchard Central. Kind of out in the open but never lacks traffic, since people are going in and out to the MRT station. <br><br>Their coffee is amazing, and you even get the option to choose the type of beans you want to use: single origin vs blend. They take their coffee very seriously. <br><br>Arabica is definitely the coffee staples in Asia. And if you haven&#39;t tried it before, I very strongly recommend you to!

text: Zeppelin is a great little coffee and tea shop on the 2nd floor of sim lim. The tea is delicious. An entire pot for $8. They also have fancy sodas and cake. And you can hang out and try out the high end audio equipment and headphones. Or read a monocle. Or just sit by the window and watch the world of sim lim walk by. The staff is also really nice! <br><br>We had the mango passionfruit tea. Hot and delicious. And we sat for over an hour undisturbed. I love that it&#39;s a relatively quiet shop, too. Great to meet friends or hang out with your significant other, too.

text: Coffee quality was excellent, and you can tell that this shop is ran by real coffee enthusiasts. They provide a wide variety of drinks and food. The cold chocolate was amazing, maybe too many ice cubes, buts that&#39;s me being picky. Love the wide variety of headphones you can but as well. There are loads of different types of high quality headphones and speakers available to buy. Calming and jazzy music is played in the background, and the staff are comfortable to be around and maintain a happy atmosphere.

Well as Marcus said below, better speak Chinese for this one. Nevertheless I managed to order in English. <br><br>The coffee tasted freshly roasted and was well expressed. The pourovers were clearly poured properly, for example warming both the cone and the cup with hot water before adding filter and grounds. <br><br>The space is much smaller than I thought from the photos, and very different from your usual hipster coffee hangout. There is no well labelled merchandise impeccably ordered on minimalist japano-swedish shelves, no pastel colour scheme undermining the brutality of the raw concrete and painted building bowels. Think more Ikea furniture packed with coffee making equipment and a small roaster running at the back. <br><br>If there was food I did not see it. Four sandwiches are written on a board, and seem to be the only option. Coffee beans on sale (Yirgacheffe, 150g for $18; Blue Mountain for $65) were roasted on the 5th of March, a full week ago, which is the only minor issue I could find, but I know some roasters think coffee peaks 5 days after roasting.

text: I stumbled on this place a few weeks ago and just had my second cuppa. The coffee is great. It seems to be owned by coffee enthusiasts that are very serious about what they do. The cafe is small and there are hardly any food options but the coffee is one of the better ones I&#39;ve had in Singapore. For $4, you get a really good flat white which saved my sanity. <br><br>They share a space (I think) with a bakery that makes lovely cream puffs which go perfectly with the coffee. <br><br>Cash only. Closes at 6pm.

Taiwan milk tea', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Taiwan milk tea'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/QkOy4TalIf4aPRETkcRR5Q/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/geisha-specialty-coffee-singapore?reviewid=gBMB1DnnN9L36IXXlYVaow&select=QkOy4TalIf4aPRETkcRR5Q', 'altText': 'Photo of Geisha Specialty Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: I love coming in here for always excellent seriously yummy coffee, whether espresso or lattes, supplemented with the tastiest milk tea made by Elsie. Their coffees and tea are VERY good whether hot or cold although I always order the hot version but can&#39;t resist stealing a sip from my friends when they happen to get cold ones.<br><br>Very affordable but delivers so much, very casual and homey atmosphere. I keep bringing friends there to hangout with our cuppas! I only wished they opened longer hours!<br><br>Yummy cheesecakes too! The owners are so humble and easygoing, we&#39;ve become friends.

This is one little outpost of specialty coffee geekdom, with one exception - you might need to speak Chinese.<br><br>Owners Wang Tao and Elsie relocated here from Shanghai, and have started something with amazing dedication. Wang Tao is responsible for all the coffee action - he makes each coffee, be it espresso or pourover, or even the occasional syphon, AND he sources and roasts the coffee in their store, on a tiny Hottop - each batch averages 200g, so you can imagine how much time he spends roasting! He&#39;s roasted batches for some friends who&#39;ve become regulars (and fast friends, especially since their command of Chinese is leagues better than mine), and the range of beans, coupled with the quality of his roast, makes him quite a rare find.<br><br>Elsie is usually the face of the business, and does great front-end service, and also makes a mean Taiwan-style iced shaken tea, quite like a bubble tea. I know, it&#39;s almost blasphemous to order tea, let alone bubble tea in a specialty coffee place, but oh man. You need to try this one.<br><br>If you have time for a chat, and speak decent Chinese, come here for an afternoon. I learned a lot from a fellow who&#39;s clearly a coffee nut, and loves to share it with anyone who has time to sit back and smell.... his coffee.
Lovely place to just relax and enjoy a good cup of coffee. Price isn&#39;t too bad as well.

text: The cafe was located walking distance from Marymount MRT station. For weekday lunch, the place had a light crowd group, consisting of mainly young ones who are having school holidays, and nearby office guys having a cuppa before going back to after lunch. <br><br>Creme Brûlée French Toast (S$17.50)<br>Creme Brûlée brioche toast, Berry compote, fresh berries, hazelnuts, marshmallows &amp; Creme Brûlée ice cream<br>My favourite part was the toast which was buttery and crispy outside, while moist and creamy inside. It was a party in the mouth with the sourness of the juicy fruit and the sweetness of the soft pillowy marshmallows.<br><br>Steak &amp; Eggs ($19.90)<br>150 grams rib eye steak, potatoes topped with sour cream, free range poached egg &amp; chive hollandise<br>For a guy, the serving was quite filling and the steak was done up alright.<br><br>Cold Brew (S$6)<br>For today, it was Nicaragua coffee bean. Served in a glass on ice, it was a refreshing drink during a hot day.<br><br>Mid Wings (S$8)<br>One just can&#39;t help using the fingers to eat these. So addictive. Crispy and peppery outside, while juicy inside.<br><br>Overall the food was delicious, accompanied with flavourful drink. The place was cozy and relaxing too.

text: An unexpected gem on upper Thomson road that definitely blew us away with the quality and freshness of its food. It&#39;s now called Knockhouse cafe. There is a wait but it&#39;s a fast moving place and you will get a seat pretty quickly. The coffee is excellent and the ginger beer is very refreshing as well. The food is stellar, we got the eggs Florentine and smoked salmon hash. Quality of ingredients was top notch. Although it&#39;s a bit out of the way it&#39;s definitely worth the detour.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/D-fh90j9Afa5wVg22uEwcA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/pacamara-boutique-coffee-roasters-singapore?reviewid=Nksf4dkm5etSKgbxSrf-CQ&select=D-fh90j9Afa5wVg22uEwcA', 'altText': 'Photo of Pacamara Boutique Coffee Roasters - Singapore, Singapore. Spanish Eggs', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Spanish Eggs'}]
text: I came by Pacamara on a Sunday afternoon for a cup of coffee and snacks. After debating between the bakery items &amp; appetizers, I decided on one order of the sweet potato fries, largely because it was the same price of the bakery items ($7.50-8)! <br><br>The sweet potato fries were the thicker kind, lightly salted to perfection. It was a generous portion leaving me satisfied, not stuffed. The coffee was smooth as well, and the ambiance very clean, just as the exterior suggests. The windows are large, providing plenty of natural lighting. <br><br>[edit] I came back here to try the brunch menu, and decided with the Spanish Eggs, not quite knowing what to expect. Spanish Eggs are served in a tomato soup based, with a runny egg, chunks of chorizo, and vegetables in the soup. I am no expert to this type of dish, but was impressed by the abundance of meat in the soup dish. Good to try if you&#39;re looking for something a little different than the usual scrambled eggs! <br><br>One con of the interior is that all of the tables are long and shared, making it difficult to have a quiet or private conversation. I came here with a book to read but left soon after due to the noise levels of the conversations around me. <br><br>I was also a bit concerned about the location&#39;s accessibility but found it to be a shorter walk than I expected from the Marymount MRT station. It took me about 8 minutes to walk, with about half of the journey being covered (a nice protection from the sun or rain). Pacamara&#39;s placement on the corner of a big street makes it easy to find. <br><br>Overall, great food and clean interior, though not ideal for private conversations. Worth a visit when you are in the Bishan/Toa Payoh area!

text: Three words <br>Another.Hipster.Cafe<br><br>Having passed by Pacamara a few times, it was always crowded, we thought we&#39;d have to give it a try one day. <br><br>The interior was simple enough. Nothing over the top. It was clean, bright and comfortable. <br>The menu looked promising too. Despite having the usual brunch items (Eggs Benedict. Breakfast platter), they had fantastic sounding  dishes like braised beef cheek and Ossobuco. <br><br>Due to my strict diet, I decided to go with the Mushroom Aglio while the wife has half a chicken. <br><br>Wild Mushroom Aglio Olio ($16.50)<br>It was more a mushroom pasta than an Aglio Olio. They were really generous with the mushrooms and the pasta was al Dante. <br>Unfortunately, it lacked the pungentness and acidity of what defines an Aglio olio. <br><br>You&#39;ll love it as a mushroom fan but with exception to the mushrooms, everything else was very one dimensional. Still, a fairly decent pasta that didn&#39;t stand out in anyway. <br><br>Half Chicken ($20.00) <br>Now this was a let down. Again, generous portions but so underwhelming. The chicken lacked seasoning while the potatoes were over seasoned and the corn was borderline tasteless. The dish itself has potential but it just needed a little more here and there to really being the dish to life and at $20.00, I would have expected a lot more. <br><br>Overall, I hate to say it but Pacamara to me was just another hipster cafe. <br>Conceptually decent but failing to deliver on the food.

text: A pleasant minimalistic cafe tucked in the corner of upper Thomson :) Slightly different vibes from the many other cafes down/opposite the road with mostly white interior and exterior. The slightly harsh glossed white walls and counter top is balanced with wooden tables as well as in some of their plating. <br><br>Food is decent but might be considered a little pricey considering the serving size. would reccomend the truffle fries! :)

text: One of my favorite cafes in Singapore. Decor is white, clean and minimalistic, perfect for food photography. I got a table for 2 at the bar immediately when I arrived at 11.15.<br><br>Ordered the highly raved about Truffle Benedict ($18) and Salmon Royale ($18). One of the best egg benedicts I&#39;ve had. The eggs were nicely poached, not overcooked. Brioche was toasted nicely, crisp on the outside and fluffy on the inside - perfect to soak up the luscious yolk. The respective truffle and ebiko tastes in the hollandaise shone through - definitely enjoyed it. <br><br>I&#39;d tried the chili beef fries and mac &amp; cheese on a separate occasion and they were also very good. The salted caramel french toast was a little too cloyingly sweet for me, but the avocado toast with a poached egg on top was good for a healthy breakfast. <br><br>Overall highly recommend, would come back again!

Nicely balanced Rwandan, Kalita pour over', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Nicely balanced Rwandan, Kalita pour over'}]
text: I had never actually heard of Pacamara till today.  In fact, true to the manner in which unexpected epiphanies unfold, I would have driven right by had I not stopped at the light and caught sight of  the words &#34;boutique coffee roasters&#34;.<br><br>I looked it up on Yelp and there were no reviews on the coffee at Pacamara!  To have no mention at all about the source of the beans, the brewing methods on offer or the baristas did not inspire confidence, but I&#39;m glad I walked in the door anyway and here&#39;s why.<br><br>Mystery.  This was a 40-20-20 blend on the back of a beautifully roasted Colombian producing an aromatically complex espresso. The nose was full of fruity, floral flavors with jasmine and magnolias predominating.  A comforting roasted nuttiness was there as a solid flavor base note.  The mouthfeel was a little aggressive and acidic on the palate, but gave way quite invitingly, blooming into beautiful warm nutty flavors, suggesting toasted almonds, pecans and roasted hazelnuts.  A very expertly extracted double espresso which just made my day!<br><br>Kalita pour-over.  This was done with a craftily roasted single origin, Rwandan, I believe.  Roasted on site to release an exotic bouquet when poured and cupped hot.  The nose was full of citrus and floral flavors and the only way to adequately describe it was orange blossoms, it reminded me of standing in an orange orchard in full bloom.  The palate was equally well equipped, with sweet prunes, transitioning into toffee on the front of the tongue and then other roasty, caramely. flavor notes.  A very strong effort by the on-site roaster.  My hat off without qualification... so enjoyed this.<br><br>I think if you can look past the fact that they serve food and the hipsters sipping their steamed milk with coffee while staring at their Macbook Airs with a calculated nonchalance, you&#39;d find a true nugget of a coffee geek hangout in Pacamara.  The things I enjoyed today were all done on-site.  I hope that management continues to provide the roaster the latitude to explore with on-site roasting, tweaking it just so each time and in the process making magic.  This I believe is the only way to grow Singaporean coffee culture and move beyond being a rudimentary café culture for hipsters.  At this instant, and here in Singapore, there is so much respect for a  good quality product and a nucleus of raw talent with a passion for elevating this product with skill and attention to detail to produce something truly great.  I respect that and if you do too, then the erstwhile crew of Oz, now behind the bar at Pacamara deserve some of your time and money.

text: I had the pleasure of having brunch over the weekend at Pacamara, which just opened recently on Upper Thomson Road. For those who are familiar with Oz Specialty Coffee, these are their new digs as they&#39;ve shifted from Thomson V - and it appears they changed their name along with it!<br><br>They&#39;ve kept the interior the same as the exterior - white. All white. Since they are in a corner spot, they have a lot of natural light coming in, which makes it seem even brighter. <br><br>They can pour you a good cuppa here, and the food menu is worth trying, too. It&#39;s pricey, with a lot of the items averaging about $18, but given the quality of the food, I&#39;d say it&#39;s worth it. Miguel had the caramel banana French toast, and to counter the sweetness, I ordered the eggs benedict. Both were executed well; I thought the caramel banana was not overly sweet (a plus in my book) and the eggs bene had perfectly poached eggs and was quite Instagram-worthy.<br><br>I also liked how they had various pastries to choose from if you didn&#39;t want to drop $18 for food (or experience a 30 minute wait.) I appreciated that they were upfront with the wait time for the food, though. Hopefully it&#39;s something that will improve over time.<br><br>Bummer this isn&#39;t in an area that&#39;s close to an MRT, but if you&#39;re ever in the Thomson area, check it out. Do go early, as it definitely gets packed later in the day!

text: The stretch of shops along Upper Thomson Road changes so rapidly that I could no longer recognized it. Habitat Coffee, One Man Coffee and now comes Pascamara, one of the popular cafes these days in this area. Fortunately, the waiting time wasn&#39;t as scary as Lola Cafe. <br><br>Divided into five sections; Salads, Sides, Brunch, Pasta and Dinner (5pm-9pm) the menu offers familiar cafe items such as Chicken Wings, Fries, Pancakes, Eggs Benedict. <br><br>The crunchy Deep Fried Mid-Joint Wings ($8) were not too greasy and flavorful on its own without the dipping hot sauce. I am not a connoisseur of Truffle Fries ($8) but this tasted more like fries topped with Parmesan cheese flakes. <br><br>The cold Quinoa Salad  ($8) would not help you meet your daily green intake as it has barely much green. Quinoa was definitely in abundance but the dish was sadly under seasoned and tossed with too much olive oil.<br><br>What a nice touch for the chef to arrange the 5 cheeses next to the Oven Baked 5-Cheese Macaroni ($18). Tossed with Feta, Parmesan, Emmental, Mild Cheddar, Mozzarella, the macaroni is not too rich but there isn&#39;t much of the satisfying cheese or creamy kick.<br><br>Instead of the Salmon Royale, we had the Truffle Benedict ($18), characterized by smoked ham, wilted spinach and truffled hollandaise sauce. To be honest, I only knew that the hollandaise sauce contains truffle as I am writing this. Perhaps it had evaporated well before I could catch a whiff of it, but there wasn&#39;t any spectacular moment in this dish. However, the excellently toasted buttery brioche instilled my faith once again in their dishes. <br><br>Indeed, I would gladly pledge my allegiance to their brioche for the Salted Caramel French Brioche Toast ($16) was terrific. I can&#39;t get much caramel here, but it was the magical alchemy of salt and butter that awakened my sleepy palates. The bananas and chewy granolas played the role of a side cast; I could just have a plate with the toasts alone. <br><br>However, the other sweet brunch option, the Red Velvet Pancakes ($16) , remained a sore on the tables. The triple pancakes were squidgy and zapped of moisture, exemplifying none of the fluffy qualities I dreamt of. The dreary weight of the pancakes were aggravated by the sticky mascarpone.  But if it&#39;s mascarpone, shouldn&#39;t it be less dense? In any case, I&#39;ll stick to the classic red velvet cake, not pancakes.

Pacamara is one of several places to open up in the Upper Thomson Road area a North of central Singapore. The whole area seems to be buzzing with cool new places. Visiting on a Sunday it was also packed with people in search of a good brunch spot. Pacamara had a pretty nifty system for managing the queuing. One enters a phone number on a screen and how many people are in the group and then Pacamara calls when a table is available. The table will be held for 10 minutes after receiving the message, so you can browse around in the neighborhood while waiting.<br><br>The service was however severely impacted by the place being full. They were slow to give out menus, things were sold out and they did not inform about it upfront. Food came out slowly and orders were mixed up. All in all not a great experience. Some of the people working there also seemed to have a little bit of the attitude that they are slightly too cool to actually work at a cafe and we were actually on one visit asked if we would mind to speed up a bit as they have many guests waiting - that was especially annoying since we then had just gotten the last of our food after a very long wait.<br><br>The space is however very nice and bright, in a corner with big windows. There are mainly communal tables but it works fairly well and I must say that it looks really nice. There are a lot of seats, and while not super-comfy it is fine to sit for some time. There is also free wifi so on weekdays it may be a better bet if one wants to sit for long.<br><br>The coffee was a bit disappointing. Not at all that bad but looking at a place that at least markets itself as a top roaster I was expecting more. The filter coffees sampled were a bit bland but no bitterness and smooth, but they had not managed to bring out the best in the coffees. I got much better results when brewing the same at home so perhaps more a flaw in the brewing. Still a good cup compare to the average cafe but nowhere near the better ones in Singapore. They were also out of several of the coffees that they had up on the board so that was also slightly disappointing. The espresso based coffees where however very nicely prepared.<br><br>The food was however excellent. The truffled eggs Benedict is perhaps the best Eggs Benedict I have had. The pastries were tasty so the Kitchen know their stuff. It is a shame about the service and that the coffee quality is not top notch as the space is really nice and if they could up their game it would be a place I would visit again and again.

text: The first thing I noticed about this place is the crowd. The Sunday brunch crowd here is unlike many other coffee boutiques. It&#39;s probably because it&#39;s located in the housing area so many people can just walk here from their homes. People here look more comfortable and are dressed down in their t-shirts and shorts. And I like it. It&#39;s not pretentious and everyone who steps in all want to have a relaxing time. <br><br>The staffs are awesome as well. They were engaging and helpful in every way. We were lucky to get a seat by the bar to watch them make coffee and tea. Despite the crowd, the staff took time to answer our many questions about coffee and tea. And trust me, my husband asks A LOT of questions. The staff was nice and gave us shots of tea and coffees to try. <br><br>I also only have good things to say about their food. The Eggs Benedict with truffles was a perfectly done dish. We also ordered the caramel banana french toast. It was refreshing and not overly sweet. <br><br>I&#39;ll definitely come back here for the food, service, and ambiance.

text: Beautiful on the eyes due to its minimal decor, but jarring on the ears after a while due to the lack of soft surfaces to absorb the sounds of the many people that came. I came with a friend at around 9 or 10am and it got quite crowded that we had to share our table with 4 more people. It became a little too cramped and noisy that I heaved a sigh of relief when I stepped out of the noisy cafe. Not too sure why the whole place was so white and bright, yet the toilet was so dark.<br><br>Food was rich and of good quality, and it was really filling too. Staff were friendly and service was prompt.

Stopped by early on a Saturday morning to have brunch with friends. It is a small corner location with long tables (i.e. you will probably share with others). I ordered their French toast, and my friends ordered the pork sandwich and Egg benedict. Serving sizes are well portioned and you could share the French toast. <br>The location is a brightly lit and a great spot to stop in for early morning brunch. I was happy with the french toast, enough toppings and the bread was amazing. We also ordered a side order of truffle fries, and those were great too. I am not a coffee drinker, so i cant comment on the coffee, but my friends enjoyed the coffee. We were the first group to arrive to the restaurant, and when we were leaving a group of people were starting to wait for a table.

Unripe avocado with pit in.', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Unripe avocado with pit in.'}]
text: We waited 30 min for all our food to arrive at our table. After 15 min, two of our orders arrived. And another 15 min later our last order arrived. <br><br>The kitchen would wait for multiple orders of the same item then make them all at once. This resulted in many tables who ordered well after us to start receiving their orders before we had gotten all of ours. Normally the food should come out chronologically for whomever ordered first. <br><br>My food was good. I had the crab eggs benedict. My partners meal was also good except there was still skin from the pit attached to his avocado (as seen in attached photo). Also, the avocado in both our meals were not ripe and ended up quite hard and tasteless. Would have preferred they exclude the avocado and replace with a grilled tomato or something else. <br><br>Free wifi was nice so I could write this review. Food was good but not worth the half hour wait and the hassle of having the meals arrive 15 min apart. <br><br>Food, coffee 4/5<br>Hostess, servers, baristas 5/5<br>Wait time for orders, cooks 1/5<br><br>Pros:<br>-food was overall good<br>-servers attentive <br>-baristas quick <br>-free wifi<br><br>Con:<br>-kitchen disorganized and slow<br>-avocado not ripe and pit not properly removed <br>-ordered 3 plates and they came out at very staggered times

Salted Caramel Banana French Toast!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Salted Caramel Banana French Toast!'}]
text: An ode to Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert, I give Pacamara two Thumbs WAY UP!!! This hip, clean and ultra-modern chic coffee shop has got it going on. It&#39;s hard to describe, but you can feel a certain buzz about this place on an early Saturday afternoon with a lot of good looking people to boot.<br><br>The long black coffee was top notch, but the cherry on the cake was the Salted Caramel Banana French Toast! Woah!!!, was the dish memorable. As people know, I&#39;m huge fan of  banana anything. However, many banana dishes I&#39;ve tried end up being just a little plain.... The salted caramel mixed perfectly with the banana and you have a dish that might as well be classified as a desert dish for breakfast! <br><br>I haven&#39;t tried anything else beyond the above, but am looking forward to coming back and seeing what else this gem of a shop has in store for it&#39;s up and coming fan base. <br><br>One the best brunch spots in Singapore? You bet!

I&#39;ll get to the point. If I were to open a café, it&#39;d be Pacamara. <br><br>Coffee is great, definitely third wave. Big gleaming white Synesso churns out consistently great espresso, and they do pourover with a rotating selection of beans roasted in house. They&#39;ve also got a steampunk setup, which I&#39;ve seen them use for tea, for which they also have a very tasty selection. <br><br>Fantastic selection of coffee brew kit (parent company imports Kalita) and coffee beans. Craft beer selection is also very well curated, many taken from TSA wines&#39; portfolio (evil twin, Stillwater, brewdog), as well as some US craft. <br><br>Food is consistently yummy, although they just can&#39;t resist drizzling that damn truffle oil crap into their otherwise tasty food. One star taken off for that. <br><br>Service is always attentive and unfailingly polite. <br><br>I&#39;ll always make it a point to schedule a visit to Pacamara, whenever I can find a reason to. Well worth the trip! <br><br>p/s free WiFi, password is <a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.knockhouse.com.sg&amp;s=0d764372042a530cdb3a84cbf288c75b09df445f5164830f014608384e87e5ec" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">knockhouse.com.sg</a> - that&#39;s the parent company&#39;s website. Clever!

Every cafe has coffee but not every cafe has fresh beans. <br>The beans are fresh, aromatic and the coffee made is consistent. <br>Simple fern/ flower latte art, but milk is perfectly frothed and pattern even stays after 15minutes. <br>Now that&#39;s a good coffee. <br>Recommend hot drinks over the cold, mocha is also slightly bittersweet due to its chocolate powder. At least we know that we are paying for quality cocoa powder. <br>Everything tastes natural, and do note that there is no skinned milk option available. <br>Of course, a coffee lover will know skinned milk changes the taste of coffee, and how the yin and yang of coffee can be changed just based on milk quality. <br>Though the sizes are significant smaller, they only have Starbucks Short/ Tall sized equivalent and the prices are the same as Starbucks, your never able to compare apple and orange. It&#39;s two different things. <br>Thumbs up.

text: This place is good. That&#39;s why it&#39;s packed all the time. Espresso nice, nice alcohol selection, and decent food.

text: Nice ambiance, has an Aussie cafe feel to it. Arrived at noon for the lunch menu and the place was packed. We were seated fairly quickly and our coffees arrived soon after. However, the food took a long time. A good half an hour wait and my miso glazed salmon portion was so small that I left feeling hungry. It was delicious but I certainly won&#39;t order it again. It would have been better served with a more generous portion of mash.

Good coffee. I had the barista&#39;s breakfast so I could try their espresso, latte, and brewed coffee and all were good. The brewed stuff was flavorful and easy to drink. They have a good beer selection too. Maybe its because I saw they have Deschutes but this place kinda gave me a Portland hipster vibe. They also have the Alpha Dominiche Steampunk but it seemed like it was only used for brewing tea.

text: Excellent food, service and cofffeeee....  It is a very hippie and popular placed on the weekend for the young.  Prepare to share table and the place is not kids friendly (but the French toast and salmon Benedict are to go back for!!!).   The eggs Benedict can do with a bit more veggie (mushroom) but worth to go before taking a big hike out at macritchie reservoir!
Get coffee from here very often. They make decent coffee consistently which is a great thing.
Had breakfast   Excellent food. Nicely prepared with fresh ingredients. Good value for money.

text: Now that Gastronomia has moved to a bigger premise (where Canele used to be), it has a larger variety of food and bigger seating space. I do miss the little corner it used to occupy but I guess change is good, and sometimes for the better. <br><br>The place is now spilt into two sections. You can order hot food (well, they heat it up for you) and salad in one area with its own cashier counter, and for those who wants a quick grab and go on the pre-packed salads, pastas, wraps, desserts, bread, there is another cashier counter to handle that. This makes it neater compared to previously when you get 2 separate lines waiting to pay at one cashier point. <br><br>Now that it is in the middle of the basement level (still nearer the escalator from Metro), the food display is eye-catching with plenty of salads, pastas, pizzas and cooked food. Somehow I no longer see the deli items (hams, cheese) unlike previously. It is also catching up on latest food fads with kale and beetroot on the menu. <br><br>The food is generally good and it is really a good place to stop by if you have a dinner party and do not want to cook. There are salmon spinach puffs, frittata, scotch eggs, <br>beef goulash, pulled pork, cous cous, marinated artichokes, chili con carne and more to put together a simple meal. <br><br>It is also relatively to get a table with a bigger seating area though it still gets crowded during lunch time. There is a water dispenser which is a nice touch.

It&#39;s my fav place for a quick bite on Orchard Rd.  Their pizzas are OK, the tiramisu is fantastic.  The venue is pretty causal, and it gets busy for lunch... check that there is a place to seat prior to ordering.

text: Came back for dinner. One can easily overlook this place, hidden by queues for the two Song Fah bak kut teh outlets, and located on the less busy side of New Bridge/Eu Tong Sen. (Except for the sad-looking panini&#39;s), the food rocks! The chef, who may be more talented as a chef than as a business manager, would do well at a premium restaurant!

text: Haven&#39;t posted a review in a very long time but when you find a gem, something moves you to leave a remark.<br><br>Looked this place up on Yelp on my way to a Japanese restaurant and my stomach changed its mind.<br><br>Nice clean decor and jazz tunes created a great ambiance.<br><br>I thought breakfast food would be served all day but that was not the case.  <br><br>But I was not disappointed with their dinner.<br><br>Soft shell crab pasta caught my attention and it surprisingly delivered.  Pasta was light, crab was nicely seasoned and cooked with the perfect crunch and with every bite, the deep flavor permeated my mouth.  The glass of Chardonnay would have complemented well but the wine was not chilled unfortunately.<br><br>I also ordered ice hazelnut latte and the lava cake and my dinner was near perfect.<br><br>5 stars!

text: Good place to have food and cakes and coffee, tea and drinks. The cake taste delicious, drinks is good too.<br><br>Price however not cheap.

New kid in the block ! Wanna Cuppa opened only sometime in Nov/Dec 2015, conveniently situated right opposite Clarke Quay station. <br><br>I was there on a Sunday afternoon and it was pleasantly quiet. The ambiance is relaxing and there&#39;s ample seats. <br><br>Flat white was not bad. The enoki fries was a tad oily.<br>Didn&#39;t try anything else on the menu. They had quite a selection of cakes on display too but I was too full for anything.<br><br>I&#39;d go back if I happen to be around the area.

I don&#39;t agree with the other reviewers so 1 star to make the reviews here on Yelp seem legit. I went a few months ago, and I thought the service was not amazing, and food was horrible. In my opinion.<br><br>My friend ordered salad with chicken and she said the chicken was way too dry and forced herself to eat the salad. I had a pasta with meat and tomato sauce and I just couldn&#39;t eat any of it. It felt to me like they just microwaved meat and hence the tough meat, and pasta was not fresh it was just not up to the standard that I was expecting. <br><br>I also ordered a coffee but nothing beat ronin or punch in that neighborhood in my opinion. <br><br>Therefore I haven&#39;t gone back ever since.<br><br>I&#39;m writing this review because I am looking for other cafes and restaurants nearby this neighborhood since I just moved here. But to see this place on top of Ronin made me think the reviews are not legitimate, especially with only 3 other reviews. So let&#39;s be real. It may be good enough for locals, but as an Asian who was born and raised abroad, I personally don&#39;t like it, but give it one try, as I did, and decide for yourself.

Love the interior. The name cuppa has actually captured my attention to step it for a quick coffee! It&#39;s not easy to find a place with good coffee with pretty and lasting coffee art made with skills here. Will definitely be back here again!

What I like about this outlet is the 24hours. So a good place to hang out when you out shopping till late around City Hall area or Marina Square area (but need a bit of walk if you from Marina Square)<br><br>High traffic that is for sure because is right above City Hall MRT station.
