Singapore breakfast courtesy of Starbucks', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Singapore breakfast courtesy of Starbucks'}]
text: Who doesn&#39;t like a 24 hour Starbucks? Located at the end of the shopping center, they have plenty of seating. It&#39;s clean, the baristas are fast and friendly. There are a lot of options to eat, which was nice. I had the salmon &amp; broccoli quiche (why can&#39;t I find this in Ca Starbucks?) it was perfect. Prices are exactly what you&#39;d expect, a nice affordable breakfast and coffee. I also went crazy buying bears and mugs, as they had a large selection.

This place is always so loud and busy. They do have one of the nicest displays of Starbucks food items though.<br><br>The only time I came here was when they weren&#39;t accepting credit cards. The problem was that after ordering about $30SGD of stuff, I got the notice and had to walk away because I had no cash on hand. Not only did they have to put it all back, but they also had to throw some things away because of it. This was the first time that&#39;s ever happened to me, but for this to happen at a VERY BUSY Starbucks is pretty ridiculous.<br><br>It didn&#39;t help that the cashier was autistic, because the cashier could not communicate or clarify anything until it was too late. I don&#39;t have a problem with autistic employees, but as a former cashier I know that they are not a fit for such fast-paced/social/calculating job roles.<br><br>If coming here, don&#39;t be surprised if you have to a) use cash, b) lower your expectations, and c) wear earbuds.
Nice spot for meetings. Fee WiFi. Convenient. Next to MRT. Nothing much to say about drinks as Starbucks is Starbucks.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/eE2XjQ5cIvWSYEIIa6BNuA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/starbucks-singapore-21?reviewid=Tlvz6ylt4C_12ELofNX5HA&select=eE2XjQ5cIvWSYEIIa6BNuA', 'altText': 'Photo of Starbucks - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: I pass by this outlet almost every week - since I&#39;m almost always passing by City Hall for one thing or another. This outlet is open 24 hours and I used to study here from 8pm to 2am for my exams. It&#39;s next to a 24 hour McDonald&#39;s as well - so it&#39;s the best place to be after 12 midnight, and if you need a snack or coffee. It&#39;s great to work there in the wee hours of the morning, if you need somewhere to work on free Wifi and people-watch.<br><br>What I Love: The staff here are REALLY friendly, and apart from the outlet at Changi Airport, this is my fave place, if I wanna have a Starbucks Coffee. They remember your name, there&#39;s a lot of room, and there are restrooms nearby. The couches are comfy, and there are more plush sofas here, than other outlets. The location is really strategic - you&#39;re in the middle of everything - the best shopping malls, great restaurants, and the train station.<br><br>What I Don&#39;t Love: The morning rush. Forget about getting any seats at 8am. The morning rush is insane. Apart from that, there&#39;s nothing much to dislike about this place.

text: Attended my first Introduction to Coffee Masterclass organized by Raise SG &amp; it was such an insight! Pamela was engaging and funny, and we all had a go at latte art and tasting how different brewing methods resulted in different bodies and tastes of coffee. Enjoyed my session and definitely will be back!

The Coffee, Alchemist', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'The Coffee, Alchemist'}]
text: Double, double toil and trouble,<br>Fire burn and cauldron bubble.<br>Cool it with a fine soy milk,<br>Then it tastes as smooth as silk.<br><br>There is definitely some alchemical coffee ministrations going on at this small stark black and white hole in the wall inside International Plaza.<br><br>From the shiny metallurgical instruments to the precision of measuring beans, this truly is the best coffee in Tanjong Pagar, and despite others being more convenient, if you really want something that knocks your socks off, this is the place.<br><br>The Dark Matter is the bean of choice: Its nutty bitterness provides a robust roast for those in need of a strong kickstart in the AM. <br><br>Can recommend highly - sometimes simplicity really is the best!

text: Rather good coffee and there is nothing I can really complain about.  But it somehow falls short in comparison to the numerous coffee places around tanjong pagar. I am torn between giving it three or four stars. And I am going to give it four stars because they play good music and it isn&#39;t crowded.

Super succulent pork cheek", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Super succulent pork cheek'}]
text: Walked by this place by chance and saw this new restaurant at Ngee Ann City. At first thought the name was d&#39;gold cafe, but I&#39;m closer inspection the &#39;l&#39;  is actually a coffee bean. <br><br>The place wasn&#39;t too crowded, about 60% filled. But noticed a celebrity seated near the bar with his family. On display are many mugs signed with well wishes from other celebrities, so maybe I the cafe is owned by a celebrity?<br><br>Was given 2 menus by the waiter. 1 is a food menu and the other a drinks menu. This is quite common, but the drinks menu is like 5 times thicker than the food menu. Haa... Although I always order the same old ice tea or ice latte, I decided to check out the drinks menu anyway. The selection of teas is really... Wah...  Also don&#39;t know how to describe. You come once a week for the rest of the year, and you probably would not have tried all the teas yet. Anyway, the boring person that I am, I tried the old English iced tea,and it was pretty delicious. Definitely not BOH or lipton brand..  <br><br>Back to food, I ordered the pork cheek whilst my wife ordered the Crispy salmon. Both were fantastic. Portion abit small but it leaves just enough room in your stomach for dessert. Which is probably the goal because when a pair of girls came and sat beside us, they were already chittering away about the cheesecake. One of them sat down, looked at the cake display and exclaimed &#34;what? Only 2 cakes left? That&#39;s it, Im not going to order a main, I&#39;m just eating cake.&#34;. She meant it too. They didn&#39;t order anything else, just the last 2 slices of cheesecake. <br><br>I can&#39;t say much for the cake, I didn&#39;t get to try it. But from where I was sitting it looked pretty good. Nothing fancy about it. Just a classic, tall, moist cheesecake. <br><br>All in all, full marks from every aspect. The service staff are friendly, prompt and attentive. They don&#39;t charge for water. Food is good and served in a timely manner and at the same time. Comfortable and stylish ambience. And perhaps some chance to score a look at some celebrities. <br><br>To summarise, pretentious food without the hefty price tag.

Cold brew coffee", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Cold brew coffee'}]
text: I stumbled here while shopping in Takashimaya and decided to get some coffee.<br>D&#39;Good Cafe knows its coffee, they have real good coffee. Cold brews, nitros, filtered coffee... they&#39;ve got it all. They also have cakes and hot food too.<br>I had a cappuccino. which was skillfully made- you know the sort that has the leafy pattern on top. I gotta say the cappuccino here is way better than Starbucks. It also comes with a tiny biscotti. The cup that it was served in was rather interesting - there was no handle!!<br>The decor is also very cute- there were British tube signs but the names were replaced with towns in Singapore.<br>When you go to the cashier to pay the check, make sure you look at some of the cute teapots and stuff that they sell!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Z3EUGmEye7EDcRai16x5vg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/d-good-cafe-singapore-3?reviewid=Ie20Csm4epTeSnw6ExMVkg&select=Z3EUGmEye7EDcRai16x5vg', 'altText': "Photo of D'Good Cafe - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ygl498eXxOkueMSBr8O08A/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/d-good-cafe-singapore-3?reviewid=Ie20Csm4epTeSnw6ExMVkg&select=ygl498eXxOkueMSBr8O08A', 'altText': "Photo of D'Good Cafe - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/WA9_aBlLGClfN5biUEbrQA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/d-good-cafe-singapore-3?reviewid=Ie20Csm4epTeSnw6ExMVkg&select=WA9_aBlLGClfN5biUEbrQA', 'altText': "Photo of D'Good Cafe - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/vPvm0qKmaS65bKOIlXEK1A/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/d-good-cafe-singapore-3?reviewid=Ie20Csm4epTeSnw6ExMVkg&select=vPvm0qKmaS65bKOIlXEK1A', 'altText': "Photo of D'Good Cafe - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: The cafe was opened in Sept by local actor Chew Chor Meng and his wife Deon Tan. It was the second outlet after the first one in Holland Village. The 65-seat café houses a London Tube and an English Garden. A red British postbox is placed outside the new branch for customers who are upset to pen down their feelings. We were showed a table at English Garden area as little JJ was struck with the swing at one of the tables. He was so in love with the swing that he wanted one at home.<br><br>Spiral Galaxy ($15++)<br>Green tea and grape juice with a spiralling visual treat.<br>The tea change to purplish colour when mixed with the juice. The golden dust gave the drink a shimmering colour. It tasted light and refreshing.<br><br>Coconut Infused Cold Brew ($9.50++)<br>A multi-sensory experience with coconut-infused coffee.<br>The drink was presented with lots of smoke from the dry ice. The coffee, smelt of roasted coconut, tasted not bad with hints of the coconut aftertaste.<br><br>Hot Chocolate Surprise ($7.50++)<br>A chocolate sphere, served with hot chocolate. When the hot drink was poured over the sphere, it revealed a marshmallow in it.<br><br>D&#39;Lobster Roll ($22++)<br>Prepared from live Boston lobster. 100grams of claw and tail flesh, tarragon mayonnaise and chips.<br>The roll was great although I wish for more sauce.<br><br>LING Cod Fish and Chips ($22++)<br>Cod fish, straight cut fish, tartar sauce and malt vinegar<br>Although it sounded quite expensive, the fish was quite meaty and juicy.<br><br>Pomegranate Citrus Smoked Duck ($13++)<br>Smoked duck, pomegranate, mandarin orange, pear, greens, caramelized walnuts and citrus sauce.<br>The pancake served here was not the usual type but Deutsch Skillet Pancake. It had a eggy texture which tasted more like Nian Gao 年糕.<br><br>Overall the food was delicious. There was 10% discount for senior citizens. The staff were knowledgeable and spot on for their recommendations.

Brunch / lunch place with several outlets in Singapore. Tried their salmon and pancake in a skillet. The salmon is standard - decent quality salmon steak / nothing particularly special though. The pancake in skillet is good as expected - hot cake in hot pan come on. Taste was alright, have had better skillet pancakes elsewhere though<br><br>Restaurant feels a bit cramped

Such a cute place and away from the busy crowds. Lots of food options for any mood. I tried the pork cheek and it was so savory and delicious. Also great for tea and coffee. We ended the meal with white chocolate raspberry ice cream- superb!

text: * NB: This is a straight male&#39;s review of Manicurious - Yes, apparently straight men get pedicures, as you&#39;ll find out below*<br><br>This man certainly was curious when a rugged buddy of mine suggested we go and get a &#34;classic pedicure because we&#39;ve earned it&#34;.<br><br>I wondered to myself what he meant by &#34;classic&#34;. Was this his hillbilly term for rub-n-tug, or knock-shop? I was soon to find out. As we entered the elegantly appointed establishment on Beach Road, we were greeted warmly by the staff who looked a little perplexed at the 2 rough-around-the-edges gentlemen in front of them.<br><br>&#34;Can we help you?&#34; they asked, very enquiringly.<br><br>My friend nonchalantly said &#34;Yes. Yes, you can. 2 classic pedicures please&#34;. I was still unsure whether or not this was a secret passcode to hedonistic pleasures beyond the crushed velvet curtain.<br><br>As the heavy drapes were drawn aside we were met with stifled giggles from the parlour, before being ushered to 2 comfortable lounge seats each with its own wash basin for feet.<br><br>Gazing around the room I drank in the full entirety of what we had gotten ourselves into. &#34;This is a woman&#39;s demesne&#34; I gasped to myself, &#34;I&#39;ve been tricked!&#34;.<br><br>All around were ladies being beautified. Nails being carefully painted and polished; toes being trimmed and tapered; all whilst these 2 rough chaps sat in chairs waiting their turn.<br><br>The tea menu arrived next and what-the-hell, I went for it with an Arabian mint and chai combo that really set my tastebuds alight. Draping a soft blanket over myself I settled in for a few rounds of Clash Royal on the mobile whilst I lazed in this luxurious lounge experience. Meanwhile, my buddy turned his attention to a fantasy novel he&#39;d brought in preparation - such a professional!<br><br>Now, I&#39;ve never had a pedicure before, and if you as a boofy bloke haven&#39;t had one either, let me tell you that you are in for an absolute treat!<br><br>After what can only be described as an angle-grinder experience of sandpapering across the heel; and then a random-orbital-buffer across the toenails; I was feeling luxurious and my feet have never felt cleaner or more alive.<br><br>So, what convinces a male of the species to put himself through a pedicure? As I&#39;ve now experienced it I can give you the benefits which are three-fold:<br>- Dead, scaly skin removal from the sole of your feet, particularly the heel<br>- Trimming and polishing of cracked, dry, long toenails<br>- Washing, scrubbing and cleaning of entire foot<br><br>What this achieves is a healthier foot, which means a healthier you. Also your shoes will thank you as smelly foot odour is no longer present.

text: The place I had been to on a previous visit has since gone out of business so I searched yelp for a place that could do nail art. I also creeped the instagram page and saw some pretty awesome designs. Be sure to check out manicurioussg IG page. This location was under construction so I didn&#39;t get the coffee pie and all that. I was offered a beverage but had brought my own ice water. Be sure to call ahead and make a appointment. I had to wait an hour for a mani/pedi. <br>Though I had requested nail art when making my appointment- they said they didn&#39;t have time to do it when I came back. I ended up having a wee Baymax painted on my ring finger, but I would have really liked something more dramatic. My manicure has lasted a week with just regular OPI nail polish- that&#39;s unheard of. I have a few very small chips but it&#39;s not noticeable unless you really examine my fingers. I did pick a neutral color. <br>My pedicure was amazing. I left with my feet feeling brand new. Every inch of my feet were buffed and puffed then slathered with lotion. It was easily the best pedicure I have ever had. I wish this salon was in Dallas and not halfway across the world from me! <br>I would come back but be sure to specify exactly what you want when making your appointment and be sure to call ahead! Since everything is under construction inside it&#39;s not the best place to wait - head to the Starbucks across the street.

text: Was tempted by the reviews on Yelp and also the proximity to my hotel. Plus I needed a mani badly.<br><br>My nails were well done, mani&#39;d and buffed to perfection and I skipped on polish. Good job done.<br><br>Why 3*? I love the whole pampering experience of a mani but the start was anything but as I was getting increasingly annoyed by my nail tech chatting to colleagues and it all being a bit stop start. Maybe it was because it was late afternoon and I was the only person in the store? Who knows. So, maybe going at another time would be better, a good job done, but overall experience was only ok...

text: My husband and I had really great pedicures here. Much better than ones I&#39;ve received in the states. <br><br>1 - At first it was a bit awkward when we walked in. We were confused as to where the place was because the front is a coffee shop. We were directed through a door which led to this little hidden gem. <br><br>2 - We were immediately seated and offered tea which was super refreshing after walking around in 90% humidity. <br><br>3 - There was a lot of attention to detail but towards the end I could tell the girl assisting me was rushing to help another person which is why I&#39;m giving them 4 stars. The gal who was doing my husbands pedicure took her time. I&#39;ll admit it made me a bit jealous! Haha. <br><br>Overall the next time I&#39;m visiting Singapore I&#39;ll definitely make a stop here. <br><br>Strongly recommend calling ahead of time. We called early Tuesday evening and they were barely able to fit us in.

text: Most of my dreams revolve around the following things:<br><br>-PIE<br>-Pedicures with endless polish color options<br>-Cute and colorful bags, stationary and jewelry<br>-MORE PIE<br>-People serving me free coffee, tea and hot chocolate<br>-Flying<br><br>Not sure if I was dreaming or awake in Manicurious, but I can confirm that I was sitting down, getting a pedicure, sorting through endless polish colour options, and being served pie and (free) coffee. And this was all after perusing a beautifully curated selection of bags, jewelry, and notebooks. Welcome to my dream come true.

text: Excellent experience with shellac mani &amp; regular pedi! Ting ting gave me the most gentle and relaxing pedi ever. This place is very meticulous about their craft and is constantly making sure that you are truly comfortable and happy from beginning to end.

text: This place is absolutely amazing. I&#39;m not even sure how to categorize it. Nail salon? Cafe? Boutique shop? Heaven on Earth? Probably the last one.<br><br>It&#39;s basically 3 things that girls love the most (vanity, carbs, and shopping) combined into one cute little package of a store with very kind service. I came here while on vacation recently and had a delightful afternoon here. You get a free coffee or tea with nail service. The manicure is expensive but I&#39;ve never had a regular manicure last as long as the one I received here. Also can we talk about the adorable kitsch decor? I couldn&#39;t get over the samosa shaped pillows and copper pipe details, cute!<br><br>If you are a local, ask for the rewards card! It&#39;s worth it!

text: Having arrived in Singapore in need of a manicure I found this place ion Yelp and decided to give it a try.  I arrived 1/2 hour early and was taken back right away.  My nail tech was quiet but very thorough and did a wonderful job.  It was expensive but she spent well over an hour cleaning up my sad nails.  I had a gel manicure and the cost was SGD$107.  About $77 USD.  I am well satisfied with my experience and would not hesitate to go back.

text: Great manicure, they are able to do lots of designs, I was visiting Singapore and needed a gel manicure and they did a great job

Amazing experience from walking in the speak easy like door through the coffee shop. I visited as I was only in town for a couple weeks and this was one of the best manicures I&#39;ve ever had. The quality of the gel was exceptional compared to what is sold in the USA, lasted 3+ weeks (in week 3 now, so may last even longer) and the time spent on the nails and cuticles and attention to detail was MUCH better than what I&#39;m used to. Quite expensive compared to other pricing but not sure how it compares to others in Singapore. That would be my only possible negative. With that said, I will visit this salon every time I come back to Singapore! Thank you for the lovely experience.
Best mani-pedi and gel nails I&#39;ve ever gotten, and I&#39;ve gotten plenty all over the world. Not cheap but totally worth it.

In my opinion this is THE FINEST destination for a manicure and pedicure in Singapore!!!

text: I came in to this darling hole-in-the-wall salon and I was so happy it was cute, clean and put together. I was a bit nervous at first starting out my pedicure (I&#39;m usually pretty picky with who does my nails) but I was actually pleasantly surprised at how well Amy did. She took her time and paid so much attention to detail without me even having to tell her what to look out for. Everyone there was sweet and I was treated with a French vanilla rose tea during my little stay and felt awesome after everything was done. I&#39;m glad I stumbled upon this place. I feel sooo much better! Thanks Amy, you&#39;re a doll!

Front entrance', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Front entrance'}]
text: I never did walk into Manicurious because I&#39;d always assume it was just a nail salon, and I wasn&#39;t wrong - it started out as a purely nail salon but has since evolved into a pretty cool concept store with retail and a cafe to boot. On the retail end as its name implies, it does have many curious items in the shop - lots of interesting accessories from shades, brooches and bags, sourced from local and international indie brands, so it&#39;s a good place to head to if you want something a little kooky. <br><br>Nail salon services are still available in the back, and you can get even get a quick mani/pedi during lunch if you&#39;re in a rush, while a tiny little cafe area with just 2-3 tables makes a good spot to chill out at after pampering your nails and a little shopping.<br><br>The sales people were really nice, including the nice guy who happily indulged me trying on a zillion pairs of sunglasses and my all my hmming and hawing. Will definitely be back again!

During a recent visit to Singapore, I was delighted to see that Yelp has a presence.  I came across this place while looking for places to to visit and stores to shop.  Reading the scant reviews, they were all positive.  <br><br>I was especially intrigued by the concept of a boutique, cafe and nail salon all in one.  I have to say, the items they sold were really cute and unique.  My daughter wolfed down a slice of their S&#39;Mores pie, so it must have been awesome.  I did not even get a chance to steal a bite! <br><br>My peek into the nail salon showed it to be clean and relaxing.  I wish I had the time to get my nails done.  Maybe during my next visit to Singapore, I&#39;ll get my own slice of pie while I get my nails done.

Great place for mani-pedi, this was the second manicure place I tried out in Singapore and I was satisfied with their services, staffs were friendly, paid attention to details, this would be the place for me to go on regular basis.

Did you get over the fact that I checked in here and wrote a review yet? If you&#39;re done laughing, you&#39;ll read that I didn&#39;t come here for a mani/pedi - not that I couldn&#39;t, of course.<br><br>A friend clued me into the different things in this store, and you&#39;ll see them all the moment you step in. In fact, the nail salon section is way back at the end of the shop space, and hidden behind a curtain. In front, you&#39;ll see a variety of things including Nooka watches, lots of trinkets and accessories, and even a little fridge full of Windowsill pies.<br><br>I came by for something different altogether - some handmade bags/pouches by local label Chroma. They come in a variety of colours, and you can customise a design/size for a small fee. My friend had a couple of these she&#39;d been using as wallets, and I found them really handy, so I popped over to the store to get some made. They take a week on average to get done, and if they&#39;re anything like what my friend&#39;s got, I&#39;d be super pleased!<br><br>Ask to see the samples and the colour swatches, and marvel and what patterns they&#39;ve got!

text: When you have an outstanding business Idea like this one, your staff should be much much more nice and friendly.<br><br>I asked for a mani pedi and that&#39;s all I got. A Mani Pedi<br><br>I ask for water, I got none. ;( I ask where is restroom no one tell me :( <br><br>Only reason I give two star because they have nice selection of polish

I stopped in this place on the way to a post dinner ice-cream fix at Tom&#39;s Palette. Unfortunately I never got to experience the coffee and sweet treats or the nail salon that other Yelper&#39;s rave about. <br><br>At the front of the store is the fashion retail section, where I instantly fell in love with all kinds of pretty and eccentric things like quirky jewellery, funky patterns, bags, stationary and other innovative and creative items on offer. The shop stocks international brands from Korean to Italy so you&#39;re to find something special. <br><br>I just had to buy something and I caved to a quirky grey pink felt bag by mrkt  with a pink fish scale pattern. (<a href="/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mrktstore.com%2Fproduct%2Fpandora-5%2F&amp;s=d27fabb7bbaf8067e171cda88637598caa7473addabe3f263642da376e0a5421" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">mrktstore.com/product/pa…</a>) <br><br>Manicurious is a fabulous find and is definitely worth a visit when you get tired of trawling through the markets for cutesy cheap Asian stuff. Not only do you get  to indulge your creative side, you can grab a coffee and a sweet treat and even get your nail done. <br>What a fabulous shop, please come to Australia!!!

Speaking of hidden finds, the wonderful smells from this windowsill give it away. Windowsill Pies has since moved into a nail salon in Beach Road, but staunch supporters of their delicious pies have followed their scent over to their new location<br><br>Manicurious chooses to specialise and concentrate on a simple menu of three extraordinary pies: the Morello Cherry ($6.50), Banana Cognac Almond Brittle ($6.00), and the Pumpkin Pie with Bourbon Whip ($6.40). The Morello is an unmistakably good choice as it is chockfull with tart and sweet morello cherries and topped with a shortcrust that lends a neutral and not-as-sweet balance.

I got to know about Manicurious as I was trying to find out where my favourite pie stall - Windowsill Pies - had gone after they moved out of their shop space at Pandan Valley. I recently found out that they had gone to Manicurious and I just had to drop by to have a slice of their pie. <br><br>Manicurious itself is a pretty cool concept stall that includes a nail parlour, a fashion and accessories boutique/retail area and a cafe. Windowsill Pies can be found in the cafe area and is definitely worth trying out! One of the best pies I have eaten in Singapore is their Sour Cherry Tart - tangy goodness in every bite, absolutely to die for.

A nail bar, fashion retail space and café all rolled into one, it&#39;s a pity that Manicurious doesn&#39;t more crowds, perhaps due to its location.<br><br>Though not much of a nail art fan (except for pedicures and manicures), Manicurious does offer a variety of beauty products and fashion accessories like bags, purses and jewelery with a quirky edge that is great for browsing. And if you get tired from the browsing, the café is the place to go to. <br><br>With a barista brewing up a mean cup of coffee with Papa Palheta beans, the coffee is exceptionally good.

text: Experience started out sketchy.  Was offered tea, never served, had to ask for the tea.  The website raves about nail art, specialty manicures etc.  I inquired about a chevron design for my fingernails.  You would have thought I had asked for moon dust.  After pulling up their FB page &amp; showing their photo I was informed the charge would be equivalent to a French mani.  Fine &amp; we proceed.  1/2 way thru they show me a black &amp; white sheet outlining all of these different designs (remember that when I asked they seemed clueless about design offerings) including the chevron and the $30 (in USD) up charge!!!  Very, very unprofessional &amp; deceptive.  This is the first negative online review I have ever done but this just has me boiling!  My advice...negotiate &amp; settle on your services first!!!  Ugghhh!

text: Must try  authentic Singaporean kopi! <br><br>Food/Drink: I just got the best selling iced kopi (iced coffee) and it was delicious. They have other drinks but they are famous for their kopi! <br><br>Price: Only 4 SGD for a cup (and that&#39;s only because I got it iced, it&#39;s 3 SGD if you get it hot). <br><br>Atmosphere: Great little hole in the wall with ample indoor and outdoor seating.

text: After a long day in Chinatown, this is the place to unwind. At a small corner inside the department store is where you find this place. Other drinks are available and there food too for those who want a bite to fill your belly. <br><br>Coffee is old style and the taste superb.

text: Staff seemed unwelcoming but coffee was good. Kaya butter toast was excellent; the bread was both crispy &amp; fluffy and the butter was the perfect amount of melt. Kopi-C was fine but not astounding. Good atmosphere, nice to sit outside.

text: Hey, I was hungry, and they were one of the only places open early in the morning, so I decided to try it out. Luckily, I was not disappointed. It&#39;s a little place on the corner.  There is both outdoor and indoor seating. You are sitting on short little stools in a crowded space inside, but it was okay.  They have free WiFi. <br><br>I had an iced coffee, the special, and toast. The toast was a little different. It consists of a thin square of butter between two pieces of toast. I would describe it as a butter sandwich.  It must be a local norm. The special was pretty good, with rice dough as the base. <br><br>The staff were friendly.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=KGXWpnGr-KS9HAfV0YUDgg', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/mAFvrsbwiK6wesXpxWJusA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/mAFvrsbwiK6wesXpxWJusA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/mAFvrsbwiK6wesXpxWJusA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/mAFvrsbwiK6wesXpxWJusA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/mAFvrsbwiK6wesXpxWJusA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/mAFvrsbwiK6wesXpxWJusA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Scott S.', 'displayLocation': 'Rancho Palos Verdes, CA', 'altText': 'Scott S.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=KGXWpnGr-KS9HAfV0YUDgg', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 924, 'photoCount': 4298, 'reviewCount': 932, 'eliteYear': 2022}
text: This is a very nice coffee house style café right next to Chinatown.  What this café offers is a very nice selection of lattes and other coffee-based drinks. Plus, they have a nice selection of juices and a few other drinks, as well. They also offer a nice selection of various food items. Each of these items are prepared individually so you know that they are fresh. Also, they have some various bakery items.<br><br>Perhaps the nicest thing about this coffee house is it&#39;s atmosphere. It is very old-school. You really get the feeling of old Singapore/old coffee house when you are visiting this business.<br><br>Overall, it is a really nice place to stop in for a quick pick me up, meal, or just to hang out and spend some time with your friends.

Black Coffee + Condensed Milk &amp; Evaporated Milk (Excellent)', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Black Coffee + Condensed Milk & Evaporated Milk (Excellent)'}]
text: Since I am not a huge coffee drinker and I don&#39;t know much about what makes a good cup of Joe, I did a bit or research to make sure I give this review some justice. Singapore&#39;s signature coffee is call a Kopi. And if I lived in Singapore, I would be an avid coffee drinker because of this one drink.<br><br>While walking around Chinatown, we happened upon this adorable, charming old-fashioned coffee/tea shop. Just the outside facade had me drawn to this place. There is no A/C but we didn&#39;t find it unbearably hot.<br><br>To understand how Kopi came about. I read that empty evaporated milk cans were used as takeaways cups. They pour coffee into it and well, you get the picture. Kopi is coffee that is brewed through and strained through socks or pantyhose. They do the back and forth pour method (fun to watch) and the mixture is skillfully poured between two pots. Condensed and evaporated milk is added. The sweetness cuts through the bitterness making for an unbelievable drink. Why it is not popular in the U.S. I have no idea.<br><br>The Kopi here is served in small cups. I can&#39;t help but admire how beautiful and adorable their cup and saucers are. I should have asked if I could buy a few home with me. We also enjoyed their Kaya toast which has coconut jam and a slice of cold butter, making for a sweet and salty little treat that goes well with your Kopi.<br><br>Don&#39;t hesitate to stop by this charming coffee shop!!

text: A small and locally owned food spot that offers various coffee variants and food.<br><br>Tried this spot for breakfast and was delighted that they served Kaya Butter Toast, which is a must try if you&#39;re in Singapore!<br><br>The Kaya Butter Toast costs S$2, which is such a steal. It comes with four slices that are lightly toasted and very fluffy. The inside is lined with generous amounts of butter. It&#39;s simple, light, and delicious. It goes well with coffee!<br><br>Plenty of seating inside and outside. My only issue is that the inside could use some cleaning. But overall a wonderful spot!

text: My sister and I were walking around Chinatown and came across Nanyang Old Coffee as we waited for the Buddha Tooth Relic Temple&#39;s display to open.<br><br>I never knew that Singapore Traditional Coffee was brewed with beans that were roasted with caramel sugar and butter. No wonder it has this buttery taste that I can&#39;t quite pinpoint. <br><br>I was excited to try the famous Singapore traditional coffee. The cafe had signs and posters explaining how they roast the coffee beans.<br><br>I ordered the kopi siew dai, which is just black coffee with less condensed milk. It&#39;s very aromatic and full bodied, and has just the right amount of sweetness. I was instantly energized!<br><br>Overall, Nanyang Old Coffee was solid. I should&#39;ve tried their kaya toast too.

text: Nice coffee shop right in Singapore Chinatown.  My first time trying Kaya Toast here and I loved it!  I also ordered the Kopi (coffee with condensed milk, a couple steamed buns and dim sum.  All of the food and coffee was worth trying and it was cheap!  Make a stop here if you are in the area for a quick breakfast and visit the tiny coffee museum in the back.

text: Stopped by for a quick coffee fix in Chinatown and found this lovely gem.<br><br>Ordered Kopi O (black coffee), Kopi C (coffee with condensed milk) and pandan cake. Served in little china cups, the coffee was excellent. Would definitely recommend Kopi C - the bitter notes of the coffee blends beautifully with the condensed milk!

Ang ku kueh', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Ang ku kueh'}]
text: The little cafe in the Singapore Chinatown has a wide selection of traditional drinks, snacks, and savory meals. There are two entrances: one is the main entrance and has a counter at which you place your order, and one to extra seating and the free coffee exhibit/museum.<br><br>We visited on a hot, rainy day for some afternoon snacks, and ordered an ice blended mocha (Ice blended means the ice is crushed and mixed in.), an ice blended milk tea, an ice blended lemon sour plum drink (So refreshing in the hot weather!), an ang ku kueh (red tortoise cake), and kaya butter toast. We ordered the mocha and the kaya butter toast as part of a set, which gives you a choice of any hot or cold beverage, and is a real deal. Though I didn&#39;t try any of the savory dishes, I thought it was a great afternoon tea place with reasonable pricing. The only thing I wish could be improved was the taste of the kaya, which lacked its strong, signature coconut taste, and tasted a bit like generic jam.<br><br>Unfortunately, we didn&#39;t have time to explore the museum, but given the chance, I would go back for their drinks and see the exhibit.

text: It was hot and humid in Singapore (aka usual Singapore weather).  We just completed our visit the the Singapore Chinese Heritage Museum (good really worthwhile  visit) when we discovered Nanyang Old Coffee.<br><br>We ordered the iced Coffee!<br><br>The iced coffee was fantastic!  Good strong coffee with the cream perfectly incorporated into the drink.<br><br>Good place for coffee while in Singapore Chinatown.

text: I was never an avid coffee drinker, but this traditional coffee shop had me sold. Definitely one of the best coffees I&#39;ve had, it was creamy yet the coffee flavor was still intense but not overwhelmingly bitter. Personally, it was a perfect balance of sweetness and creaminess. Definitely recommend checking it out in Chinatown. Didn&#39;t even know it was actual a famous coffee shop. Stopped by because I wanted a cold drink to get through the humid Singaporean weather, and lucky for us, there was no wait. My friend told me she passed by yesterday and apparently the lines were pretty long.

text: Friendly service and nice to rest your feet after walking all over the area. <br>Popular for old sg coffee which is basically milk and coffee. I had the blended version which is made w ice and served cold. <br>Tasted great. No complaints here.

text: Although very crowded and touristy, this is a good sample of local coffee and toast. The Singlish placemats add to the charm.
Good coffee and kaya toast but don&#39;t expect good customer service. The people who worked there doesn&#39;t not smile and they look like they hate their jobs.

text: Stopped here during my short trip to Singapore. This was actually the first coffee shop I visited and everything that followed was varying levels of disappointment.<br>This shop is right on the outer shirts of china town which would make you think it&#39;s a tourist trap.  The interior is really trendy with hints of traditional decor.  As a foreigner they made ordering very simple with the simple to understand coffee chart.  By far the most flavorful cup I have during the entire trip.  Service was also excellent and the bathroom and table were clean. For a coffee shop that&#39;s pretty much all you need to do to be successful.

text: Mmm, not authentic nanyang/hainanese coffee. Prolly catered towards tourist market(non SEA) region.<br>The kaya toast is decent but abit dry.<br>My hainanese ancestors will disapprove.

text: Singapore is the perfect place to have local Chinese style breakfast. They called it &#39;kopi tiam&#39; or place to have coffee. The simple simple breakfast usually a cup of coffee or tea with &#39;kaya&#39; jam sandwich and half boiled eggs in a bowl. Of course, this place also have &#39;nasi lemak&#39; and cakes. Very popular with locals.

text: What&#39;s more refreshing than a cold beer while roaming Chinatown in the heat?<br><br>An Iced cold Ice Blended Kopi from Nanyang Old Coffee!!!<br><br>Love that retro look and decoration.<br><br>What&#39;s make Singaporean Coffee different than the one I used to drink? It is all in the beans. Singapore Traditional Coffee bean is roasted with small portion caramel sugar and butter or margarine and brewed it traditional handmade method. <br><br>The coffee is strong, sweet and has this wholesome feel. Smooth and full of aroma........<br><br>Sipping my iced coffee with a big smile on my face! I had a photo to prove that too!

text: Stumbled across this place by accident while roaming through Chinatown looking for breakfast.  We chose this place because my bf needed an emergency pit stop to the bathroom.  I can&#39;t comment on the bathroom facilities because I was a bit afraid to go in there after he was done.  :/<br><br>The menu listed a Kopitiam set for only $3.50, yay!  I also saw a beautiful photo of Bah Kuh Teh that we unfortunately didn&#39;t get a chance to come back and try for lunch.<br><br>Standard Kopitiam breakfast with runny eggs, Singaporian coffee, and kaya butter toast.  Simple decor with a cute old-fashioned look with a mini Singapore coffee museum which was literally just a few ancient artifacts displayed in the back room.<br><br>I was excited to let my bf try a wife cake (one of my all-time favs from Taiwan), but I was a bit disappointed at the greasy pastry that ended up before us.  Not sure if this was typical Singaporean style or a rancid leftover, but it was nothing like the light, flaky ones I&#39;ve had from Taiwan.<br><br>We also grabbed some bottles of grass jelly to quench our thirst, and I didn&#39;t realize they were mint-flavored.  So that was a bit weird, but still interesting to try something new.

text: For a visiting tourist I would maybe slightly edge this place as it&#39;s charming, it&#39;s located within Chinatown. The other would be killiney kopitiam on killiney rd which is more for locals. To be honest ya kun is my favorite but this place is good too.

text: I actually only came here because my hostel (Royal Hostel) had a breakfast deal with them. The line at 8am was fairly long though which suggests good things - line also moved fairly fast.<br><br>I got the lo mai gai - or sticky rice chicken. Usually a dim sum item, steamed while wrapped in a lotus leaf. There was no lotus leaf here, but it was actually pretty tasty overall. It did lack the characteristic leaf flavor but the rice was cooked very well and the sauce had a terrific depth of meatiness and savoriness. I would recommend it.

My favorite spot for a Kopitiam breakfast set! Coffee is always delicious and strong. Eggs and Kaya toast also delicious. Good covered seating outside with fans. Seating inside with AC. Breakfast set is only $4.20. Service is always quick and friendly. <br><br>Recommended over the Kopitiam chains in town!

text: One of my must stops when In Singapore. Grab a cup of copi and a snack. Sit inside and feel like you&#39;re in a different era or sit outside and slow down and enjoy the day.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/pJMNdqkBUdpMIfDgLfk-dg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/nanyang-old-coffee-singapore?reviewid=uc1W3PhyB-iSqkIAwxHmUg&select=pJMNdqkBUdpMIfDgLfk-dg', 'altText': 'Photo of Nanyang Old Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: In a world where everything&#39;s moving so fast, and the youth moving on to &#39;ang moh&#39; coffee la, espresso this and macchiato that, it&#39;s nice to know that places like this that serve a mean cuppa good ol&#39; coffee (like the Samsui women used to sip!) still exist.<br><br>This is the best out of the old-world cafés (Ya Kun, Wangz, etc) in my opinion. Great toast and kaya, fragrant coffee served in the traditional white cups and saucers, though the Nyonya Nasi Lemak is a huge, huge disappointment (probably one of the factory made, pre-packed variety). The coffee aunties are sweet and nice (just like the coffee - if you like it with condensed milk!), and we might move on to beans from Rwanda and Ecuador, but it&#39;s nice to know what kept our country awake and working (and growing to the finesse it is today!) during the 60s! Take a sip of some rich, rich delicious history.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ygBesncMYkNCLTRWDKCLuQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/sam-yat-coffee-singapore?reviewid=T9L-7NB19FhjiIh3fw0xCw&select=ygBesncMYkNCLTRWDKCLuQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Sam Yat Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: I really enjoyed this place! It was right by our hostel (the COO) and there were both meal and dessert options. The prices were decent and the food was good. The sell laksa, pat bing soo, kopi, etc. It&#39;s not too busy but there&#39;s always people eating food!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/-CJGA1oIAnMm24bQ9VT5Aw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/sam-yat-coffee-singapore?reviewid=ombGYeYMdcAq3BrplV4uVg&select=-CJGA1oIAnMm24bQ9VT5Aw', 'altText': 'Photo of Sam Yat Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/A7U8AS2WCXBIjYdjOBJQ_g/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/sam-yat-coffee-singapore?reviewid=ombGYeYMdcAq3BrplV4uVg&select=A7U8AS2WCXBIjYdjOBJQ_g', 'altText': 'Photo of Sam Yat Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: The cafe was opened by the people behind Tiong Bahru Pau. Besides items from Tiong Bahru Pau, the kopi style cafe also offered simple local dishes such as Kaya Toast, Mee Rebus, Curry Chicken, Chee Cheong Fun, as well as, Bingsu and French Toast. Only cash payment was accepted.<br><br>Scrambled Egg on Toast ($3)<br>The seasoning on the scrambled egg was a tab uneven as it was a bit too salty on one side. I wish the toast was more crispy.<br><br>Cendol ($3.90)<br>It was quite expensive for a cendol. The dessert was served with a bottle of gula melaka syrup where one can add additional to sweeten the dessert. The ice was shaved rather fine here which was why it melted rather fast and easily.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=XzJDB_XdAZnOAtQqhtT6yw', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'Cheeyuen L.', 'displayLocation': 'Whitchurch-Stouffville, Canada', 'altText': 'Cheeyuen L.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=XzJDB_XdAZnOAtQqhtT6yw', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 65, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 1, 'eliteYear': None}
text: This place serves authentic local fare with very reasonable prices.  The place is really clean and well ventilated - always a good way to enjoy a meal in hot and humid Singapore.  <br><br>There is also a lot of attention to details, eg the green jelly in  chendol, the type of spoons used, etc<br><br>Keep up the great work. <br><br>P/s: we had laksa, Milo dinosaur, mango shaved ice, honey lemon water, honey aloe water,  chendol.

text: Atas breakfast without the crazy prices. Ample dining air-conditioned dining too. Same family business from Tiong Bahru Pau, so pick up whatever you need and eat right in here. If not you&#39;ll have options like curry chicken too! Friendly staff and also very new and clean. Even the fruit juice is one of those slow juice kind. Highly recommended. roadside parking.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/NDa-s6AzQkfM-XkRP1EaAw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/sam-yat-coffee-singapore?reviewid=jzSv8VN37XToeXcjFiqN2w&select=NDa-s6AzQkfM-XkRP1EaAw', 'altText': 'Photo of Sam Yat Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Cute place - loved the simple clean decor. And I loved that it has local food - a welcome change to all the hipster cafes in the area.<br><br>Azuki bingsu ($6) - 4 stars<br>There&#39;s more azuki inside! This was milky and tasted kind of like eating cereal for breakfast once the the shaved ice melted to become milk and we were eating it with the cornflakes on top. Good though!<br><br>Injeolmi bingsu ($6) - 3.5 stars<br>This one tasted like oat and almond granola - it was more nutty - but the injeolmi wasn&#39;t very sweet and I wasn&#39;t quite impressed. It was my first time having injeolmi. It was good overall but I preferred the azuki bingsu.

I&#39;m obsessed. Kaya toast became an obsession in Singapore and I ate it every morning for the duration I was in Singapore. This place is super local and super cheap. The staff here is super warm and friendly, they explained how to eat the kaya toast to me here (although I had been warned and watched youtube videos on how to do), but I appreciated the friendliness. I went a little bit after it opened and there were quite a few customers already. Lots of people that were definitely regulars as the person at the register knew their orders. The food came out quickly and the ordering process is really swift. Definitely always get the soft boiled eggs with the kaya toast it is EVERYTHING. <br><br>I wish they had places with real kaya toast in the US....

Kaya toast', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Kaya toast'}]
text: I came here after reading all the great reviews but was a bit disappointed TBH. I wanted to start my day with authentic Singaporean breakfast - Kaya toast and eggs with kopi and hence got here.<br><br>The food was good but the place was too small and cramped, service was bad and staff was unfriendly. You need to first wait to be seated, then note your table number and then go to the counter to place the order. You need to mention the table number when you place your order. And they&#39;ll bring the food to your table. <br><br>We were seated in a table and once I went to the counter to place the order, they moved my family over to a different table. I had to go back and change the order again to update the table number. <br><br>Also they don&#39;t provide you napkins, so make sure you get your own or have a back up plan.<br><br>Portions were very small and even though I placed 3 orders of the breakfast, they brought all the food in one plate. I had to then ask them to get us additional plates, bowls, utensils since 3 of us would be eating (what were they thinking?).<br><br>Food was good, but there are many other places with much better service and much better food and portions. I would skip this one and find a better place.

text: If you are looking for something local and fast, this is the place to come. We came in at 800 right before a crowd came in so we had no trouble finding a table. The servers are kind and attentive. <br><br>I&#39;m giving them three stars because the food was okay. We ordered the Bread Toast, Laksa, and Nasi Lemak with Otah. For drinks, we ordered the Organic Chinese Tea and the Coffee with milk.

text: This place became our daily morning ritual on our trip to Singapore, for some reason we were up by 4am almost everyday, and with waking up came the hunger.. a quick search in yelp showed this place open, it close to our hotel so that was a plus as well, and so we went... the food was great! It was tasty and inexpensive, the place was clean enough, my only gripe is that they don&#39;t give you any napkins (I noticed a lot of places here don&#39;t), so if you are messy eater like myself, bring some on your own, other than that our experience here was more than satisfactory, it fed us when we were hungry at an odd time in the morning, it was tasty, cheap, and clean enough... the Chicken Curry was easily the best dish! <br>Would definitely recommend.

Toast and eggs', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Toast and eggs'}]
text: Yes, yes, and more yes!  Simplest breakfast foods ever, but SO GOOD that I had it twice during my stay in Singapore.  Kaya Toast, soft boiled eggs, and soy milk with grass jelly cost no more than ~5 SGD!!!  Walk up to the counter, order, pay, sit down, and out comes to the food.  Nothing fancy, just plain and simple.<br><br>This place is an institution and has a lot of history to it.  Great to visit and to try especially how cheap it is.  This one is also the original in Singapore, so def visit.  Consider also getting a jar of the kaya spread.  You can even try to make it yourself at home.  I did.  *___*

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/1iXwlxT7ESULYVh_YsKPOg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/killiney-kopitiam-singapore-4?reviewid=ZUTlJFsTfEpErfgB_J7Dow&select=1iXwlxT7ESULYVh_YsKPOg', 'altText': 'Photo of Killiney Kopitiam - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: I didn&#39;t know such old-school kopitiam still exists today, and right in the heart of Orchard Road at that!<br><br>I was having a post-wedding staycation at Lloyd&#39;s Inn, and the stay includes a breakfast set at this place. We came late and coincided with the lunch crowd who were mainly there for some after-lunch coffee/tea.<br><br>We ordered the simple toast set/french toast set which was simple and yet so filling!<br><br>My french toast set had egg mixed in with the bread and layered on top, with kaya and a slice of butter on the side. It reminded me of my primary school days breakfast that my grandma made for me; I vow to recreate this at home next time!<br><br>I also ordered the Ginger Tea sans milk and it was very &#39;hot&#39; (in my tummy) and strong; good for removing excess wind in the stomach.<br><br>Will certainly drop by this place again if I&#39;m craving some good &#39;ole toast and coffee/tea!<br><br>A tip is to come here before or after the lunch crowd (say before 12pm or from 145pm onwards).

Mee cheong', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Mee cheong'}]
text: Hands down the best traditional S&#39;pore breakfast I&#39;ve had during my week here.<br><br>The first kaya breakfast I had in my life was at the big chain, Ya Kun Kaya Toast. You can see it in the food levels of Singapore&#39;s many malls around the city, or like we also did, visit the original location on China Street in between Telok Ayer and Chinatown. But Killiney&#39;s original location on Killiney Road a little walk&#39;s away from Somerset was just as quaint and much more delicious in my opinion.<br><br>Their system of ordering is at the cashier once you&#39;ve found a table. You can&#39;t order items unless you can provide a table number, so if you&#39;re with a buddy, have them take over a table while someone else puts the orders in. MAJOR KEY. We had their soft boiled eggs and kaya toast, mee cheong, mee siam, and iced tea/coffee. We ate like kings for about $20-$30 I believe. I don&#39;t remember the actual amount, but it should be around that price--pretty great for Singapore.<br><br>My favorite was their kaya toast. SO much thicker and still crisp compared to Ya Kun&#39;s, and their spread was less sugary like Ya Kun does it. I even bought a jar of kaya spread to take home to the States! I loved it THAT much (kaya is essentially pandan, coconut milk, eggs, and sugar). I can&#39;t wait to use it on my toast at home. <br><br>Their iced tea was SO good, not overly sweet like at Ya Kun, and definitely freshly made with fresh foam on top of my cup. We were so excited about our first order, that at the end I put in an order for mee siam after looking around their shop at the photos. That wasn&#39;t my favorite item, but the egg was cooked to perfection, and the sauce was a hint spicy with lots of flavor. Service is QUICK and their workers are all bosses at efficient food running and order taking. Hats off.

text: Delicious Curry chicken rice for $6.80. The curry rice come with thick fragrant gravy with a lot of potatoes and meat. Fast serving and big portion. Definitely will return for lunch!

Kopi', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Kopi'}]
text: It was really my first taste of the authentic Singaporean breakfast of Kaya toast, egg and topi, for my standards, I thought it was pretty darn good. The coffee is strong but not over powering. I love the sweetness from the condensed milk. The eggs were done perfectly and the toast had a good amount of coconut jam (kaya) and was crunchy enough to soak up all the egg deliciousness. <br><br>Tip: Don&#39;t be afraid to add soy sauce to the eggs because it adds a extra layer of flavour to the egg and sweet bread combination.

text: I wanted a taste to see what a typical Singaporean breakfast would be like. <br><br>This place was really packed in the morning. I ordered two types of sweet toast and some fried noodle rolls. Everything was super sweet. It was definitely unique and worth a try especially if you are a tourist.

Stopped by here one morning to have breakfast during my visit to Singapore.<br>It was not a great experience. It was a combination of language barrier, overly spicy food for breakfast, and a jam-packed interior. Most of what we ordered was not available, their boiled eggs were essentially raw, even after we made a request for done eggs.<br>Not coming back to this particular one for sure.

text: Grabbed breakfast here. Got coffee, soft boiled eggs, rice cake, and some type of toast. Coffee has condensed milk in it, so it was super sweet. The toast was also really sweet as well, I&#39;m not a fan of sweets really and I don&#39;t usually eat breakfast either. Definitely not my first choice, but my friends liked it. Service was nice and attentive.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=biNk2izKRsujpMUT-0WKLg', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/twSw16-Hr2BfGs5hZF9FYg/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/twSw16-Hr2BfGs5hZF9FYg/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/twSw16-Hr2BfGs5hZF9FYg/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/twSw16-Hr2BfGs5hZF9FYg/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/twSw16-Hr2BfGs5hZF9FYg/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/twSw16-Hr2BfGs5hZF9FYg/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Chris S.', 'displayLocation': 'San Francisco, CA', 'altText': 'Chris S.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=biNk2izKRsujpMUT-0WKLg', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 20, 'photoCount': 41, 'reviewCount': 117, 'eliteYear': None}
text: A great place to grab a cheap and delicious breakfast. In fact, I went here twice for breakfast while in Singapore The Kaya spread that had a unique combination of mildly sweet yet savory taste to it. I&#39;d recommend the french toast and spread some of that kaya goodness with it. The coffee also goes well with the toast. The coffee is also well balanced and goes well with the toast (keep in mind that the coffee with cream is sweet due to the condensed milk that they use so order without sugar so you can adjust the sweetness after you&#39;ve tasted it). I also order the laksa which was creamy and cocconuty with a slight spice kick (it wasn&#39;t too spicy but just enough).

Toast and eggs', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Toast and eggs'}]
text: Yes, yes, and more yes!  Simplest breakfast foods ever, but SO GOOD that I had it twice during my stay in Singapore.  Kaya Toast, soft boiled eggs, and soy milk with grass jelly cost no more than ~5 SGD!!!  Walk up to the counter, order, pay, sit down, and out comes to the food.  Nothing fancy, just plain and simple.<br><br>This place is an institution and has a lot of history to it.  Great to visit and to try especially how cheap it is.  This one is also the original in Singapore, so def visit.  Consider also getting a jar of the kaya spread.  You can even try to make it yourself at home.  I did.  *___*

Kids loved their French bread kaya toast so much, had to buy a few jars to take back home to Cali. Love their quick n friendly service, n u gotta love the prices!

text: Open seating and it&#39;s always full in the mornings. We went there on a Sunday morning around 10am and it was packed. Come 11am and there&#39;s a few vacant tables already. <br>Food is simple yet good. I had the soft boiled eggs with Kaya toast. Hot coffee and iced tea. Really good!  You can also buy their Kaya jam jar to take home.

First day in Singapore and this place was near the hotel.  Was looking for Kaya toast and Killiney was recommended.  It was very good and cheap (Set A; $4.80 sing).  Small shop and very busy, and people were eating all sorts of things for breakfast.  I think I may return to try some variety, but there is food everywhere in the area and I&#39;ve got a few days.  Coffee (dark with condensed milk) hit the spot.

text: Delicious kaya toast and French bread. The egg was nice and runny-- perfect for dipping.

text: We stumble upon this amazing breakfast place. I have never had Kaya toast and wanted to try. OMG! It was so good! Also, i ordered the ginger milk tea (amazing) and the Laksa noodles. I was super impressed with everything and will head back before i leave tomorrow.

I walked by this shop almost daily for weeks without realizing how much of a Singaporean institution it is. I did notice that it was packed almost all day, every day no matter the time nor weather. My partner and I stopped by one Sunday afternoon for a lunch and iced coffee after I discovered its notoriety. <br><br>You order and pay at the front counter, so its better to know what you want before you come in. Its usually pretty busy but especially packed in the mornings. The menu is pretty limited and I didn&#39;t have the chance to try too much, but there&#39;s a nice variety of items to choose from whether you want a snack or a meal. I&#39;ve had the chicken curry with prata and it was delicious. The curry itself was rich and flavorful with a couple of bone-in pieces of chicken and potatoes. The prata is perfect for soaking up the spicy curry goodness.<br><br>The iced kopi was a perfect mix of rich, strong coffee and creamy sweetness. And it was perfectly priced. All in all, the meal is incredibly tasty and the price can&#39;t be beat. If its reputation doesn&#39;t pull you in, its value will.

text: Excellent home made kaya toast and white coffee for breakfast! Service is fast and food is cheap too.

This is one of my &#34;must-eats&#34; when I am back in Singapore.  Worked close by a few years ago and had my breakfast here almost every day.  My absolute favourite is Mea Siam.  Love the spicy, tangy soup and the generous portion and very reasonable price.  Service is so so, though after a while once staff knows you it becomes a family affair.  Don&#39;t forget to get some Iced Milo to go with it or top it off with some Kaya Toast.  <br>You really cannot go wrong here as all is delicious.<br>A word of caution though:  Killiney Kopitiam has various outlets around Singapore.  However, the food is not as you would expect from a chain.  The tastes and quality of the food vary greatly from outlet to outlet.  So if you want the best then stick to Killiney Road.<br>Seating is usually limited with some waiting involved especially in the morning.

text: Grabbed breakfast here. Got coffee, soft boiled eggs, rice cake, and some type of toast. Coffee has condensed milk in it, so it was super sweet. The toast was also really sweet as well, I&#39;m not a fan of sweets really and I don&#39;t usually eat breakfast either. Definitely not my first choice, but my friends liked it. Service was nice and attentive.

A great place to have your coffee and if you want to know what this first store of a big kopitiam chain is like. Go in, pick your table, go to the counter and make your order mentioning your table number. <br><br>The coffee is tasteful not just a bland black water. the softboiled eggs are perfect. Couldn&#39;t ask more from a good kopitiam place.

text: Love this place, fatty but amazing! The Kaya toast had coconut Pandan and egg white the flavors are sooooooo good! If you are a pineapple bun fan you will definitely love this! I was in Singapore for 3 days and came here every day!!

Killiney Road, with the signboard for Killiney Kopitiam', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Killiney Road, with the signboard for Killiney Kopitiam'}]
text: This landmark kopitiam is where I go when I&#39;m usually craving a quick bite of unhealthy local fare. (I&#39;m here like maybe once a week) <br><br>It&#39;s not air-conditioned and has a very old-school feel. <br><br>The food is admittedly pretty average, but it is always crowded with locals at all hours. <br>I always get the laksa (although personally, I feel the Katong Laksa tastes better) and chee cheong fun. My friends are fans of the mee siam.<br><br>I like their teh-si peng which is just nice in its sweetness. <br><br>I top my meal off with a local dessert like cheng tng or grass jelly with longan.  <br><br>Price-wise it&#39;s still in the cheap range although it&#39;s expensive for a kopitiam. <br><br>The manager (?) of the restaurant who takes my orders is this friendly Chinese woman who is always happy to have a chat and a laugh.

text: Chicken curry is a better choice compared to the mee rebus. I don&#39;t think I can appreciate this kind of food. The staff is nice though.

text: 7am and they are packed like sardines in a can.<br>from taxi drivers to policemen to working crowd on their way to the office.<br><br>seating space can be a little crampy.<br><br>you order at one counter, pay at another then grab a sit and your order will find it&#39;s way to you.<br><br>a french loaf set is only $4.85.<br>you get a good cup of teh c.<br>2 half boiled eggs, mine was slightly overcooked today<br>local sized baguette, toasted well to melt the kaya and butter spread within.<br>it can be messy to eat as a result but they have an easy to access tap for washing up afterwards.<br><br>parking is definitely a nightmare and tickets will fly for illegal parking around here.

Epitome of the meaning, &#34;a little goes a long way&#34;. The menu is quite simple with just a couple of main breakfast items. The ambiance is very local and can feel like an old school breakfast cafe in the colonial times (maybe i am overdoing that but still feels authentically Singapore).<br><br>Kaya Toast w/ Butter - The basic high calorie high fast working mans breakfast. <br>Chicken Curry w/ Roti - a great go to local breakfast meal. Be careful as the curry splashes.<br>Laksa - Same thing...splashes<br>Assorted Breakfast drinks but my favorite is the Ginger tea w/ Milk. <br><br>These are the only things I eat when I break bread here. I guess I am a creature of habit. I tell you though with their consistently good turn around I can gather that the everything else is good stuff to.

This is the place where it all began. <br>Where everyone is treated as an equal, <br>and where the lines know no end. <br><br>There was a time when Kaya toast was hard to find. <br>When half boiled eggs were a rarity,<br>and dark sauce symbolized true darkness. <br><br>Not anymore, but I&#39;ll still keep coming back here for both the good vibes and the memories.

First day in Singapore and this place was near the hotel.  Was looking for Kaya toast and Killiney was recommended.  It was very good and cheap (Set A; $4.80 sing).  Small shop and very busy, and people were eating all sorts of things for breakfast.  I think I may return to try some variety, but there is food everywhere in the area and I&#39;ve got a few days.  Coffee (dark with condensed milk) hit the spot.

text: Got the French bread kaya toast and wholemeal bun kaya toast and they were both great! Also got mee rebus n that was pretty good,got a lil kick to it. Kids loved their French bread kaya toast so much, had to buy a few jars to take back home to Cali. Love their quick n friendly service, n u gotta love the prices!

text: authentic traditional Singapore breakfast!  we ordered and just watched to get a feel for how exactly to tackle the meal :) my mistake was getting the French toast first time, my husband got the regular toast with the Kaya and I made sure to get that our second time in!  get your table, order, sit and enjoy. good coffee, quick service, the eggs were runny enough and the toast was perfect to dip.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=OwKgErB62F7947UEZ5lqVw', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/xRlLSBQiDqmK0G4ClepQcA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/xRlLSBQiDqmK0G4ClepQcA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/xRlLSBQiDqmK0G4ClepQcA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/xRlLSBQiDqmK0G4ClepQcA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/xRlLSBQiDqmK0G4ClepQcA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/xRlLSBQiDqmK0G4ClepQcA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Ben K.', 'displayLocation': 'San Francisco, CA', 'altText': 'Ben K.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=OwKgErB62F7947UEZ5lqVw', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 312, 'photoCount': 205, 'reviewCount': 133, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Killiney Kopitiam is a mainstay in Singapore&#39;s breakfast culture, and has been for many years.  They know it too - they sell small jars of fresh kaya that can be carefully packaged for a long flight (well, Singapore&#39;s just one island, so all the flights are international).  There&#39;s a number of things you can buy as gifts - I have actually done this and it&#39;s a great gift for friends or family.<br><br>Come to Killiney during morning primetime, and you&#39;ll likely be queuing up outside and/or hovering around a table waiting for people to finish feeding themselves.  The queue for ordering food is also a bit annoying - it&#39;s disorganized and right next to people sitting at tables.  Frequently you have to move around to let servers go by or let customers in/out.  Considering the size of the place, this should be expected (and in Singapore space is at a premium), so it&#39;s not a huge issue.  Your average hawker center probably has less room to maneuver.  <br><br>As for the food, it&#39;s the best kaya toast I&#39;ve had in Singapore, the laksa and mee rebus are both great, and their kopi c/teh c/yuan yang drinks are all top notch.  The french loaf kaya toast and soft-boiled eggs combination is something I&#39;ve recommended to many of my friends before, and also unique to Singapore.  I&#39;ve checked - no one else sells a french loaf like this.  It&#39;s kind of like banh mi bread - a baguette that&#39;s toasted and crispy but soft and fluffy at the same time.  The kaya is fresh and when combined with the melted butter, is heaven in your mouth. It&#39;s hard not to eat 2 of these french loaves when they&#39;re SUCH a good value.  A french loaf, 2 eggs, and a kopi will be about half the price of any other sit-down breakfast in Singapore.  Sometimes the staff can be a bit rude - probably because they are an institution for kaya toast and the queue is pretty constant during the entire morning.  Most of the time I had pleasant experiences with the staff, and most of the time my table was clean when I sat down (again, this is about what you can expect with low-cost casual dining in Singapore).<br><br>I should say this - this Killiney Kopitiam location is the original, and the best by far.  I have always had great quality food here, whereas other locations are VERY hit-and-miss (usually a miss).  I started going out of my way to come here, even though I was working within walking distance of the Raffles location.  Just don&#39;t think that the rating and quality of this place will be the same island-wide, or at the airport.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=A-8ziBhkw7KAVymBxN6loA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/gIdCDyqf5qDGiWMd51zqlg/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/gIdCDyqf5qDGiWMd51zqlg/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/gIdCDyqf5qDGiWMd51zqlg/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/gIdCDyqf5qDGiWMd51zqlg/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/gIdCDyqf5qDGiWMd51zqlg/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/gIdCDyqf5qDGiWMd51zqlg/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Outsourced N.', 'displayLocation': 'San Antonio, TX', 'altText': 'Outsourced N.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=A-8ziBhkw7KAVymBxN6loA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 138, 'photoCount': 597, 'reviewCount': 417, 'eliteYear': None}
text: This joint is the perfect place to step back from the hustle and bustle of Orchard street during the day to grab a kopi or a perfect start to the day!<br><br>This place is old with chipped tables and plates and always crowded, but the modus operandi is to grab the first empty chair and signal the old man or woman over and get the morning started with slices of bread toasted over a charcoal fire, kaya (coconut egg jam), two soft boiled eggs and kopi.  Grab a small bowl toss in soy sauce, white pepper and get to it by buttering one slice of bread ..spreading kaya, breaking an egg, splashing soy and one bite of that delicious chewy bread, rich yolk, sweet kaya and the nice bit of salt from the soy sauce and tingly white pepper and you know your day is going to be okay!!  A few sips of the kopi and all is good!<br><br>I have been to a few other locations, but this is my favorite.  Not to mention that there is a fabulous mutton puff shop two doors down that makes a crazy good mutton curry puff!

Long time visitor, one of my favorite breakfast place in Singapore. I&#39;ve tried the kaya toast, nasi lemak, curry chicken, and mee laksa, never disappointed. Loving the white coffee, too. Come early in the morning (they open from 6am), it gets busier around 9ish.

A favorite haunt of mine, it&#39;s great for ol&#39;fashioned breakfast after a night of clubbing or an intense mahjong session. <br><br>I&#39;ve been coming here since my secondary school days just to hang out with friends when I get sick of Starbucks and the like, and need some good ol&#39; kaya toast with soft-boiled eggs. Never really liked their laksa, but the chee cheong fun here is pretty decent as well, should you not feel like kaya toast! <br><br>The prices here are cheap, and service is quick. I also enjoy the random meetings that occur here with friends I&#39;ve not seen for a while.
Nice kopi; even better kaya toasts.<br><br>One thing that grabs your attention is the many humorously pessimistic excerpts on marriage stuck on the walls.

text: Great little clinic-looking Killiney joint with zero ambience to get your daily kopi jolt and observe the kaleidoscope of humanity around you all enjoying the same.

text: This popular old establishment in Singapore is a great place for morning breakfast. When we arrived at this restaurant, it was crowded with locals. The menu is quite extensive. We ordered kaya toast, soft boiled eggs and nasi lemak for breakfast which was delicious. Great to go with a cup of teh tarik. Price wise - cheap and cheerful!

This is the ORIGINAL Killiney Kopitiam. As in the very first one. Indeed, you get a real sense of nostalgia when you step in and sit and the old school marble kopitiam tables. You know they have been there a long time, not the sort that people buy at furniture stores for the &#34;vintage look&#34;. The curry chicken and mee rebus here are famous, and for good reason. The curry chicken is one of the best, if not the best I have tried in Singapore. It&#39;s super thick and aromatic and the chicken and potatoes are cooked just right. You can really taste the fresh spices and coconut that have gone into making that delicious gravy. It also has a real kick of spiciness, not like the lousy curries you get in food courts that are oily and one note. If i were to nitpick, I would say that sometimes the chicken has that faint chickeny taste you get when the chicken used isn&#39;t super fresh.

text: Due to it&#39;s location, very basic Sg breakfast fare is being sold at an inflated price  the kaya toast &amp; tea is only average. Would not come here unless desperate because there&#39;s a chain outlet for kaya toast just slightly down the road at the main shopping area which is Air Conditioned.

text: One of the many great cafes at millennia walk-love how quiet it is (off lunch hours). You can always count on them for a good cup of Joe and recommendations on beans!<br><br>There are also power plugs at the side with high tables to ensure that your devices are fully charged for meetings and work! Staff are friendly and approachable, don&#39;t be afraid to ask for recommendations! :)

It&#39;s been awhile, Yelp, it&#39;s been awhile. Let me start this review by saying I am not a coffee drinker. I grew up grinding coffee beans for my mum and brewing them in a french press and somehow the overdose of aromas, maybe the bitter overtones, turned me off coffee. I am also highly sensitive to caffeine and sugar since I drink water and eat fresh food where possible.  Oh and of course that time I had a latte at a Starbucks in a central Singapore location and it gave me the worst stomach ache a few hours later (they apologized, said it was the milk and offered vouchers - which was sweet, but I wasn&#39;t about to get myself sick again). <br><br>All this to say that when I DO choose to drink a coffee, it has to look really inviting and pleasurable. Jewel Coffee does just that. I enjoy wine and analyzing it so this is the best I can piece apart the coffee at Jewel. The red velvet latte is made of brewed coffee from one country, steamed milk and then some red velvet powder. There isn&#39;t any sugar added so you can do what you please at the condiment station. <br><br>In wine, a single grape variety can deliver a good profile of flavors without the haphazardness of a blend of grapes. I&#39;m not partial to both but it&#39;s interesting to taste each variety on it&#39;s own. It seems the same way with coffee beans - I picked beans with some coffee tones and a mild &#34;rust&#34; to it, and it was a great base for the red velvet powder. Having tried the red velvet latte a few times now, opt for the full fat milk and not the skimmed. It makes a huge difference to the acidity of the drink. I really enjoyed the latte and as mentioned, I&#39;ve had a few times since. I can only drink about half a cup before the caffeine kicks get too much, but my partner gladly finishes the other half (no pun intended). <br><br>Jewel also carries some interesting pastries. There&#39;s a salted caramel something and a gula melaka croissant...both of which were quite good. Though I wish they were fresh and warm without asking. There are some quirky bags for sale as well in the merchandise section that perhaps one day, when I&#39;m high enough on coffee, I will actually buy.<br><br>The last perk about Jewel is that this outlet has great seating space that allows you to talk business without being overheard (some of the other options in the mall have very packed seating). I would request that they put in some arm chairs or more comfortable chairs though. There is also another Jewel Coffee outlet that I shall not name that is fantastic on the weekends for chilling in and watching the world go by. Residents who live nearby are already clued in and I&#39;m not about to give the lobang away, but it has lots of sunlight streaming in, couches/tables/work counters and as mentioned above, the food and beverages aren&#39;t bad at all. <br><br>In other words, I think I have found a coffee chain to my liking. Yours truly, a non-coffee drinker.
