text: This is a great coffee shop from which to work. Lots of space between tables for privacy. It&#39;s a bit more pricey so not mobbed with people.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/k8Q9NIWCIPkWDrnw8-lvtw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/maison-kayser-singapore?reviewid=innqEZFQMkimgwyF7fEppw&select=k8Q9NIWCIPkWDrnw8-lvtw', 'altText': 'Photo of Maison Kayser - Singapore, Singapore. Pain Aux Yuzu - S$3.10 (before 7% GST) ~ my love!', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Pain Aux Yuzu - S$3.10 (before 7% GST) ~ my love!'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/OHoc42qO1idiISOwNuzz2A/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/maison-kayser-singapore?reviewid=innqEZFQMkimgwyF7fEppw&select=OHoc42qO1idiISOwNuzz2A', 'altText': 'Photo of Maison Kayser - Singapore, Singapore. Ananas Coco ie. pineapple &amp; coconut!', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Ananas Coco ie. pineapple & coconut!'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Jt1qb6zeS08aPDXutf3Atg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/maison-kayser-singapore?reviewid=innqEZFQMkimgwyF7fEppw&select=Jt1qb6zeS08aPDXutf3Atg', 'altText': 'Photo of Maison Kayser - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}]
text: Who could resist the aroma of a freshly bake dough coming out from the oven and not getting hold of them? The sight of it was enough to make me hyperventilate, let alone tasting one.<br><br>It as probably 6-months ago since I last had my bun from Maison Kayser at Scotts Square. They have never failed to draw crowds despite the fact that they are anchoring at the basement of a smaller but prestigious mall. Prior to its opening last December, it was one of the most anticipated bakery by many eager Singaporeans. I admitted being one - so sheepish.<br><br>Their butter croissant has always be a big draw. As they baked in batches to allow the bread to taste its best (given the high humidity level in Singapore, the crust gets softened pretty fast), luck plays a big part in determining if I manage to bring one home today. It was far better than striking lottery, to me.<br><br>Today, I am not in my lady luck - I missed the batch of croissants. The fella who has gotten the last piece, must be gloating now. Not feeling worst, I have still have other consolations to pick from.<br><br>Recalling what I had on my last two visits, I chose an array of sweet bread which tasted almost new to me.<br><br>Pain Aux Pommes - The bun had a very faint sweetness arising from the honey. Its shell was undeniably crusty with a chewy dough. It was visibly filled with large apple chunks, stodgy and a tad sour. The walnut adds a good nutty flavor to the rustic bun.<br><br>The Orange - Not sure if I read the tag correctly at the counter, &#34;earl grey with orange peels&#34;. I sniffed none of the earl grey scent but the bread was baked using dark rye flour - nutty and doughy. I have always been attracted to chewy European-styled bread; this was the show stopper among all, which I bagged today. Generous amount of orange peels were seen everywhere, candied but still contained its natural citrus flavor. Marvelous!<br><br>Pain Aux Yuzu - Didn&#39;t know that I had this yuzu bun until I read my previous blog! So this was my second attempt? And it had the same consistency! I adored the crumble yet the center was soft. The sweetness in the dough was prominent but natural. The yuzu peels were seen scattered evenly which gave a good lemony taste. I am still loving it.

A better than average bakery in the basement?  Yes!  Despite the German sounding name, Maison Kayser is from Japan and their products fill a nice niche that is richer than local bakers yet lighter than traditional European bakeries.  After reading the other reviews, I really should have gotten a baguette.  But I was able to try some croissants, eclairs, and cakes so I can definitely comment on those ;).  Their almond croissant was excellent.  Really.  Not sure if I like theirs over Paul&#39;s but in any case, it&#39;s damn good.  I wish I could say the same about the cakes.  Most were ok, but nothing really stood out.  However, their best seller, the lemon tart, is excellent.  Great flavor and a lovely tart altogether.  The yuzu eclair however, was a fail.  Overall, a very nice choice for bakery in an unlikely place.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=q2hwhINsyDgEbocO1_hlZQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/VA2TyetFdD2rM7efiORlZQ/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/VA2TyetFdD2rM7efiORlZQ/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/VA2TyetFdD2rM7efiORlZQ/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/VA2TyetFdD2rM7efiORlZQ/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/VA2TyetFdD2rM7efiORlZQ/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/VA2TyetFdD2rM7efiORlZQ/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Andrew S.', 'displayLocation': 'San Jose, CA', 'altText': 'Andrew S.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=q2hwhINsyDgEbocO1_hlZQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 5, 'photoCount': 10, 'reviewCount': 222, 'eliteYear': None}
text: This is a cute, small French-style bakery/cafe in the basement of the Scotts Square building. A good place for a post-dinner pastry and coffee.

We had lunch here on a Sunday. This is the second time we have been for a Sunday lunch and have not experienced the queues mentioned in other reviews of this place. <br><br>So the good news first. The food is very good. The menu is fairly simple but non the worse for it. Soups have been very tasty with the bread basket with six different kinds of bread. Not sure if the breads with fruit in go so well with soup but they are nonetheless very tasty. The jambon and fromage baguette was very good. Not too much mustard and the cheese and the ham both had good flavour. Apart from running out of Coke while we were there the flavored teas Nd coffee also lived up to expectations. <br><br>Now the not so good. <br>Simply put the service is poor. It is certainly not for the lack of staff with 3 to 4 people serving a relatively small number of tables excluding the staff behind the counter. However no one takes responsibility for set tables with the result that no one is responsible for your food and drinks coming out quickly. Our drinks finally arrived just as the food was finished. The staff need to take responsibility for set tables otherwise nothing will improve. As mentioned accurately in another review. They should change to self service and save on the staff costs. It really is a shame as the food and drink make this a worthy stop.

This place has the best bred I tasted so far in Singapore! Better than most boulangeries in France. I love it. Although because of the weather you tend to lose the crispiness quite quickly.  Advise: put it in the over a few minutes before eating if it stayed out a few hours.<br><br>We had a croque monsieur, mushroom soup and hand and cheese sandwich.<br>Everything was quite good, very simple but good.<br>Ham and cheese may not appeal to the asian crownd as the baguette bred is quite crispy and hard on the outside but it is authentic.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=pa10dSWdk-aRPk8vka57AQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'Rachael K.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Rachael K.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=pa10dSWdk-aRPk8vka57AQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 13, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 2, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Their products are so good when they are fresh. Unfortunately, everything now is made from their factory in Woodlands and transported over to their shop.  Try their stuff in NYC and it will be different.

The best bakery in Singapore hands down. I&#39;ve been waiting for Maison Kayser to enter Singapore ever since I read about it in a manga. <br>Without a doubt, the main attraction is the buttery smooth crossiant that makes just having one only impossible. Snaking queues are a common sight in the day so the best time to go and try it would be in the evening, as I found out when I visited. Service is brisk and the staff are well-informed on the various types of bread on offer and can advice you on just what you require. Pricewise, I was pretty amazed that for such high quality breads, what you&#39;re paying for is downright cheap and inexpensive. They have a small cafe where you can dine in and have coffee as well. Being in the basement does cost the cafe a little bit of the allure of a glamourous bakery, but the bread more than makes up for it.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/sBije1RYUhSoJef-MaUWAA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/maison-kayser-singapore?reviewid=vSdWB2zf0aVc-IiD00bsng&select=sBije1RYUhSoJef-MaUWAA', 'altText': 'Photo of Maison Kayser - Singapore, Singapore. Kayser from the top', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Kayser from the top'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/94Z1vCzS4ccRqBQ_Tba2kg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/maison-kayser-singapore?reviewid=vSdWB2zf0aVc-IiD00bsng&select=94Z1vCzS4ccRqBQ_Tba2kg', 'altText': 'Photo of Maison Kayser - Singapore, Singapore. Ham and cheese baguette', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Ham and cheese baguette'}]
text: For the crusty baguettes alone, I give 5 stars. For baguettes so good, I am happy just munching them on their own. Anything else on it is just a bonus.

I tried the almond croissant but was not impressed, but Mum really likes the orange breads. Definitely prefer the version at Tiong Bahru Bakery. The coffee is alright though not mindblowing.<br><br>This place is always filled with tai tai types, not surprisingly given its location and type of stores. <br><br>Service is friendly and helpful.

All the breads and pastries I&#39;ve had from Maison Kayser have been really satisfying. It&#39;s on the more expensive side as far as bakeries go, but I think it&#39;s worth it. Even though it&#39;s a chain, I&#39;d still say they do one of the best baguettes in Singapore.
It&#39;s all about the chausson au pommes. Croissant was legendary also.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=D6-pwyZgXy8wxFy-NbCWCw', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'Etienne T.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Etienne T.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=D6-pwyZgXy8wxFy-NbCWCw', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 2, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 48, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Best croissants in Singapore. Slightly crispy on the outside and smooth inside. Not as oily-feeling as Tiong Bahru Bakery&#39;s and doesn&#39;t deflate like Paul&#39;s. <br><br>However, I find several of its other breads a bit too hard.
still happy with the baguette, however..they&#39;ve stopped selling ananas coco :(

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=NUK8drx_RDOMjh4WxIBc6Q', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/jXLSk8zyxUCwJdbzHzRKTQ/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/jXLSk8zyxUCwJdbzHzRKTQ/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/jXLSk8zyxUCwJdbzHzRKTQ/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/jXLSk8zyxUCwJdbzHzRKTQ/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/jXLSk8zyxUCwJdbzHzRKTQ/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/jXLSk8zyxUCwJdbzHzRKTQ/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'LT K.', 'displayLocation': 'Los Angeles, CA', 'altText': 'LT K.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=NUK8drx_RDOMjh4WxIBc6Q', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 2, 'photoCount': 2, 'reviewCount': 478, 'eliteYear': None}
text: I should rate JD a three-star, but the gula Melaka pandan cake won me over to give a 4-star. Also the good service.<br><br>The cappuccino is very decent but still not what it should be. What kills a cappuccino is too much milk. I have to ask for less milk, more foam to balance it out.

A good alternative to the generic Starbucks and Coffee Bean at Kallang Leisure Park. They offer decaf for the espresso based drinks. <br><br>Lots of power points for your laptops/phablets. <br><br>No cooked meals offered but lots of sandwich options, e.g. Egg mayo in croissant, or ham and cheese croissant.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/kxXI_p7mStGYSJU1DXrKEg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/93-degreesc-coffee-singapore?reviewid=l6Ny0gBEle_Ntgh8M2dVjQ&select=kxXI_p7mStGYSJU1DXrKEg', 'altText': 'Photo of 93 DegreesC Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: This is definitely a hidden gem. Tucked away at the foot of Mount Faber. A place for friends to hang out with and it is pretty cozy.<br><br>I had a cup of Salted Caramel Latte ($5), it was rich and creamy with a nice cholocatey taste.<br><br>Besides coffee, 93 DegreesC also serves all-day breakfast and cakes.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/-d01x7BhZZo3cS9yxG9HQA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/dutch-colony-coffee-singapore-2?reviewid=YPKI7_W-4CqNISLJH1PDeg&select=-d01x7BhZZo3cS9yxG9HQA', 'altText': 'Photo of Dutch Colony Coffee - Singapore, Singapore. Raisin Scone (served warm), $3.20', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Raisin Scone (served warm), $3.20'}]
text: My goto coffee place. Strong excellent coffee and for a $1 extra they serve it with oat milk. Staff is very friendly and you get your coffee fast, not like other places.<br>There are a couple of tables inside but also an outdoor area with cute little tables and chairs.<br><br>For food they have a couple of bakery items (bagel, scones, pie) and some smaller breakfast plates (granola, avocado toast with eggs).<br><br>I highly recommend checking this place out if you are ever in the area, especially if you are a coffee lover.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/QnXKhUJ0ypxDd3NUMQefTw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/dutch-colony-coffee-singapore-2?reviewid=jwqboY3qzjNDUWxo_Nr9Ow&select=QnXKhUJ0ypxDd3NUMQefTw', 'altText': 'Photo of Dutch Colony Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: The way they prepared my iced latte was unlike anything I&#39;ve had before. They steamed the milk and made it foamy before adding it to the espresso and ice. I really loved it!

Cute coffee shop!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Cute coffee shop!'}]
text: Cute coffee shop! Glad this place is nearby the airbnb we are staying at. It&#39;s not too for from the fort canning MRT station.<br><br>Ordered an iced Americano and didn&#39;t need to add any cream or sugar. The espresso was smooth and was what I needed to help me get over my jet lag. <br><br>The WiFi also works great and there&#39;s plenty of seating inside and out. Will be coming back to get my caffeine fix during my few days in Singapore!

text: One of the better cafes in Singapore. Coming from a coffee snob. Although young, the baristas seem to actually care about the production of each cup.

text: I couldn&#39;t resist to try this coffee    here in singapore U E square! Really recomended to try their cappucino excellent taste and for sure will come back

text: Steady coffee, lack of milk choices. Had the guacamole with a poached egg on toast very nice.

text: This is probably the best coffee in this area, I could smell the coffee every time I pass by, finally I tried one, WOW....then I have to have one every single day! The iced lattes is my favorite, however if the weather is not so hot I prefer to enjoy a large cappuccino, will be stay here for another week, I will definitely miss this place for sure !

text: First time here in Singapore (from Australia) and to Oberstrasse.<br>Great first impression!! Lovely friendly staff.<br>We were greeted the second we stepped into the cafe, were given menus and a table and within the next minute were given table water.<br>I am very fussy with my eggs, and the chef did them PERFECT which rarely happens when asked in Australia. Very very happy!! Our coffees come out within 5 mins which is how it should be!!  as for our meals they were also out quick and fresh and hot. Was very impressed with everything!! Will definately be back here!! And will recommend to others visiting Singapore.<br>Thankyou Oberstrasse!!

text: Oberstrasse is a German term for Upper Street and is commonly used in Germany. The cafe is just a stone throw away from Lavendar MRT Station. It&#39;s quite a popular place for some breakfast and brunch. It was a last minute idea that we came here for a meal, but for a dinner.<br><br>Interior feels cosy under the orange lights. In fact the theme of using transparent containers with the bulbs in them gave the environment a rustic feel altogether with the wooden tables and chair.<br><br>I bet everyone hear about their Rosti and comes here for this! The homemade potato rosti was awesome accompanied by a pretty sunny side up egg, wedge of lemon and a spat of sour cream. The Rosti was pan-fried to crisp at some parts and texture was perfect without being too burnt. If I were to compare Rosti from Marche, both as are tasty, just that the differences is that Oberstrasee Rosti are more of wider and shorter while Marche&#39;s were machined cut thus the size of it is uniform.<br><br>Sunny Rosti - $11<br><br>Sandwichies are served in freshly baked Ciabatta with Smoked Cheddar, Coral lettuces, Tomatoes and Onions. It consist of Norwegian smoked salmon, Avocado spread, horseradish dill sauce and alfalfa sprouts.<br><br>Smokled Salmon &amp; Avocado - $12<br><br>I had the Duck Confit as my main course that come with 2 sides and I had the homemade slaw as well as the House Salad. The color combination of this course looked pleasing to the eyes with purple slaw and Salad drenched with roasted sesame dressing. On the other hand the Duck Confit was deep fried, though it was a tad on the dry side, it was well complimented by the Lingonberry Sauce that elevated the dining experience of the dish.<br><br>Duck Config with Lingonberry Sauce - $18<br><br>It was quite quiet during the night and perhaps many would come for their brunch or breakfast. Service was friendly and prompt. The only down side I would have think of is perhaps the smell on the clothing after dining. I don&#39;t mind returning for sausage and rosti.

text: Atmosphere: <br>* Quiet<br>* Good for working<br>* Seats aren&#39;t comfortable so I won&#39;t think it&#39;s a place to chill with a book <br>* Soft background music<br><br>Location:<br>* Closest station is Lavender<br><br>Price: <br>* Reasonable - average of $5 for a cup of coffee<br><br>Service:<br>* I wouldn&#39;t say they were unfriendly neither would I say they were friendly - they were kind of the &#34;in between&#34;... Don&#39;t know if that made sense<br>* Fast service<br><br>Variety:<br>* They have muffins, pastries, pasta and all day breakfast. Drink variety is alright - wished they had Chai Latte though!!<br><br>My order:<br>Green Tea Latte ($5.50) - it was alright; got a bit bitter towards the bottom<br>French toast with berries ($6.50) - wish they were more fruits<br><br>Others:<br>A little more $$ could be put into cosying this place up a bit more i.e. More comfy chairs!! Other than that, you pay for what you get!

Coffee', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Coffee'}]
text: Cute coffee shop serving breakfast and lunch. Stopped in today for brunch and ordered a Soy Latte and Eggs Hollandaise. Coffee was perfect. Blend was delicious, loved the latte art (which they can&#39;t do with soy in Australia ha) and it was smooth and went down very easily. <br><br>Eggs Bene was nice. Nothing too exciting. Eggs were well poached but the serving of salmon was a little on the stingy side. <br><br>Interiors are very cool and industrial. If I lived here I&#39;d come back!

While on vacation in Singapore we came across this great coffee shop. We enjoyed wonderful iced lattes while taking advantage of the free Wi-Fi to plan our next stop. The employees were very nice and the cafe was clean and well-decorated.

text: Doi Chaang had me at &#34;Akha&#34; &#34;fair trade&#34; and &#34;organic&#34;. Yes, I am a sucker for such things, and they work directly with particular community in Thailand, which makes it more personal.<br><br>Confession- I&#39;m not a coffee aficionado, and how I decide if it is good coffee is when I don&#39;t get stale coffee breath after. (eeps! I sense judgement.) Anyhoo, the reason why I&#39;m giving this place 4 stars is the ambience. <br><br>That particular stretch at Rochester Mall is very pleasantly windy. Literally there is some good Feng Shui there. Which means alfresco is actually much nicer than sitting inside! :O (just keeping it real...asian here) Secondly, the decor and furniture aren&#39;t too pretentious, and the staff aren&#39;t good-looking hipsters. So unpretentious that they started playing EDM (oh man, what happened to cafe music!), but I suspect it was the jam of the middle-age barista, so hey, I ain&#39;t raining on no parade. <br><br>Food- I&#39;ve only tried the crepe cake (earl grey specifically), it&#39;s nice, but a bit too milky for my taste (maybe because I am getting more conscious of my growing lactose intolerance... sorry TMI). <br><br>It&#39;s not too popular so is a nice place to read/work/chill.<br><br>Tip- the tables are a bit low for laptop work (do it at the counter, but you might be too distracted people watching).

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/8vje6jVace9nLILWR7eF_Q/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/doi-chaang-singapore?reviewid=6YxaqsKKq0tjY8Ivfqj0cA&select=8vje6jVace9nLILWR7eF_Q', 'altText': 'Photo of Doi Chaang - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/RJAn106ZMwhuoEFueucSOg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/doi-chaang-singapore?reviewid=6YxaqsKKq0tjY8Ivfqj0cA&select=RJAn106ZMwhuoEFueucSOg', 'altText': 'Photo of Doi Chaang - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/4dV-g59xcrBDi7yKyUzd3g/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/doi-chaang-singapore?reviewid=6YxaqsKKq0tjY8Ivfqj0cA&select=4dV-g59xcrBDi7yKyUzd3g', 'altText': 'Photo of Doi Chaang - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/5FqzCxkGoodQ06tWihIPzg/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/doi-chaang-singapore?reviewid=6YxaqsKKq0tjY8Ivfqj0cA&select=5FqzCxkGoodQ06tWihIPzg', 'altText': 'Photo of Doi Chaang - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}]
text: Located in Rochester Mall which is half a hotel and half shops/residential, is Doi Chaang Coffee! I had been meaning to try out their crepe cakes for awhile,  but it&#39;s on the other side of the country for me!<br><br>At 8pm or so, we popped by and alot of their drinks were sold out and they only had 1-2 slices of crepe cakes left! Being the all greedy, I decided to try one of each flavour!<br>For big groups of 7 or more, you will have sit outside, as their indoor air-conditioned seating is meant for groups or 2 to 4.<br><br>So after ordering all 7 crepe cakes, the staff had to get creative with designing all 7 plates with chocolate syrups. Each plate had a different design and they were all so cute! I have ordered the cakes in the order that I like the most! All their crepes tasted fresh with the same consitent texture, look and feel for all 7 flavours.<br><br>1. Earl Grey $6.90 <br>This is by far the best crepe cake I have ever eaten. The earl grey flavour was just right! It wasn&#39;t too sweet and you could distinctively taste earl grey. <br><br>2. Matcha &amp; Azuki $6.90<br>I am a Matcha lover and this is so much better than the infamous Lady M green tea crepe cakes, and there&#39;s even azuki beans in this crepe cake. Definitely getting this again in the future!<br><br>3. Hokkaido Milk $6.90<br>A very milky, creamy tasting crepe cake, an interesting flavour that I really liked! It wasn&#39;t too sweet, and yet, you could still taste the milk!<br><br>4. French Vanilla $6.90<br>A bit similar to the Hokkaido Milk, but less milky and more creamy.<br><br>5. Raspberry Yogurt $6.90<br>I guess because of the raspberry jam on top, this crepe cake ended up tasting the sweetest, too sweet for my liking. Additionally, you could taste the yogurt flavour in between in layer! <br><br>6. Chocooffee Praline $6.90<br>The powder on top, was an overkill and I couldn&#39;t taste much in this crepe cake, we actually couldn&#39;t tell the difference between this and the Tiramisu crepe cake.<br><br>7. Tiramisu $6.90<br>Tasted like any normal tiramisu crepe cake, nothing special.<br><br>Melon Milk $4.90<br>I really liked this cup of melon milk, it was very refreshing and sweet, but as the ice melted, it tasted really diluted, either that, or the the sweetness overdose from the raspberry yogurt killed my taste buds.<br><br>All in all, a great place to chill out in the buona vista area. Grab a cup of iced drink and a crepe cake to complete your day!

text: The marketing game here is on point. Beautiful inviting storefront with bright colors. That&#39;s pretty much how they got me to stop inside. I was walking and on my way to the Chinatown MRT and I stumbled upon this cute coffee shop. <br><br>All the desserts and drinks are creatively titled like the Clouds in my Coffee, a super creamy cold brew that is mildly sweet. Delicious! I even ordered a side of macarons as a sweet snack just to balance the coffee, but honestly, it wasn&#39;t necessary. The cold brew has a nice aftertaste without being overly bitter. <br><br>The staff was super nice and friendly as well! Definitely a great find here in the Chinatown area of Singapore.

text: Updating to five stars. Truly a one of a kind place in Singapore. Their flavors are in point. Excellent cocktail menu to boot. Great ambience as well with all three floors having a distinct vibe. Get the goat curry and any dish which comes with the curried avocado. You won&#39;t be disappointed.

text: Elegant décor (especially the upper floors). Nice African ambient music. Friendly service from a waitress with a brand new iPhone 11 Pro Max. We were the only guests for lunch on a weekday, yet the food took 30 minutes to come out. It is good, but portions are small, for the price (around $30++). Mobutu&#39;s heirs can afford to come to Utu, but not Mobutu&#39;s mob.
Wonderful breakfast experience! Loved the chicken peanut curry and the speciality coffees. Staff was attentive and polite. Will definite be back again to check out their dinner scene.

text: This is an absolutely fantastic place to go for breakfast. Their coffee is amazing, so be sure to order some of their specialty ones. I don&#39;t remember the name of it, but one had salted peanut butter on the rim of the cup and was really good. All of their breakfast items were excellent. Even if you just go for a coffee, be sure to order the little coconut donuts to go with. It&#39;s an easy walk from the main street in Chinatown called Tajong Pagar. Plus, the AC is nice and frosty  :)

text: Came here as a pit stop in between lunch and dinner to meet with some old friends. First impression? Calm and easy. Had such good conversations. Left with a nice #Iwillbeback feel. Oh btw did I mention the coffee was very good?

text: Came to this quaint little cafe ona whim, when my group was walking past. We were looking for a pitstop for a quick drink and a little rest, and this is everything we could have asked for!<br><br>We were greeted and served by the owner, and she radiated a warm and welcoming feel. The vibes of this cafe are cozy and laid back, with a quiet buzz of conversation and some people being productive. The drinks were fantastic and fairly priced too!<br><br>Overall, this spot was everything I was looking for when visiting a cafe and I&#39;ll definitely be back if I&#39;m in the area!

text: *Coffee Snob Intro*<br>When you&#39;re let go from a company the locations you frequent many many coffee shops.<br><br>These wonderful roasteries provide the perfect balance of professional attitude, casual attire, and passionate delivery to aid you in your job search.<br><br>I&#39;m going to rate a bunch of coffee shops based on this metric and a few others and provide an overall rating for the experience.<br><br>----------------------------------<br>OVERALL: 4 stars<br><br>Ambience: 4<br>Coffee: 4<br>Food: N/A (didn&#39;t try)<br>Meeting Place: 4<br>Working Space: 4<br>----------------------------------<br><br>*Coffee Review*<br><br>Carry On is a quaint little coffee shop in Tanjong Katong, that is frequented quite heavily on weekdays by freelancers, mums/dads/kids/helpers.<br><br>I came here recently looking to do some work and found it a really pleasant space to tackle the daily tasks. They have some pop tunes playing throughout, and a nice long table that suits the laptop loiterers.<br><br>for those looking to relax they have a selection of books (remember these?) for a flip-n-sip session, whilst also carrying through with their naming theme by selling backpacks ... see what I did there?<br><br>Overall a really chill experience, suitable for work or play. Can definitely recommend, and will be back for both.

Nice and quiet coffee bar that serves good wraps, croissants and some cakes. Relaxed atmosphere with an interesting DIY feeling interior. Young audience. The name comes - I suppose - from the bags and backpacks they sell.

text: This is an amazing spot. If you&#39;re visiting Singapore, make a trip here-- no matter what part of the city you&#39;re staying in. The owner and mastermind showcases the best flavors of Singapore and does so with ingenuity and care. Try: chili crab pasta, rice pattie chicken satay burger, durian cheesecake (!!!) and much, much more. Mmmmmm.

Avocado toast one slice baby', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Avocado toast one slice baby'}]
text: Lovely space in Chinatown. Surprised Singaporeans don&#39;t utilize Yelp, since us Americans worship the app. So happy to be the 2nd reviewer of this place. <br><br>Happy to say - it&#39;s worth the hype. Currently in this roomy, but cozy well lit cafe, and there are many coffee goers situated here, each working on a laptop or reading a book nestled in the corner. There&#39;s a nice area of the shop where they sell products made by individuals who have high barrier to employment; they&#39;re creative products, jewelry, candles, bags, socks, etc. Beautiful products, but a bit overpriced. <br><br>There&#39;s also another area where they sell no-waste items, so you can refill product like soap, shampoo, etc. What a genius idea. I love that they have created this space to work and teach their customers new ideas in the space without us knowing it. <br><br>Would highly recommend this place for a cup of coffee. Strong wifi and a few outlets here and there.

text: This is such a cute space, I was torn between keeping it a secret or sharing it for fear it will get crowded over time . But good food must share :) just opened for 3 months as of July 2018, the sourdough open face toasts are simple yet so tasty but so clean after you eat it. I love the banana peanut butter with honey and coconut and the avocado egg toast! Coffee was great, service was incredible and did I mention the smoothie bowls also taste amazing. Nice ambience and chill crowd tucked away on a quiet street. I&#39;ll come back for more :) love this place<br><br>Ps: There is also a little space selling socially sustainable/ responsible crafts and a nail place tucked in the corner.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=mGKjX2fzkTIVv9DwFZ0bww', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'John D.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'John D.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=mGKjX2fzkTIVv9DwFZ0bww', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 13, 'photoCount': 4, 'reviewCount': 18, 'eliteYear': None}
text: 100% based on friendly accomodating staff.  Decent breakfast.  Great ambience.  Good location.  OK, admittedly, I am severely biased in their favour.  The last 8 times I have been there it was to watch football games on widescreen TVs.  This is a cozy sports bar with multiple screens to watch several live games.  They allow groups to reserved tables and watch games and tolerate the cheers and noise.  Went to an upstairs wine tasting there years ago that was quite good.  Also have done a few upstairs lunches.  Decent fare, good price.  When it&#39;s left turn to Molly&#39;s or right turn to Boomarang, there is no hesitation.  Right is the right way to go for food and drink.
Good location for brunch or for a relaxed dinner. It&#39;s also perfect for watching sports games but probably need to book a table in advance.
This is an interesting place with interesting food and coffee options. Defin recommended! Great service

Meat and eggs breakfast place with good coffee. It&#39;s rare to find hearty breakfast places like this, so I&#39;m sad I&#39;ll never go back. They just too often forget my order and let me sit there like a fool waiting for food that never arrives. Today I asked for a refund. Was told the owners don&#39;t empower the staff to do that. If you can&#39;t make a customer happy, you lose the customer.

text: Really nice place to hang out with a group of friends over a cuppa coffee. They serve a wide range of drinks with both a breakfast and a lunch/dinner menu. <br><br>I had the chai latte and my mum had her latte. Both were equally fabulous. My chai had some really nice foam on the top which I seriously loved. <br><br>Sadly, we didn&#39;t order any food but their breakfast menu looked and sounded delicious. (I uploaded a picture of their brekky menu)<br><br>Definitely recommend this place.

text: Situated at the corner with quick friendly service and a good choice of breakfasts. The Sportsbar is rather quiet in the morning but you could stil watch sports for breakfast. My fresh pressed juice came quick as well as the scrambled eggs and toast. All fresh and delicious!

Nice place to get breakfast and watch American baseball, or even NFL football. They always also have a rugby game going.  All of the usual suspects are offered for breakfast, mostly served with grilled tomato or baked beans, a very English/Australian breakfast.  They do serve a Texas size toast for those that like alot of bread in the AM. <br><br>Be careful of ordering a alcoholic beverage for breakfast as its pricey. Stick with a coffee or orange juice without the kick.<br><br>This is the only place in Boat Quay that is open for breakfast, not as glamerous as brunch at The Fullerton, but still a sold choice if you are looking to eat breakfast in the area.

Meat and eggs breakfast place with good coffee. It&#39;s rare to find hearty breakfast places like this, so I&#39;m sad I&#39;ll never go back. They just too often forget my order and let me sit there like a fool waiting for food that never arrives. Today I asked for a refund. Was told the owners don&#39;t empower the staff to do that. If you can&#39;t make a customer happy, you lose the customer.
Below average food and expensive, but nice ambiance to hang out watch sports and watch the expat crowd. <br>Not a destination, more of a compromise.
This is an interesting place with interesting food and coffee options. Defin recommended! Great service
Good location for brunch or for a relaxed dinner. It&#39;s also perfect for watching sports games but probably need to book a table in advance.

text: We came here for breakfast. Great selection. I had the granola muesli which was really tasty and the fruit was fresh. My husband had the chicken, cheese and avo wrap which was also delicious. I ordered an iced chai which was by far one of the best iced chais I&#39;ve had... And I&#39;ve had a lot! The service was super friendly and fast, which isn&#39;t always the case in Singapore. We&#39;d definitely come back!

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=mGKjX2fzkTIVv9DwFZ0bww', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'John D.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'John D.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=mGKjX2fzkTIVv9DwFZ0bww', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 13, 'photoCount': 4, 'reviewCount': 18, 'eliteYear': None}
text: 100% based on friendly accomodating staff.  Decent breakfast.  Great ambience.  Good location.  OK, admittedly, I am severely biased in their favour.  The last 8 times I have been there it was to watch football games on widescreen TVs.  This is a cozy sports bar with multiple screens to watch several live games.  They allow groups to reserved tables and watch games and tolerate the cheers and noise.  Went to an upstairs wine tasting there years ago that was quite good.  Also have done a few upstairs lunches.  Decent fare, good price.  When it&#39;s left turn to Molly&#39;s or right turn to Boomarang, there is no hesitation.  Right is the right way to go for food and drink.

text: Kampong Glam is a lonely place in the morning. If one&#39;s walking in from the bustle of Bugis, crossing Ophir Road may feel like reaching a different dimension where time behaves oddly. Kampong Glam is apparently asleep and every single business appears to be closed. Don&#39;t get me wrong, there is people on the street, but most are just passing (or sleepwalking, one never knows). A few people are cleaning the establishments, but it is not known if they&#39;re about to open or if they&#39;re just closing from the night before.<br><br>In this strange dimension, All In is easy to recognise: it is the only place that&#39;s open. Not only it is open, it&#39;s alive with the aroma of freshly ground coffee. It is a tiny corner, almost a hole in the wall, but size is definitely not important when it comes to coffee. There is a fairly good array of brews, including cold brewed coffee in those charming glass flasks so ubiquitous these days. They also serve fresh juices, ice cream and some solid snacks. The staff are very friendly which is always welcome, more in the environment of Kampong Glam in the morning.<br><br>There is maybe a table or two, I can&#39;t recall. All In is not a place to linger. Instead, it is like a short rest stop where one can get caffeine, sugar, and a good bit of joy before heading into the doom and gloom of Kampong Glam before noon.

text: This hole-in-the-wall coffee shop also has smoothies, ice cream, pastries, quiche, sandwiches, and bottled drinks. It is very clean and modern. You can see the preparation area. The staff are friendly and welcoming. It is just hip enough not to be cloying, which is a victory in this cafe district. I recommend it highly. Especially appreciate it&#39;s being open when everything else is closed in the morning, which is helpful for those dealing with jet-lag.
Great service along with quality coffee and better than Starbucks is why it&#39;s worth a visit! Thank you Oromo!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Kz9ntQmE2FSH15dJ_eqZMQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/oromo-coffee-singapore?reviewid=qNqMnVrSqSz_d73Rq6ZH4Q&select=Kz9ntQmE2FSH15dJ_eqZMQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Oromo Coffee - Singapore, Singapore. Very nice flat white', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Very nice flat white'}]
text: Not sure what to make of this place. Walked in and was immediately caught of guard by the large group of high school students all behaving, well like high school students. It was a raucous atmosphere and I was seriously having second thoughts about planting myself down for a cup of coffee. I don&#39;t mind customers having a good time but it the decibel level off the scale for a coffee shop. The reason for the lively atmosphere is due primarily to the Subway Sandwich shop that shares the retail space. So on one side, there&#39;s a Subways and on the other is Oromo Coffee. Fortunately, I wasn&#39;t there to read a book, do some work or sneaking in a nap. Saving grace is the nice, quality coffee Oromo serves and the pleasant service.

text: Disappointing. This isn&#39;t a standalone cafe; it shares space with a Subway chain and has no wifi nor working power outlets of its own. Noisy and awkward. Wifi slow. Nice little sesame cookies, though.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/FMK3ebEqcUF_qZAl-gUajg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/fabcafe-singapore?reviewid=LK82kHvt8YYPXmaQXYMsEQ&select=FMK3ebEqcUF_qZAl-gUajg', 'altText': 'Photo of FabCafe - Singapore, Singapore. The shockingly amazing coffee art.', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'The shockingly amazing coffee art.'}]
text: The location is superb, and you can actually get something 3D printed or get your phone or phone engraved with a laser cutter, for a reasonable price. The service is quick, and the coffee art is FLIPPING PICASSO WORTHY STUFF!! The flat white could be creamier, and less froth and more coffee, but apart from that, it was superb. There is also a gift shop. The atmosphere was quiet and cool, and the tall 3D Printer looks perfect on the stand. The café is connected to the Art &amp; Science Museum ad well, which is awesome. I would definitely come here again, totally recommend it!!!

Maple sea salt cheesecake, earl grey lavender latte", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Maple sea salt cheesecake, earl grey lavender latte'}]
text: Every time I&#39;m back i try to stop by D&#39;Good Cafe for my favorite early grey lavender latte. Also got to try their maple sea salt cheesecake which is their signature cake. The cheesecake was alright, tasty though denser than I was expecting. Service was slow (~15 minutes) even there were only 3 tables occupied and the other 2 had already gotten their orders. The cafe is in a small-ish space with cute decor. The top floor has been converted into a cocktail bar of sorts. All in all, still a great spot to come chill and have a beverage.

text: Ordered the pancake Apple crumble. It is sweet and tasty. Cost $12. Filled with Apple crumble. I really like it a lot. The texture of the pancake is soft too. Yummy ! My friend ordered housemade English breakfast. Cost $16.50<br>It looks yummy and smells good too. She ordered the Cold Brew and I ordered the Chamomile tea. Total bill cost $44.95 with gst. This cafe have a outdoor seating on the 3rd floor. 2nd floor have a two seat designed as a swing facing the window. But the spaces are limited. The ambience is nice. Thumbs up!
Maple sea salt cheesecake ($9) - 2.5 stars<br>Too creamy and not cake-y enough for my liking. It also tasted burnt. I was disappointed.

Seafood agio olio with signature chocolate", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Seafood agio olio with signature chocolate'}]
text: Cozy environment, good for chilling out with loves or friends. Place is not too big, if come in big group better be ready. Not sure if reservation is available. <br><br>There is both indoor (a/c) and outdoor (limited area) seatings. Nicely done up place. The cafe can be accessed from both the front and back alley. <br><br>Tried their seafood agio olio, comes with 6 prawns and average portion for reasonable price as compared to other restaurants. Self service, thus no service charge!<br><br>Cheers!

Love the atmosphere and food in this cafe. I tried the Green Tea Lava Cake and a kiwi fruit juice, both of which were good. I will admit that the lava cake was a bit sweeter than I hoped though. <br><br>Cute seating on swinging benches by the window. Seats can get limited during peak hours so watch out!

Wait time, 40min. Lemongrass chicken.", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Wait time, 40min. Lemongrass chicken.'}]
text: Young, hipster land, lots of chatter, noise, whimsical decor. A place for coffee and dessert. Go on a date. Instagram your food pics with ample light on the 3fl (Alfresco seating available in addition to inside) Third floor tends to get the high decibels, bordering on canteen levels, while the second is more hushed. Brunch maybe, but keep expectations low and order the same as your partner. As I type this, my bangers and mash has been consumed, and my better half&#39;s lemon grass chicken is 37 min after ordering and still not here! <br><br>In the end, it took 40min to be plated. The kitchen is tiny. Stick with the easy to prepare dishes. Stick with the coffee which is decent. They are passionate about their beans. Mains are meh. Lastly, the price points are on the higher side. In sum, I wouldn&#39;t go out of my way. 2.5 Just average.

text: Coffee is too good!!! <br>Another outlet opening in September at Takashimaya! <br>Must be back to try their food and pancakes.

text: I&#39;ve been to other breakfast cafes like Wild honey, common man, and W39, and I&#39;ve found a new favourite in d&#39;good. I came across it on Yelp, so I thought I&#39;d give it a try as I&#39;m always looking for new places to get quality coffee and good food. <br>From the outside it has a hipster grungy feel as it is hidden away down a side street. On the inside it is very trendy, and with 3 rooms to choose from to eat in, it caters for a range of people. It also has a roof top bar if you don&#39;t mind the heat. <br>The coffee is really good! <br>The food is great and affordable. I had the egg upon egg, which filled me up (and I&#39;m a big eater).<br>The service was exceptional. All the staff were very welcoming, friendly and helpful.

text: Nice cafe to chill on the weekends but seats can get extremely limited especially during peak hours! <br><br>The matcha frap is a really great drink but is slightly more pricer than the one found at starbucks!<br><br>To improve on: they really need a better queue system, new customers are not aware that you need to queue and the staff have to chase the new customers away from reserved tables, AWKWARD!

text: Cosy setting with pretty interior deco :-)<br>Food was served promptly after orders and staff were polite &amp; friendly! <br><br>Food and desserts were pretty average but it&#39;s a good place to catch up friends especially if it&#39;s a large bunch outdoors on the 3rd level! Overall it was a good experience :)<br><br>(My friend and I shared the Portobello Mushroom Eggs Benedict and both of us had the runs after, don&#39;t know whether it&#39;s coincidence but perhaps remind the staff to cook the dish a little more if you&#39;re scared!)<br><br>Do note that D&#39;Good Cafe is located on the 2nd and 3rd storeys.

Aglio Olio with prawns", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Aglio Olio with prawns'}]
text: An excellent cafe in terms of food quality and decor! My friends and I went for early lunch on a weekday and got to sit on the lovely swing on the second floor. The table can spin so be careful when you put stuff down. It is self service which is fine as you pay the price stated on the menu. The set meal was a pretty good deal. They pay attention to small details like giving a soup bowl with a handle on the side. The aglio olio with prawns tasted as good as it looked. My aglio olio with real crabmeat was also satisfying although my friend found the flavour too strong. The tomato-based pasta with soup was rather small in portion compared to the other dishes. I was too full for dessert but my friends enjoyed the pancake with sweet potato, matcha syrup and vanilla ice cream.

text: Cute cosy cafe with yummy drinks. Affordable too!<br><br>Came across this as we were randomly walking around Holland V. It&#39;s been awhile since I visited this area. Many cafes and restaurants come and go, and we were excited to try something new.<br><br>D&#39; Good Cafe caught our attention when we realize we could enter by the &#34;back door&#34;. Climbed up the stairs and it felt like we entered another world all together. The lighting done right, adorable decor all around. Suits the hipsters and young students.<br><br>We were told to pick up the menu and find a seat. It&#39;s a self service place where you place your order, make your payment and will be issued a pager to pick up your food when it&#39;s ready. <br><br>We ordered a tea time meal which comes with an orange juice (there are other options) and a waffle. Initially I was expecting a full waffle unfortunate it turned it to be half a waffle. Urgh. Who got the other half! <br><br>Anyway, i ordered a green tea matcha frappe thingy. It was absolutely delicious. It&#39;s been awhile since I drank a decent cup of green tea frappe. <br><br>The price is fairly affordable and hence the throngs of students. The upper floor was really pretty however was super turned off when I saw the whole area filled with students on their laptop and notes. Almost felt like a classroom or tuition centre. We were on the 2nd floor which didn&#39;t have any students mugging but still had dating students cuddling on swings and cozy seats. <br><br>Overall, a nice stopover for an affordable and delicious tea break. Strong air conditioning is definitely a plus too.

Lovely decorations sprinkled around.", 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Lovely decorations sprinkled around.'}]
text: I&#39;m one of those weird folks who doesn&#39;t drink coffee at all, yet love visiting cafes and bistros, especially the indie ones that are popping up around town faster than I can ever keep up.<br><br>I&#39;ve read about D&#39;Good Cafe and have been curious and eager to try it out, glad to finally get the chance to do so on a Saturday afternoon after running some errands at Holland Village. Located on the the 2nd and 3rd floors amidst a bustling stretch of banks and F&amp;B establishments, one would most certainly miss this if you weren&#39;t specifically looking for it. Look for The Body Shop, and then make your way up that narrow stairway next to it.<br><br>Once you enter, it&#39;s a whole different world up there! The ordering counter is on Level 2, so place your orders here, then look for a table either on the other side of Level 2 (grab the lovely swing seats with a view if you&#39;re lucky enough); or head up to Level 3 attic for more seats, incl. a tiny outdoor patio (seats under a tent) if it&#39;s not too warm. And who would have guessed that they even have a little lift (yes elevator!) right inside the unit? You got to try it just for the fun of it, it&#39;s operated via a &#34;press and hold&#34; button inside the lift, maximum capacity of 4 :)<br><br>We were here only for drinks - Mocha was good, Long Black was strong (a tad sour), reasonably priced between S$5 - 6 each. Don&#39;t make the same mistake I did though, I didn&#39;t check the price and ordered a simple &#34;Brewed Tea&#34; (since I don&#39;t take coffee), which turned out to be a TWG teabag in a small pot of hot water, no milk or cream provided... and that came up to S$7!! How on earth did my plain teabag cost more than the coffee, I just couldn&#39;t figure it out. But ouch!<br><br>Service was bleh, the guy who took our order was sulky and not the least welcoming, fortunately the thoughtful cute decorations and detailed aesthetics sprinkled all around made up for that lack of service. All in all, a cute little hidden treasure, just save yourself some bucks, don&#39;t order the brewed tea.
Overall an &#34;OK&#34; experience. We had several brunch / lunch items: salmon, toast, etc. and everything was standard - not particularly good or bad. Space is a bit cramped.

Portobello pasta", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Portobello pasta'}]
text: Spotted this cafe while walking around holland village area in search of food for dinner. From the outside it looks like a plain building. Need to climb a flight of stairs to get to the counter where you will be ordering your foods and drinks. Seating area there is one on second floor and one on the third floor. There is a lift that brings you up and down in case you do not want your serving trays to spill over while climbing on the steps.<br><br>Seating area is rather small for a cafe but have to admit that the second floor interior design was good. It has the outdoors components inside. Third floor is just more like office hang out interior design. <br><br>There are a number of staffs working but you need to self serve but they will clear your plate away. Food wise, I had a portebello pasta (mushroom pasta) in cream sauce. Price wise it&#39;s a bit on the higher end. I&#39;m a little disappointed with the pasta as the sauce is dry and there is not much taste to it. My friend who had bacon carbonara commented the same.<br><br>I am not sure how the coffee tasted here as I cannot drink coffee. There are a few selection of TWG teas in packets and Arizona teas in the bottle. <br><br>Overall it is a nice concept for a cafe and it is good environment to hang out with friends. Next time round I will order their bake goods instead.

An aromatic cup of mocha", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'An aromatic cup of mocha'}]
text: Purely based on quality of food and drinks, 3.5 at most, but additional 0.5 stars for the free wifi. This cafe is quietly tucked away on the second and third levels of one of the shophouses in holland village. I came here on a weekday afternoon and easily got a seat. I love how this cafe offers free wifi. It&#39;s getting harder to find cafés with free wifi in Singapore to prevent customers from staying excessively long but I that similarly deters me from visiting them! <br><br>My order was taken by a pleasant and good-natured barista who recommended the tea time set. This is basically a drink (lattes etc) and a slice of one of the featured cakes for a price of $6.50. My mocha alone would have cost $5.80. This cafe serves up a decent cup of mocha. It was aromatic and flavorful, and the chocolate was not overwhelming. The Oreo cheesecake on the other hand was a disappointment. While the tea set does come across as a good deal, I would pass on the dessert the next time round.

text: Espresso - a small volume of potent coffee, partially covered with a medium brown crema. There were some citrus notes, but they were secondary to the intense bitterness which followed in the aftertaste, and which lingered long after the shot had been finished. The bitterness is dominant in this shot, with some harsh elements present also. This may not be an issue for pour over coffees, or americanos, where the end product is diluted with hot water, however an espresso shot is more concentrated, which can exacerbate harsh notes. There are a number of different types of coffee beans available however, and D&#39;Good offers customers the option of choosing their own preferred type. It may be advisable to highlight this more prominently at the ordering counter though - it is certainly a selling point that not all cafe&#39;s in the area offer. <br><br>Cappuccino - there are some large bubbles present in the foam, but not in sufficient quantities to affect the texture. The latte art is nicely executed also. The mouthfeel is dominated by the texture and taste of warm milk, rather than the hybrid of milk and microfoam that can work in conjunction to form a smooth hybrid of taste and texture. The flavour of the underlying espresso shot is somewhat diluted by the milk, but the bitter aftertaste is still discernible. This may be entirely subjective, but the intense citrusy bitterness described above may work better with pour over coffee, rather than with milk based drinks. However, as there are a number of bean varieties available, and the ability to customise drinks, this can quite easily be fixed, and may not even be an issue from week to week.<br><br>Staff are friendly and accomodating to requests, noticing when customers are looking for sugar or water, and stepping in to help. Also, thought and effort has clearly gone into the decor and layout, with an intelligent use of space allowing for lots of seating space, as well as a very pleasant al fresco area on the upper level. Busy periods can cause delays however (just as they would in any cafe), with a delay in used cups and plates being cleared, and tables being cleaned. Staff seem clustered in the kitchen and ordering counter area instead, but it should be noted that they did collect plates from the upper level before the end of my visit. Increasing the frequency of staff checks on the upper level may help.<br><br>The ordering counter can become crowded, and as a result customers collect drinks after they have been prepared. This may be to keep the ordering counter clear, but one minor issue is that drinks can be slightly less warm when the are collected. This is a minor issue though, keeping the ordering counter and roasting space clear is a good reason for doing so. <br><br>At $14.50 for a single espresso and 2 cappuccinos, the prices are about right. There is also a selection of cakes and baked items available, as well as syphon and pour over coffee.<br><br>Overall, this is not a bad cafe by any means, with some admirable traits - a good selection of beans and brewing methods, and a micro roastery - everything I look for in a quality cafe, and I genuinely want D&#39;Good to succeed. With some minor changes to the beans used for different drinks, and to the frequency of checks on the upper levels, this could be a very good cafe in a great location.

text: The cafe has a warm and cozy atmosphere on the second floor.  It&#39;s third floor is dedicated for people studying and planning on squatting for a while. The cutest part is a swing where you can enjoy your coffee/food while looking out on the street. The coffee is typical &#34;cafe coffee&#34; but the food is pretty good. <br><br>Even though it doesn&#39;t leave the deepest impression, I find myself frequenting it often because it&#39;s reliable, cozy, and right next to the Holland V mrt.<br><br>It&#39;s often busy so make sure you check to see if there are seats that you like before ordering your coffee/food.

Just swing away", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Just swing away'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/59DlrEfkPKxr49HHiZrtQA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/d-good-cafe-singapore?reviewid=z6BonZVVRM6e97M0Cv3aig&select=59DlrEfkPKxr49HHiZrtQA', 'altText': "Photo of d'Good Cafe - Singapore, Singapore. Best maple sea salt cheesecake", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Best maple sea salt cheesecake'}]
text: D&#39;Good Cafe is a whimsical spot to swing your worries away, right smack in the heart of Holland Village. It sits in a funky shop house unit that has 2 entrances and the layout reminded me of that children story about a house in a boot with many children (uh huh i really don&#39;t have much of a childhood).<br><br>D&#39;Good Cafe specializes in single-origin coffee beans, which are roasted in-house. The owner is some crazy coffee fanatic and you can get your Ethiopian, Guatemalan, Jamaican beans done the siphon, drip, pour-over or espresso way. You wouldn&#39;t be able to miss the Elektra espresso machine at the counter! If you&#39;re up for something more exotic, there&#39;s the famous Kopi Luwak (civet coffee) from the Wahana Estate in Sumatra for $38 a pop. You can also make your own blend here at D&#39;Good Cafe too.<br><br>Here&#39;s what we had. The Prawn Aglio Olio ($16) was a little on the dry side, especially after it cooled a little (it became clumpy). I thought it could use a little more salt but it&#39;s certainly quite well flavored. The prawns were nicely done and crunchy.<br><br>I liked the Bacon Carbonara ($15) more than the previous pasta. It&#39;s creamy (more on the milky side) and certainly more satisfying (only if you like cream). Generous portions of bacon too. It would be perfect with some fried bacon bit and an egg.<br><br>The Eggs Benedict ($13.50) was a sad sad portion. I was terribly disappointed by it in fact. The brioche was nice but was too thinly sliced. As a result, it was soaked through by the eggs. Too much vinegar was used in poaching the eggs and that contributed to the papery texture of the whites and that acidic taste. Holladaise sauce was weak too. Certainly not something i&#39;d recommend ordering. Add on $3 to the breakfast sets for a Latte that is well balanced with a nice crema. <br><br>I must say we were all happy with our choice of caffeine. The Earl Grey Lavender Latte ($7) was aromatic without being overpowering. I&#39;m fearful of lavender because it just smells and tastes a little like air freshener but this was just right. The Caramel Hot Chocolate ($7.50) will satisfy your sweet tooth because it&#39;s on the sweet side but i found the chocolate a tad artificial. The foam had somewhat of a brulee texture which was interesting. And if you like latte art, they do a lot of cute animal prints.<br><br>We concluded that the best part of the meal was the maple sea salt cheesecake ($9). You cannot miss this smokey sweet and creamy cheesecake. The cheese was rich but not too heavy and it went perfectly with the crunchy and compact graham crust. I suspect a lot of butter went into it but it&#39;s awesome. Repeat after me: Butter is awesome (especially salted ones).<br><br>D&#39;Good Cafe also has a rooftop area for alfresco dining. This would be perfect at night or on an extremely cool day. Pretty isn&#39;t it?<br><br>I&#39;d certainly be back for more cheesecake. Tried the Strawberry Cheesecake and it just didn&#39;t cut it after the mindblowingly good maple sea salt one. Enjoy this one!

text: One of my favourite cafes located in Holland Village! Cute deco and furniture which makes the place so cozy and a great place to hang out. While the cafe spans 2 storeys, there isn&#39;t much space for big group gatherings as it&#39;s often crowded, especially on weekends. <br><br>Food at d&#39;Good has always been pretty good. I&#39;m less of a fan of their cakes, however. I had a really nice strawberry cheesecake once which, sadly, I haven&#39;t seen in their cake window for a while. Some of the other cakes I&#39;ve had weren&#39;t awful, but they weren&#39;t amazing either.<br><br>I have to say, their drinks are the best things on the menu for me. I&#39;ve had kiwi juice, which was really sour and definitely made from real kiwi (I love anything sour), but my all time favourite is their lavender earl grey tea latte. It&#39;s creamy without being too heavy, and the presentation of the drink is really pretty too. My sister&#39;s told me that their oolong tea latte is lovely as well.<br><br>A definite must-try!

Pot of tea! Comes with rock candy for the sugar, cute.", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Pot of tea! Comes with rock candy for the sugar, cute.'}]
text: Nice coffee, tea and specialty drinks menu; I love the salted earl grey tea :) Food is decent and the cakes are very good, I tried the red velvet but the chocolate cheesecake also looks delicious. D&#39;Good is a great place to study or work in quiet, although the aircon is always on very high! I find myself working for an hour or so and then taking a break to warm up on the third floor terrace.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/vO6arRuxaB2vdxVpPFEZwA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/d-good-cafe-singapore?reviewid=L1YwWR4VKWstDwZzuO0ngQ&select=vO6arRuxaB2vdxVpPFEZwA', 'altText': "Photo of d'Good Cafe - Singapore, Singapore", 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: One of the few places where I get to choose my type of coffee roast and brewing technique. <br><br>Tried out my favourite coffee (the Ethiopian Yirgacheffe) and it was a steal at 5.50! <br><br>Ambience was nice, though I only tried the seats at The Lawn (level 2) - it had a swing and power points too. <br><br>Will definitely be coming back!

Quaint cafe serving pretty classic brunch dishes in humble portions and great to get some work/studying done. Although a sign says no laptops on the 2nd floor, there are clearly people who set up shop there. There&#39;s a couple outlets, so if you can snag those tables then you&#39;re good to go for some time. The swinging porch chairs facing the street are also so adorable!
Pros: Cute, trendy, and delicious. Cons: crowded, loud, and verrryyyy uncomfortable seating for studying.

text: The  food and drink are very good. I had the croque madam and caramel frappe and they are both very good. The food does take a while to be made so budget some extra time to compensate.

Oh I love this place simply for the fact that it has a swing?!<br><br>Now where can you find swings nowadays? Some parks don&#39;t even have it!<br><br>What&#39;s better then sipping a cuppa and swinging away?<br><br>The faux grass carpet was a bit prickly so don&#39;t take off your shoes!

text: This place is one of two including Jimmy the Monkey at One North where I would say you can get an excellent coffee and where I would dare order a macchiato and expect to get a real one. Tried the scrambled eggs. On toast which was small but ok value since it was only $7.50. Mainly this place is great for a coffee. Has free wifi and staff are efficient.

text: I love this place! The food and coffee is delicious and my son enjoys playing with the toys set up on the 3rd floor.

text: It&#39;s a cute cafe with a relaxed ambiance. <br>The only thing that&#39;s stopping me from rating it higher is the &#39;designated study space&#39; being only on the third floor. Clearly the cafe was empty on a Monday morning but they insisted that I HAD to study on the packed loud third floor when there were many empty tables on the second...which was a little bit of a bummer :(

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=wEzjzGIrosldGywLy8dFKg', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'Peggy L.', 'displayLocation': 'Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Peggy L.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=wEzjzGIrosldGywLy8dFKg', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': 69, 'reviewCount': 14, 'eliteYear': None}
text: This is one of our favorite cafe.  Good coffee with lovely latte art.  Each cup comes with a different design.  The menu expends every now and then which is awesome.  There&#39;s something new to try when one feels adventurous than ordering the usual.  Egg Benedict is yummy and the eggs are cooked perfectly each time.   The seafood lobster bisque is one of my favorite.  The soup is delicious and licked clean every time.  Be Careful though if you come with a few friends and order all at once.  They sometimes will group your order together before buzzing your pager, so food could get cold while &#34;waiting&#34;.  Their strawberry ice cream is super creamy and yummy!  They wouldn&#39;t tell me where they got it from.  Dang it!   Chocolate lava cake is heavenly by itself or with the strawberry ice cream  d&#39;good is a self service cafe and they get quite busy on the weekend.

Char siew is a bit on the dry side.  Dry Hor fun is very soft.', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Char siew is a bit on the dry side.  Dry Hor fun is very soft.'}]
text: Hill City Cafe, or Shan Cheng as you will see on their cafe entrance above the menu, is accessed via the outside of Paya Lebar Square on level 1, facing Singapore Post building. <br><br>It is a small 38 seater cafe that serves up Chinese style hor fun, noodles &amp; rice dishes. <br><br>Upon entering, the staff will ask you how many are in your group &amp; will only seat you once your whole group is present. This is because this cafe gets crowded very fast &amp; the customers eat &amp; leave fairly quickly as well. Once seated, you will need to go to the counter inside at the end on the left to place your order. Cash payment is the usual  payment mode. Once ordered, you will be given your drinks &amp; a white round palm sized device which you can bring back to your table &amp; wait for it to light up when your order is ready for collected. <br><br>The condiments &amp; cutlery counter is just facing the order counter so help yourself while you wait. Tissue is also available for those who forgot to bring theirs. <br><br>Popular dishes are their hor fun in dark sauce which is very soft &amp; light. Although I find the soup a bit salty. A set lunch of a bowl of hor fun with char siew, soup &amp; drink only costs $6.50 which is quite value for money. <br><br>A good place for a quick noodle fix.

Love, love, love this place.  I could probably eat it every day, for realz. <br><br>Although I&#39;d then be broke, but I&#39;d be healthy, so what&#39;s more important? <br><br>Anyway, my work people rave about GT all day every day, so I thought let me go see what all the fuss is about.  I ordered the upstream which was really really good.  The dressing was the real star, and although when you look at the amount of food you are getting, you start to panic, but you&#39;ll be full.  I promise.  You can also make your own salad, or bowl, or whatever, but they have some pretty good ones already put together.  The second one I tried had chicken, and more of a Mexican feel, but the upsteam was def. better.  For a meal, snack and water will run you $16.  Not cheap, but def. worth it.  I saw they also do breakfast, and have some interesting stuff going on, so looking forward to go when I have a free minute to spare in the AM.  Perfect for those who work in the CBD and need a quick, healthy lunch, or live in the area and need something after a work out, or on the way home from a late night at the office.

text: Delicious.. BUT EXPENSIVE! <br><br>I really don&#39;t understand. Does eating lunch in CBD has to be this expensive? I know there are bankers and lawyers but there are also underpaid consultants (aka me) and also others who earn a decent salary for a living. I call this pure indulgent eating here, and can only do it once a while.  <br><br>That being said, Grain Traders serves really good, fresh food. I enjoyed my food here tremendously. It definitely reminds of the fuss- free, health-conscious restaurants you get in Australia or the US. The concept is the same like The Daily Cut, you can either order set meal called &#34;Hero Bowls&#34; or DIY your own lunch. Same price at $16 nett. Hero Bowls section comes in 6 choices but since I was hangry (read: hungry + angry), i head straight to the DIY section. For the price you get to choose: <br><br>1 grain (quinoa, brown rice, japanese rice, or soba)<br>1 protein (beef, salmon or chicken)<br>1 hot vege (various items to choose from)<br>2 cold vege (various salads, kimchis etc)<br>1 topping (no, im not talking about rainbow sprinkles or m&amp;ms here)<br>1 sauce (you MUST MUST try the MISO CARAMEL sauce!!)<br><br>........................and you get a bowl of wholesome meal. <br><br>There;s also a coffee bar on the other side of the restaurant that serves decent coffee at the price you get from &#39;bucks. I got myself a cup of latte and it was pretty good, at $5.50. <br><br>I spent a total of $21.50 of lunch today, which is equivalent to almost 3 plates of normal mixed rice from the hawker center. Will i come back, yes. Maybe once every fortnight. Or else I might have to get a bank loan to eat here daily. <br><br>Lunch crowd (12-1pm) tends to get overwhelming so come really early or late to avoid the madness. Service is prompt and efficient overall! <br><br>p/s: The miso caramel sauce is as good as the maple butter syrup from clinton st bakery. I can drink it on its own, I swear

Banana oatmeal- one of the best oatmeals I&#39;ve had!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': "Banana oatmeal- one of the best oatmeals I've had!"}]
text: One of my favorite breakfast/lunch places when I wanted something healthy in Singapore!<br><br>For breakfast, I&#39;ve had their polenta and oatmeal. They give you two 2-3&#34; circular pieces of grilled polenta with greens, beans, and avocado. For oatmeal, it&#39;s a big hearty scoop with delicious toppings. Oatmeal&#39;s a little bit on the sweeter side but what I loved about it was how sticky it was. Both are $8 SGD which is a little bit pricey but totally worth it. <br><br>For lunch, I usually make my own bowl. I&#39;ve had their tuna, salmon, and chicken as protein with toppings such as apple kimchi, beans, and roasted veggies. For dressing, their beetroot feta yogurt, wasabi, and coconut curry were my favorites. All the ingredients are super fresh. I also love their concept- it&#39;s healthy with unique flavors! The only thing I wished they offered was giving the option of doing half greens and grains for the base (you can only get salad only or noodles/rice only).<br><br>Service is super quick (even during peak hours) as it is in the hustle and bustle area of CBD. Definitely recommend this place to anyone in Singapore who is looking for something healthy and hearty!

Let me make it clear, I am only taking off one star because of the price, as other people mentioned, of the bowls and drinks. As everyone says, the quality is there, but for lunch, it may be too pricey for an every day occasion. <br><br>HOWEVER, I did want to review something that most people don&#39;t think of when they think of Grain Traders: THE BAGEL SANDWICHES. Only $10 and you get: a bagel, a protein, a spread, a veggie, and something extra. I always get their plain bagels toasted (they only have 2 types of bagels unfortunately), with jalapeno cream cheese, cured salmon, avocado, and spinach. ALL THAT FOR JUST $10! Great deal! The only sad part is that breakfast is only available 8am-10:30am. Booooo. I want bagels for dinner!

text: This will put a dent in your wallet, but once it touches your lips, it&#39;s just so good!<br><br>I understand the appeal. In CBD, tons of people want healthier options, and this is definitely one of them. There are a lot of choices here, and possibilities seem endless.<br><br>I&#39;m usually the type who&#39;d rather just choose whatever combos they offer, but none of them really appealed to me so I went the custom bowl route.<br><br>You get to choose from lots of different grains, proteins, and veggie add-ons. Everything I chose tasted great: the charred corn, striploin steak, pickled capsicums, and the bean pico de gallo. Additionally you can choose a sauce, and that in itself took me a while because there was a lot and I wanted to try so many!<br><br>Depending on what you get it could be $15-20. For Singapore, that&#39;s a pretty expensive lunch. <br><br>To beat the crowd, you seriously have to go between 11-11:45, because once 12 comes around the queue spans the entire restaurant and there are no seats available.<br><br>Enjoy your healthy lunch! I, on the other hand, just need to learn how to make all of these ingredients at home so I can assemble myself!

text: Simple, good food that&#39;s also healthy fast food! <br><br>The menu hasn&#39;t changed since they first opened, which is a good sign - it&#39;s not an F&amp;B outlet that follows the latest food trends. <br><br>A little on the pricey side, but your body will thank you, trust me! Satisfying meals every time I visit, and pretty good (attentive) service too!

Divine!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Divine!'}]
text: This is my new favorite lunch place! The food and coffee are both above par, and I love the variety of healthy and colorful food options.

What&#39;s with the attitude here, ladies? Grain Traders must have the shittest service in Singapore, hands down. Not a single smile and really curt replies when we ask questions. It wasn&#39;t even at peak lunch hour. And I thought it was just me, maybe I had too many questions since it was my first time, but my two other girlfriends had the same treatment. There wasn&#39;t anyone in line after me at 2pm. Ok, maybe they were tired from lunch service.<br>The quinoa was yummy. The beef ok... For the same price I could get just as yummy a salad without the bitchiest attitude from the whole bunch of staff. Not cool, Grain Traders!

text: Obsessed with this place! My husband took me for lunch today and I forgot to take pictures of the food, but I had the steak and salmon bowls to share. Coffee was alright but the juices were delicious. Definitely recommend, but seating is limited and it&#39;s super packed during lunch hours. Still, people don&#39;t eat for more than 15 mins on a busy work week so turnover is not slow. Steak is more filling and salmon is healthier. Husband said he also tried the pork which was good. I can&#39;t wait to try the rest of the menu. Will come during non peak hours since I&#39;m in school anyway and don&#39;t have a set lunch time. Too bad they don&#39;t have one near my school (INSEAD) otherwise they would sell out so quick! Maybe do a pop up for a month or something. Anyway, right now daily cut and salad stop are the only healthy options. And class ends late so it would be nice if healthy options are open, not just bar food. Anyway, go and eat healthy here!

text: Lau Pa Sat was my first ever Hawker Centre and it made a lasting impression. <br><br>This review is based on my pre-COVID experience so I&#39;m unsure what it is like now considering Hawker Centres are so communal. <br><br>When visiting Singapore, I wanted to experience the liveliness of a Hawker Centre and this did not disappoint. There are so many food stands specializing in certain dishes so you know whatever you end up choosing, it will be good. I ordered the duck and one stand and my fiancé ordered Pad Thai at another. Both were good but the Pad Thai was honestly THE BEST Pad Thai I have ever had and still crave it to this day. <br><br>The prices are incredibly cheap and it makes your vacation money stretch. <br><br>Singapore is hot and because Hawker Centres are busy and full of people on their lunch breaks, it gets even warmer. However, there are fans blowing which helps a little. <br><br>If you find an empty seat without tissues on the table, grab that seat! People claim their seats by putting a packet of tissues on the table. It was so amazing to watch this ritual because here in the U.S, not only would someone take that seat, they&#39;d also take the tissues. It was beautiful to see how trustworthy people were with leaving their claimed seats to grab food and how honest the other customers were by not grabbing the claimed seats. <br><br>Overall, this was a wonderful experience and anyone visiting Singapore should come to this specific Hawker Centre. Why this one? Because the Pad Thai is worth the  long flight. Definitely try it!
