Interior', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Interior'}]
text: Somehow this is one of the very few original outdoor open air eating locations that survived Singapore&#39;s redevelopment. Yes, it has been upgraded since times of old but it has remained a great place to check out a vast mixture of true Singaporean cuisine.<br><br>There are two distinct areas of Lau Pa Sat Festival Market. There is the interior where you will find tons of food vendors offering various types and interpretations of food and then there is the outdoor space where you will encounter a lot of food hackers calling you over to their stand.  The interior space does protect you from the elements to a certain degree but the outdoor food stalls are definitely the place to eat at night. <br><br>Overall, this is a great place to check out the various interpretations of true Singaporean cuisine and to truly experience Singaporean culture. One of the great things I find about Lau Pa Sat is that though, sure you are going to encounter a certain number of tourists, it is not overrun by them like say the outdoor dining space of Chinatown.<br><br>Overall, fun place to eat.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/h_ejQhCJwVMOOipUj0pPlA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=MMJB5380yc60nqUVXsuR_g&select=h_ejQhCJwVMOOipUj0pPlA', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore. 7 &amp; 8', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': '7 & 8'}]
text: How can you not visit! The place is alive with colors and sounds AND FOOD!! Its tradition, if you are in Singapore and you HAVE to try it at least once.<br><br>It&#39;s not what I expected, but so glad I went. Here you can try some of the best Satay and some of the worst, but heck that&#39;s some of the fun isn&#39;t it? <br><br>Just beware, you will be bombarded with people coming at you trying to get you to order from their stands. Just say no and walk around until you are ready to order. Once you decide, order from the one you decide on and sit down, eat, drink and enjoy!!!!

Beef and chicken satays', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Beef and chicken satays'}]
text: Among the myriad of Hawker Centers sprinkled throughout Singapore, Lau Pa Sat is known famously for Satays. <br><br>Situated in the financial district with a panoramic view of the high rises that is especially beautiful at night. <br><br>While there are foods and sweets for every cravings, Satay is the main reason drawing tourists and locals alike to the dozens of stands lining up outside. <br><br>The most raved about is stall number 8. Many waxed poetic words in describing their experiences. As a Yelper, I felt the need to do my due diligence by way of comparisons. We ordered satays from another stall in addition to stall 8. <br><br>In this case, the hype is real. Stall number 8 was definitely tastier. The beef, chicken and prawns were all tender and well seasoned with a nice balance of sweet and savory. The charred edges and smoky flavor made it that much more delicious. It is best eaten with the accompanied peanut sauce that is sweet with the sambal lending a spicy kick. <br><br>If you are looking for a tried-and-true satay place with tons of reasonably priced choices, Lau Pa Sat will not disappoint.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/HQYHaWWeWu_cJbdLzqkouQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=Y_l2zyVNp0_dCdhJ6DaN7g&select=HQYHaWWeWu_cJbdLzqkouQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/1-K_rHZBLVoT4XQcStwEwQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=Y_l2zyVNp0_dCdhJ6DaN7g&select=1-K_rHZBLVoT4XQcStwEwQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/O5zyNx7-4-8R-oOc6oD7sw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=Y_l2zyVNp0_dCdhJ6DaN7g&select=O5zyNx7-4-8R-oOc6oD7sw', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: Two different people recommended this place and we end up going for dinner.<br><br>We were in shock with everything going on there. They have over 50 satai stands outside, with people cooking on the bbq the chicken, meat, shrimp, and all the types of satay you could imagine. A very colorful place.<br><br>Also, they have a HUGE food court inside and it has so many food vendors that I didn&#39;t know what to choose, so we end up seating outside and eating at one of their satay sections.<br><br>Price, flavor, and quality were great!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/XJxrnzHRQ-Fz8ANFnNs4sw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=LJOyruQaweMithRDktUszQ&select=XJxrnzHRQ-Fz8ANFnNs4sw', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: We came to visit back in October of 2019.  It&#39;s hard to miss since it&#39;s such a gigantic center.  When we first arrived, there was lots of activity around the outside of the entrance, consisting of vendors BBQing food on open grills and people sitting out on picnic tables.  There was actually a sea of people and it was quite busy.  Once we actually entered the center, however, it was quiet, probably because everyone was outside.  About half of the restaurants were closed, however because the place is so big there was still lots of selection.  I think next time we would have opted to eat outside sine there was more going on out there, and wished that we hadn&#39;t visited on our last day.

I missed Lau Pa Sat on my first trip to Singapore and promised myself to check it out when I came back.  Sad to say, I was a little disappointed.<br><br>First off, location.  This is located in the middle of the Central Business District (CBD aka Financial district).  If you are walking and following any kind of GPS it can be a bit confusing, as I found ourselves walking in circles for a bit.  But we finally found it amongst the skyscrapers.<br><br>Yes, there is a lot of hype about Lau Pa Sat being famous for their Satays.  I can see why - dozens of vendors set up on the street with fresh Satay during the evening.  Tasty, yes.  But they were pretty small in size,  and to be honest, there is not much difference it seems from each of them (quality or price wise).    <br><br>Do note about the warnings in other reviews about the seafood vendors there - while sitting they will bring menus for their stalls and the seafood satay is WAY MORE EXPENSIVE than the satays! We paid $50SGD for 4 &#34;giant&#39; prawns which was good but not worth that price.  Stick with the street stay vendors and you&#39;ll be good.<br><br>Glad I checked it off my list but I will stick with other hawker markets on my next visit.

Satay', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Satay'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/83eppZR03qhh5jwYzvksyQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=Ewh7ARgW3ko-3N2JQkdwfQ&select=83eppZR03qhh5jwYzvksyQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore. Beef la mian', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Beef la mian'}]
text: You will find a big selection of food stalls here. 8 rows to be exact. From Malay, Thai, Chinese, to loca dishes. There is satay outside if you fancy a stick or 30, which they tried selling us.<br><br>Great prices! The Xiao Long Bao stall had 6 of them plus a giant bowl of beef noodles for only $11. Satay sticks were 20 for $14. Cheap beer too!<br><br>I like casual spots like this, a mix of locals and tourists.

I can&#39;t speak for locals because I&#39;m a tourist myself but as a tourist - this is as good as it gets for satay. I have travelled to Singapore numerous times as a child and my family&#39;s &#39;must go-to&#39; place in Singapore time and time again is always Lau Pa Sat in the evening. I have so many fond memories of this hawker place that I knew I just HAD to bring my husband when we visited in 2019. <br><br>I remembered the gist of the format of things from my visits as a kid to know that you should bee-line for the satay stall that you want, order what you want, let the stall employee help you find an open today and sit your ass down and wait for other people to come with their menus. Unfortunately, during my last visit - I remembered everything up to the &#39;sit you ass down and wait&#39; part. I was so eager to go inside to get the remaining dishes of what I remember my parents ordering during our past visits here that I forgot to remind my husband to be on the look-out for menus from other places. Big mistake because that&#39;s where I missed the stingray.... (another must eat), but that&#39;s ok because I went in and got my char gwai deo and oyster omelet.<br><br>The satay takes awhile (like a lonnnng while) so be prepared to wait but if you find that you&#39;re waiting for 30+ minutes and still no sign of it, feel free to remind the stall worker you placed your order from that you&#39;re still waiting. But during the meantime, sit tight, absorb the AMAZING atmosphere, and down a Tiger beer pint or two. Hey, if you&#39;re in for the long run - get a jug! If beer isn&#39;t your thing, go inside and find the juice/smoothie stall in the middle of the market. <br><br>Lau Pa Sat is just amazing because it&#39;s such an eye-opener to the phenomenon of satay stalls and the hawker experience in the middle of downtown where you&#39;re surrounded by finance skyscrapers.  Highly recommend for every tourist coming through Singapore. If there was one thing you just can&#39;t miss in Singapore - it would be Lau Pa Sat!

Beef and chicken satay', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Beef and chicken satay'}]
text: Too touristy. Too many hagglers wanting you to buy satay, or go to their food stall, or wanting to give you a menu. It made us want to turn around and leave. But, we stayed anyway for the satay, which wasn&#39;t even that good. It was also too sweet. I&#39;ve had better satay at Satay by the Bay. The noodle dishes were also not good. The only decent food at Lau Pa Sat was the Singapore oyster omelette. But, this was not a dish that was worth coming back here just to eat. Unfortunately, we will not be returning to this hawker center.

text: I had to try Lau Pa Sat after seeing the movie Crazy Rich Asian during the short trip to Singapore!! I spoke to some of my friends who live in Singapore and they recommended SATAY chicken and shrimp from #7 or #8!! Well, that is my rule: always ask and trust the local!!! It was good and a great street food experience!! There were other booths inside the market as well. We got sugar cane drink and that was good. This one I didn&#39;t get the recommendation from friends, but just join the longest line, and the result won&#39;t disappoint you!!!

I live in the CBD and as such, Lau Pa Sat is my closest hawker center.  And although a zoo during the work week when at least 100,000 blue collar workers are looking for lunch all at the same time, I find this place really quite nice during off hours and evenings (on the weekends, some places are closed, thus why mid-week is better). <br><br>Lots of seating, loads of cheap food options for any craving, and on the land of historically the first open air markets like this in Singapore countless years ago, Lau Pa Sat is a little chunk of history amongst the urban jungle growth of Singapore&#39;s financial district. <br><br>In addition to the Satay Street experience that is available every night street side (See Yelp &#34;Boon Tat Street Food Market&#34;), I am addicted to Thunder Tea Rice served from the Thunder Tea Rice stahl at Lau Pa Sat.  A bowl of rice/quinoa, topped with green onions, peanuts, basil and dried anchovies, then you pour over a thick layer of green tea...it sounds awful, but such a healthy, hearty food discovery of mine I love.  A bit salty, unique flavors, fresh.  You can then get it as a set, with tofu and a fried egg all for like $8 SGD.  But from vegan options, to Chinese, Malay, Indian, fresh juices, bakery items, beer....there is a lot to be found here. <br><br>Now a local would say that this is not the best hawker center in Singapore and I would not disagree (Tiong Bahru might be my favorite!). You will always find more authentic options the further out you go from the tourist areas for sure.  But if you are a tourist and looking for your closest option to MBS and the harbor area or you live downtown like me, Lau Pa Sat is your closest option and a relatively decent, clean one at that.

Great street food for satay skewers, but make sure you come in the evening! They&#39;re not open during the day time. <br><br>However, my mom and sister did get skewers that we&#39;re still kinda raw so be careful and check before you chew!

text: We walked through here early in the day after visiting a couple of temples. The heat here really gets to me such that I&#39;m not only grumpy but tired. <br>Hubby&#39;s main interest is to come to these places to take pictures. We had a big breakfast at the hotel so lunch wasn&#39;t even on our radar so we didn&#39;t try anything. <br><br>It&#39;s not very clean but the place is large.  Bathrooms are outside and they&#39;re old and not very clean either. Bring your own toilet paper because there is none in these stalls. There is a community trough outside to wash your hands. The tables have dried bird turd on them because the birds fly in and out. I watched some of the food prep areas. That was enough to turn me off from even thinking of eating there. Saw people eating with their hands for certain dishes. Another vendor had fried fish piled high. Guess it sits there all day in the heat waiting for a purchase.

Excellent Hawker center in the CBD.   So many choices.<br><br>I really enjoyed a roast pork and rice dish at Chicky Fun.   The pork was moist and had crisp edges.    The food at most of these stalls are about US$3-4 each plate.    <br><br>You can pick from juices, dessert, dim sum, Indian, Chinese, Vietnamese, Noodles, Steaks, Soups, etc... <br><br>Great selection.  Great prices.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/pdIQxJ_W7XOrfpa9lEcVHg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=zW5dWbTolNt0QqJFvuA3VA&select=pdIQxJ_W7XOrfpa9lEcVHg', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/22TpkJ87P9yLWqj9bTUdAQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=zW5dWbTolNt0QqJFvuA3VA&select=22TpkJ87P9yLWqj9bTUdAQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore. Chicken Satay from #7 - Amazing!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Chicken Satay from #7 - Amazing!'}]
text: We took the stroller from merrily on Park to have dinner at the house. We came here specifically after 7:00 pm to experience the satay. I knew from previous research that I wanted to go to stall #7. When we got there the owner was very excited to inform me that do to our popularity she is now stall #7 and #8.<br><br>We made our order and then a gentleman escorted us to an empty table. This was helpful as the place was packed and due to his kindness we did not have to deal with the hassle and bustle of locating a table. Also due to my research, I knew to place a pack of tissues on my table. This indicates that the table is reserved. The chicken satay was amazing! Definitely the best I&#39;ve ever had. The minimum order is 10 pieces at SGD $14 (US $10).<br><br>Some of the vendors can be very pushy and you might be put off by some of the aggression that comes with that. However, once you get over the initial hustle and bustle you start feeling right at home. <br><br>Side note, The more popular food stalls are those that have a line and are not pushing you to visit their stall. Look around at stalls with lines or even foods that people are eating. Most people are happy to tell you where they got their food if you see something that interests you.<br><br>I was bummed to find that many of the places started closing just before 9:30 PM so I did not get a chance to try popiah or laksa. Thankfully it wasn&#39;t my last night in Singapore and I knew that I had plenty of time to try all of the various cuisines.

Seafood fried rice and stingray', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Seafood fried rice and stingray'}]
text: Of all the food I&#39;ve have in Singapore, this was my favorite experience. The seating is outdoor and there are more than a dozen street vendors. We sat and ordered from booth #8 since that&#39;s where the locals order satay from. <br><br>We had a variety of satay. The seasoning on it was kind of sweet but it was quite tasty. Ordered a beer and just enjoyed the ambiance, food, and had great conversations with friends. <br><br>The lemonade from the drink stand was very refreshing. It was not too tart or sweet.

Thunder tea rice with a bao from another stall', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Thunder tea rice with a bao from another stall'}]
text: Ughh Lau Pa Sat is a dream. Exciting food options around every corner. Unfortunately I don&#39;t recall the names of the stands I went to over the weeks, though one does stick out for its unique offering: Thunder Tea Rice. It was a mixed rice dish with a sort of green tea pour-over. From my understanding this is meant to one of the healthier options at Lau Pa Sat. Very tasty, and if you enjoy green tea definitely go for it

text: As far as Hawker Stations this is a good one. I cant say its my favorite although certainly a great place to rest from the hot sun in a hot cafeteria environment. Staff are friendly and dont chase you down to sample anything. Mostly locals on the day we visited. If im in the area I will come back for sure.

text: My first venture to Singapore&#39;s street food wasn&#39;t a bad experience but I remember that stepping out of the hotel, I became a ball of flame because the heat and humidity was something I was not used to.  This entire place is filled w/ many different types of food (Indian, Mediterranean, Malaysian, Chinese, Vietnamese, Filipino, etc.) but the drawback was that this place isn&#39;t equipped w A/C.  Little did I know these street places do not have A/C.  These places do not have napkins to give out either... there is also no such thing as iced water.  <br><br>I had a samosas and an Indian plate which I thought was very delicious and very cheap. The dim sum was very greasy but tasty, still. <br><br>Cash only.  I hate that these places are cash only.<br><br>Warning: you will sweat even if you are motionless.

text: Just a short visit after 22:00 for the famous stall 7/8 &#39;best satay&#39;. They really weren&#39;t that bad but also not to categorize them with the best I&#39;ve eaten. Quite touristy feeling.<br><br>The prawns are quite expensive conpared to the meat satays and quite dry. The best ones by far were the mutton! Ordered a second round of those

text: This is a hawker center eating area in the heart of the financial district. It is pricier than something you&#39;ll find in the residential areas, but serves as good of food as anything else. A lot of people will swam here during lunch time b/c the workers and people working in the tall buildings around will come down here for lunch. Avoid during 11-1 pm is my opinion if you don&#39;t want to wait long lines. The food here is excellent and prices are affordable compared to sitting at a sit down restaurant and ordering. You&#39;re only paying 3-4 USD$ a plate and if you&#39;re in a group of friends, can order a lot of plates to try amongst yourselves. I won&#39;t write too much of what to get here, b/c it&#39;s all good and other reviewers have spoken out what is good, but as someone who is 1/2 Singaporean, I can say it&#39;s all solid stuff! Definitely have someone sit down and hold a seat for you b/c it can get crowded. <br><br>Some cool history is that this used to be a church and thus you&#39;ll hear the large bell still chime the hour as you sit and enjoy your food. The inside is spacious and grand and you can see the tracings of past historical structures- this makes this place enjoyable for food with its historical flavor and location. When you walk out, you are right in the middle of the busiest part of Singapore. And just a few mins within walking distance of the other exciting parts of Singapore like the Marina Bay area and the Chinatown and the Merlion and other places. Highly recommend coming here if you have not hit a hawker center yet and tried out local foods!

text: Great hawker stall in the middle of downtown. Lots of food options, tons of variety. I had some fresh juice the pear apple was my favorite. I had black and white carrot cake, really delicious. Lots of hot sauces to add! I also had a noodle dish with pork belly, also yummy! Definitely a good stop for a huge variety of food choices!

text: When you are visiting Singapore, you MUST visit this location.  It is one of the best outdoor food court.  Almost 100 restaurants serving different foods..  I wasn&#39;t able to try all but I did try satay.  During the night time, road gets closed and small cart vendors create new few court selling satays.  <br><br>I have purchased combo package from street cart which had chicken, beef, and prawns.  So good..  it makes perfect combination with tiger beer...  Beer lady walks around the dining tables and getting orders.<br><br>If you are into local food, you need to come.<br><br>Be sure to take napkins or wet tissues since you can&#39;t find them at any place.  There is a lady who goes around and sells the tissues.

Char kway teow', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Char kway teow'}]
text: Lau Pa Sat is my first experience with a hawker center in Singapore. It&#39;s pretty interesting and if you haven&#39;t gone to one I would recommend it!<br><br>The street has some stalls and lots of seating. It&#39;s pretty humid in Singapore so if you don&#39;t mind the weather you can sit outside with everyone.<br><br>I tried the stand on the far right (not inside the building). I got the char kway teow but the spicy version. My friend tried the non spicy version. I thought both tasted good but it&#39;s not really similar to pad see ew at all, so don&#39;t go expecting that flavor. I thought it was generally less flavorful and less sweet than pad see ew. The spicy version was more flavorful to me and quite oily which I like!<br><br>Inside there was a lot of stands. One of the stalls had fruit drinks, which was pretty good.

Satay', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Satay'}]
text: I had heard so much about this hawker center that I thought it would be a lot different than what it really was.  <br><br>Pros: There was more of a variety as I saw Costa Rican, Filipino and Korean bing soo stalls.  It&#39;s also really clean compared to some of the other ones.  And the actual building looks pretty cool.  <br><br>Cons: I HATE being approached by people holding menus.  Apparently that&#39;s called &#34;touting.&#34;  I call it being a pain in the ass.  I get that it&#39;s just a part of life here and that&#39;s fine, but I hate having several menus from different businesses shoved in my face while I&#39;m just sitting there at a table after I&#39;ve already ordered food.  Yes, the satay street is also really cool and an awesome experience but holy crap were those people aggressive. After having a menu thrown at me, the man lied and told me all the stalls had the same exact menu with the exact prices so don&#39;t bother looking.  Oh really? I walked two steps to the right and saw a different menu.  Yeah, I&#39;ve heard that stall 7/8 was the best, but we didn&#39;t feel like dropping $25 on meat as we had already eaten.  The last stall at the very end of the street was .80 per stick, (10 minimum) which was perfect to share with my brother.  And it was awesome! Unless you&#39;re a satay expert, I&#39;m sure any of the stalls will satisfy your skewer meat needs.  That peanut sauce though. Yum!  I would definitely still visit this place if you&#39;re a tourist, but I liked Maxwell and the Chinatown hawkers better.

This is a better hawker center than Maxwell in my opinion. Most importantly to me, the sanitary conditions seem better, it&#39;s more spacious and clean, and there are still a number of great food options available. I got some roasted chicken along with a sugar cane drink. The chicken was flavorful, and the portion was filling for the average person (I still felt a bit hungry after so I got noodles as well). Overall, I would recommend this place for the diversity of food and cleanliness.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=_tFquA65cSXC98QrQgOJug', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Yb8iKY2pSs6nYlnMaXtHQQ/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Yb8iKY2pSs6nYlnMaXtHQQ/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Yb8iKY2pSs6nYlnMaXtHQQ/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Yb8iKY2pSs6nYlnMaXtHQQ/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Yb8iKY2pSs6nYlnMaXtHQQ/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/Yb8iKY2pSs6nYlnMaXtHQQ/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'James M.', 'displayLocation': 'Las Vegas, NV', 'altText': 'James M.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=_tFquA65cSXC98QrQgOJug', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 305, 'photoCount': 558, 'reviewCount': 373, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Overall awesome place and lots of options but watch out...some stands better than others...<br><br>Fruit juice stand is good but asks $1 if no ice else fills up with Ice mostly. Not worth it.<br><br>Satay stand 3 4 was pretty good but less than. Best satay hype<br><br>Satay stand 7 8 was ok but beef very chewy<br><br>Fragrance garden cafe soup wasn&#39;t very fresh

Definitely the most disappointing hawker center I&#39;ve been to in Singapore. Everyone who says Lau Pa Sat has turned into a tourist trap is right. The dishes you get here barely scratch the surface of what any other hawker center has in terms of variety and flavor. Yes, there are a ton of stalls, but it&#39;s variety for variety&#39;s sake. <br><br>This is also an uncharacteristically pushy place where vendors walk from table to table, imploring you to look at their menu and order from their stall. And don&#39;t even get me started about the aggressive vendors at satay street right outside. <br><br>Save your money (yes, stuff also costs more here) and time. Head away from the downtown core and indulge at the hawker centers at Old Airport Road, Serangoon, or Chinatown instead.

Satay ($38)', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Satay ($38)'}]
text: This is the nicest Hawker center in singapore. It&#39;s newly renovated, so it better be, but I was surprised just how clean and bright it was. The signage is also very consistent and nice. Because it&#39;s so beautiful, it&#39;s very crowded, especially with tourists and foreigner business workers.<br><br>The food is not that exceptional, but there&#39;s a huge variety all in one place, so you&#39;re guaranteed to find something you like. We got satay (which is on the street side), basil chicken, pork on noodles and char keay teow. Everything was tasty, but I definitely have favorite places to go for many of these dishes. We also got yummy sugar cane juice. Yum!<br><br>Seating can be difficult, especially if you have a large group, so you have to hawk dive for tables sometimes. This is definitely a very Singaporean experience that everyone should experience!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/U_7eHjH4o63yRld9IyyDOw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=hASIW94e2tl1-Z0nEzbHTQ&select=U_7eHjH4o63yRld9IyyDOw', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/vOmW4k4Lo3uEE7vikYLbWQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=hASIW94e2tl1-Z0nEzbHTQ&select=vOmW4k4Lo3uEE7vikYLbWQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Oyma-PXFFlT_xVDzbgDsnQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=hASIW94e2tl1-Z0nEzbHTQ&select=Oyma-PXFFlT_xVDzbgDsnQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/p7H4S3mi92Jp9lBVDv-t0A/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=hASIW94e2tl1-Z0nEzbHTQ&select=p7H4S3mi92Jp9lBVDv-t0A', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: Just a short visit after 22:00 for the famous stall 7/8 &#39;best satay&#39;. They really weren&#39;t that bad but also not to categorize them with the best I&#39;ve eaten. Quite touristy feeling.<br><br>The prawns are quite expensive conpared to the meat satays and quite dry. The best ones by far were the mutton! Ordered a second round of those

I missed Lau Pa Sat on my first trip to Singapore and promised myself to check it out when I came back.  Sad to say, I was a little disappointed.<br><br>First off, location.  This is located in the middle of the Central Business District (CBD aka Financial district).  If you are walking and following any kind of GPS it can be a bit confusing, as I found ourselves walking in circles for a bit.  But we finally found it amongst the skyscrapers.<br><br>Yes, there is a lot of hype about Lau Pa Sat being famous for their Satays.  I can see why - dozens of vendors set up on the street with fresh Satay during the evening.  Tasty, yes.  But they were pretty small in size,  and to be honest, there is not much difference it seems from each of them (quality or price wise).    <br><br>Do note about the warnings in other reviews about the seafood vendors there - while sitting they will bring menus for their stalls and the seafood satay is WAY MORE EXPENSIVE than the satays! We paid $50SGD for 4 &#34;giant&#39; prawns which was good but not worth that price.  Stick with the street stay vendors and you&#39;ll be good.<br><br>Glad I checked it off my list but I will stick with other hawker markets on my next visit.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=C7KRfB4PvY601xBOjUV7ng', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'Christine K.', 'displayLocation': 'Alpharetta, GA', 'altText': 'Christine K.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=C7KRfB4PvY601xBOjUV7ng', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 3, 'photoCount': 819, 'reviewCount': 95, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Awesome place for delicious and a huge variety of food. Specially in the evening very crowded and the back street full of roasting satay stands that you can smell from a distance. You just don&#39;t know what to order because everything is prepared fresh and looks and smells delicious. Everytime I visit Singapore this is a must go place!

Definitely the most disappointing hawker center I&#39;ve been to in Singapore. Everyone who says Lau Pa Sat has turned into a tourist trap is right. The dishes you get here barely scratch the surface of what any other hawker center has in terms of variety and flavor. Yes, there are a ton of stalls, but it&#39;s variety for variety&#39;s sake. <br><br>This is also an uncharacteristically pushy place where vendors walk from table to table, imploring you to look at their menu and order from their stall. And don&#39;t even get me started about the aggressive vendors at satay street right outside. <br><br>Save your money (yes, stuff also costs more here) and time. Head away from the downtown core and indulge at the hawker centers at Old Airport Road, Serangoon, or Chinatown instead.

text: This place is amazing. Tons of different food to try from dim sum to Thai to satay and there are sweets and breads as well. It&#39;s also incredibly cheap... you can eat for $5 SGD easily. Make sure you bring cash as they don&#39;t take credit cards and it can get pretty busy and hot inside. But there are tables just outside the market, too. Definitely a great place to stop for a bite.

text: many different choices chinese japanese malaysian indian korean thai vietnamese etc. can always look for rated stalls as well as long queue to know which ones are good. char kway teow ok

Black and white carrot cake', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Black and white carrot cake'}]
text: Great hawker stall in the middle of downtown. Lots of food options, tons of variety. I had some fresh juice the pear apple was my favorite. I had black and white carrot cake, really delicious. Lots of hot sauces to add! I also had a noodle dish with pork belly, also yummy! Definitely a good stop for a huge variety of food choices!

Lots of choices here, it&#39;s clean, I enjoyed pad thai at one of the booths and prices are not bad. There are fans inside, but can still get a little warm. Make sure to bring your own napkins. However, this place was a little touristy, so if you are looking for somewhere more for the &#34;locals&#34; and authentic food, then I recommend the second floor of a building on Smith Street in Chinatown. It has many many options and excellent food.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=OilpEvC9-SYrTwLy2IAfUw', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/4dVBg_eEjsUCKhhz1ESEaQ/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/4dVBg_eEjsUCKhhz1ESEaQ/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/4dVBg_eEjsUCKhhz1ESEaQ/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/4dVBg_eEjsUCKhhz1ESEaQ/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/4dVBg_eEjsUCKhhz1ESEaQ/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/4dVBg_eEjsUCKhhz1ESEaQ/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Ling C.', 'displayLocation': '天后, Hong Kong', 'altText': 'Ling C.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=OilpEvC9-SYrTwLy2IAfUw', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 3, 'photoCount': 52, 'reviewCount': 71, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Came here 5 years ago and was unimpressed, and upon my return also found it underwhelming. We came just before the lunch crowd and found that the selection and quality was a far cry from the other hawker centres that we went to. And it also seemed to lack some authenticity to the dishes - felt like it was a tourist haunt, tourist prices and dishes catered to the tourist palate. If you&#39;re looking for satays, they aren&#39;t served at lunch time. I&#39;m surprised by all the high ratings for this place, I think you would fare better at a food court than here. Maybe it&#39;s the post drinking measuring stick?

We came to Lau Pa Sat on a Sunday late morning, but many of the stalls lining the streets weren&#39;t open yet so my review will be a little skewed.  However, the food that we had and the service provided was on point.  Lau Pa Sat is located in the CBD of Singapore and by all accounts full to the brim during weekday lunch hours.  It&#39;s located inside what was an old church building and from what I&#39;ve read the building served numerous other purposes.  There was a level of uniqueness to the space that wasn&#39;t present at the Maxwell Hawker center.  However, with the improved interior design comes a price and the overall cost was a few dollars more, but let&#39;s be honest here...we&#39;re talking a dollar or two difference for a four course meal and we&#39;re talking $4 to $5 dollars per dish at the max.  That&#39;s not a bad deal.  This is a much cleaner space as well with more seating than expected.  The restrooms were located on the street side and were well kept.  Overall, it was a good experience for what we had.

text: Good place for good eats. Came here for breakfast. Lots of choices. Reasonably priced. Very near bus stop and easy to get to.

text: Stepping foot into Lau Pa Sat Festival Market, I was in transcendence. So many different food stalls with different cultural influences - Chinese, Indian, Thai, Malaysian, Vietnamese, and even Turkish! - are packed inside this single-level market building in Singapore&#39;s central business district, engulfed by skyscrapers but populated by many locals, especially during the busy lunch hour.<br><br>Despite the vast number of options and the fact that I wasn&#39;t famished to begin with, I only tried two dishes: char kway teow and roti pratha. Char kway teow is a very popular dish consisting of flat rice noodles, Chinese sausage, cockle, and egg stir-fried in a soy sauce mixture, and although I found it a little too salty and very greasy, it was delicious! Understandable as to why it&#39;s a favorite in Singapore, but definitely not something I could eat everyday. The roti pratha came with mutton, curry sauce, and some kind of yogurt/onion sauce. The roti had very fluffy layers, the curry sauce was spicy and mutton tender, and to pull the whole dish together, the yogurt/onion sauce helped balance and tone down all the strong spices and flavors.<br><br>Although there are several stalls selling the similar items, go to the ones with the longest lines, as those are the best. Lau Pa Sat can be a little overwhelming if it&#39;s the first hawker center you&#39;re dining at, but it&#39;s still worth a visit to walk around the stalls and appreciate the architecture. But try to go early around 11am, when the stalls are just starting to open and the lunch rush hour hasn&#39;t begun.

text: Huge variety of stalls but I went when it was quiet. Went to a seafood place. A bit expensive for two meals and rice at $31 but it was good!

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=3UfaNU33lD86wnyAIwyhzA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/5oImEX6jGjqcciJG41J5zg/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/5oImEX6jGjqcciJG41J5zg/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/5oImEX6jGjqcciJG41J5zg/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/5oImEX6jGjqcciJG41J5zg/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/5oImEX6jGjqcciJG41J5zg/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/5oImEX6jGjqcciJG41J5zg/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Rachel R.', 'displayLocation': 'San Francisco, CA', 'altText': 'Rachel R.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=3UfaNU33lD86wnyAIwyhzA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 216, 'photoCount': 897, 'reviewCount': 478, 'eliteYear': None}
photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/95phJA-k5OdCzEbl6lUyhw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=N-hf9bCidz9489uYuPNkjA&select=95phJA-k5OdCzEbl6lUyhw', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore. Cold desserts', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Cold desserts'}]
text: This was my first hawker center experience, and it was a good balance of &#34;overwhelming&#34; meets &#34;toned down for tourists&#34;. We went at night, so it was vaguely cooler, and with some local pals. <br><br>We sat outside on the closed street, near stalls 7 &amp; 8. Half of us were vegetarian so they called over someone with a menu for rice and other non-skewers. <br><br>You can either BYO napkins or people will come by selling wet wipes for a few dollars. They will bring beer to your table but otherwise you&#39;ll need to go inside to retrieve water or juice. <br><br>The meat eaters had skewers of various meats, plus some stingray, which was unique. The veggie eaters has spicy fried rice, a pancake with veggies, and greens in garlic sauce. <br><br>We stopped for shaved ice inside which I found mostly weird - ice with sweet syrup, red beans, corn, and salty gellies - it wasn&#39;t for me. <br><br>4 of us had more than enough food for $75 (SGD)

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/SpzDbeHPFaYL7NIJ_n0eWA/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=4JDwybbrgkSmYQM_Oe0pmQ&select=SpzDbeHPFaYL7NIJ_n0eWA', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Come here for tourist feel? Yes. If haven&#39;t tried the local Satay or seafood, it might be good environment for you. If you are looking for good and real authentic food, this is not the place for you.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/mpHzu2ENALGujFLgQee1NQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=j_oPJetUPiuJwPJSuZDVeA&select=mpHzu2ENALGujFLgQee1NQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/QqInGxfWyFON9Fu3y54ONw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=j_oPJetUPiuJwPJSuZDVeA&select=QqInGxfWyFON9Fu3y54ONw', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore. plain roti with curry dipping sauce', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'plain roti with curry dipping sauce'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/v0zTCB2-dCBHfqDut08kFQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=j_oPJetUPiuJwPJSuZDVeA&select=v0zTCB2-dCBHfqDut08kFQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore. magical hands making banana roti', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'magical hands making banana roti'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/W26X2v6o3-spiBz2KysUvw/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=j_oPJetUPiuJwPJSuZDVeA&select=W26X2v6o3-spiBz2KysUvw', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': ''}]
text: This is not the best hawker food around, but it&#39;s a great place if you around the Marina Bay area.<br><br>The 5 stars is really for the Roti cart guy that is not in the building itself but outside at the end of the seating area. These guys know how to make roti - seriously.  BEST.ROTI.EVER  <br><br>So there are several types:<br>- plain roti<br>- egg roti<br>- banana roti<br><br>I suggest sticking with the plain roti (which comes with a curry dipping sauce) - its PHENOMENAL. And watching the guy make it is so amazing. He pulls it paper thing and puffs it up!  LOVE IT.

text: Pretty decent hawker center. The satay &#34;people&#34; attack you pretty much here, they are very aggressive with you. The skewers are pretty tasty though. The hawker center also has a good variety of items - dim sum, prawn noodle, char kway teow, indian, etc!<br><br>Good price, small portions (compared to America haha)

text: The place is known for serving not only Singapore but other countries local delicacies that is convenient to go right at the city. It can be considered a walking distance after enjoying the scenery at Marina Bay Sands, Esplanade and Merlion. But then,although it was renovated a few years back,(im not so sure how long actually,but i know they have renovated), the place is dirty. Small cockroach keeps walking all over the table. I sat on one empty table chair,to realize that the table has many cockroach,so i went to another table,but then its the same. So,that place,most of the tables,especially the wooden tables,are a home for those cockroaches.

text: Bit dissapointed with the fanfare here.. what happened to the good ol days of street hawker foods?? The open air market feel.. I haven&#39;t been back to SG for a proper visit in 15+ years. Overall Lau Pa seems a bit over priced for hawker. a satay stick is 0.70 cents? BUT I have to admit though it was the highlight of my night. The satay sauce and the chargrilled beef pork !!!! My mouth is watering just thinking about it! I want more!!! I ordered to my hearts content! It was only until the mrs&#39; silent death stare that capped my overzealous ordering. <br><br>Char Kwei Teoh &amp; Lo Bak - saw grps of people hanging around Seng Kee Local Delights. At one stage the line went around the corner. Naturally, I gravitated to the same expecting to see a hot chick serving or something ;) but alas the star of the show was actually 2 dishes that repeatedly were being ordered n picked up by locals. So after figuring out where the line was I did the same... ordered the Lo Bak n char Kwei Teoh. there was a bit of a wait for the food so ventured to another shop that had people lining for the chicken rice. I&#39;ll come back to that in a bit... <br><br>fast fwd to .... n after a devoured plate of chicken rice later I came back just in time to pick up my order. the Lo Bak was great! Very tasty! Not oiled up soggy or burnt. Which I&#39;ve had in the past. um I actually don&#39;t know how else to describe it. It&#39;s just Lo bak w/ egg and spring onions. <br><br>But as for the char kwei teoh ... this was disappointing!! I don&#39;t get it.. a wok was used but why no &#39;wok hei&#39;!! It seemed like it was just stirred n pushed around in oil!!! All the right ingredients were in there including the baby oysters.. But it lacked everything I&#39;d expect from a stir fry from a hawker... flavour! oh be warned the fish cake slice I had in my dish was sour.. I spat it back out! <br><br>happy yelping y&#39;all.. <br>///dt

text: This place is amazing. Tons of different food to try from dim sum to Thai to satay and there are sweets and breads as well. It&#39;s also incredibly cheap... you can eat for $5 SGD easily. Make sure you bring cash as they don&#39;t take credit cards and it can get pretty busy and hot inside. But there are tables just outside the market, too. Definitely a great place to stop for a bite.

text: I&#39;m an American and I visited Lau Pa Sat for the first time a few weeks ago. I was in love with this place, I kept coming back. Lau Pa Sat is truely a foodie&#39;s paradise. They offer everything anyone can crave under one roof. Behind this hawker center is a strip designated for satay stalls in the middle of the modern financial district. On the weekend this place is packed with expats, tourists and locals. The expats are beautiful so come to people watch! The food is great. I didn&#39;t eat anything I didn&#39;t like. It may be a little pricey but totally worth it. You have to try the chili crab, butter prawns, morning glory with sambal, satay of all kinds and for some reason, I just love the guava juice at the beverage stall. The people are friendly and the place is clean. <br><br>TIPS:<br>Some of the stalls are open 24 hours. BYON (Bring Your Own Napkin) or purchase wet naps for 3 for $1.

text: This is where you go to eat the best satay in Singapore. The hawker center is massive with a huge variety of dishes. There is literally something for everyone. This is also where they filmed the movie &#34;Crazy Rich Asians&#34; (the scene where they arrive in SG and then go eat dinner). But honestly the satays are the reason for coming here! The market is open during the day but the Satay shops only open after 7 pm. This is the perfect place to start an evening of fun. Oh and do bring your own hand wipes or tissues for cleaning your hands. Or you could buy it from the old man and lady that walks around and sells them.

text: I have to disagree with the folks here and give it 5 stars. This is possibly because I live in Arizona and am STARVED for good Asian food. There is stall after stall after stall after stall after stall of Chinese, Korean, Japanese, Indian food. Additionally they have stands offering fresh squeezed juice, and there are also ample opportunities to grab a soda or even a Tiger Beer.<br><br>On my last visit I had an overnight on my way back from Bali. So after checking in at my hotel and cleaning up, I came straight to Lau Pa Sat. I think I went back for Shrimp Dumplings three times, I was like a meth-head. So much so that by the third time the stern little Chinese lady cracked a smile at my zeal. On my most recent night here, the requisite Filipino cover band played a Whitney Houston tribute followed by some ABBA and other late 70s/early 80s tunes.   <br><br>La Pau Sat is a must in my opinion whilst in Singapore. Granted in Singapore you&#39;d probably be hard pressed to find a BAD meal, but for a lowly Yank like me, I love the one stop shop approach here.  It&#39;s like South Coast Plaza for Asian Food.<br><br>So do yourself a favor and come here with between $20 and $30 and an empty stomach and let loose!

text: I love night markets and well executed &#34;street food&#34; so Lau Pa Sat was right up my alley. I was on a business trip and luckily my hotel was around the corner from the market. I can&#39;t remember the name of all the vendors I ate from, but I didn&#39;t have one bad meal. Always open, super convenient.

text: Also known as Telok Ayer Market, this hawker centre (aka food court) is remarkably clean, has plenty of food and fruit/dessert options, indoor &amp; outdoor seating, and a beer stand. I read online that there would be people selling napkins, but I never saw them, and they don&#39;t have napkins in the open, so maybe bring your own? Also, make sure to bring cash because they do not take credit cards.<br><br>I chose to try the Thunder Tea Rice, per a suggestion from my colleague (a local). I ordered the Thunder Tea Rice Special with chicken patty. The dish was $8.50S (Singaporean dollars) and was pretty big (not humongous but more than enough food). It came with a bowl of tea on the side that you put into your rice. The flavors were very interesting (there are a number of toppings on the rice, including peanuts and dried anchovies) and definitely something I&#39;ve never had before. The chicken patties were delicious, with a hint of sweet to the salty savory taste.<br><br>I also stopped by a cut fruit/dessert place and got the mango sago for $2.70S. It is a bowl of shaved ice with condensed milk, cubes of mango, and these colorful little balls of, maybe, tapioca? Quite a sweet and refreshing way to end my meal. If you want to carry away, make sure to let them know, otherwise it will come in a plastic bowl.<br><br>Other options include Korean food, Costa Rican food, satay, Chinese food, bakery, beer, Cambodian, and others.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=DgQQh4VqBG-9zQhc776a2g', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/8tolnerArzGvMr7pKZ0upg/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/8tolnerArzGvMr7pKZ0upg/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/8tolnerArzGvMr7pKZ0upg/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/8tolnerArzGvMr7pKZ0upg/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/8tolnerArzGvMr7pKZ0upg/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/8tolnerArzGvMr7pKZ0upg/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Michael L.', 'displayLocation': 'Peachtree Corners, GA', 'altText': 'Michael L.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=DgQQh4VqBG-9zQhc776a2g', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 470, 'photoCount': 166, 'reviewCount': 739, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Just came here for a late night bowl of laksa (Prawn Noodle- Stall 10 259). My appetite was satisfied, but I wasn&#39;t necessarily blown away by it. <br><br>Hope to come back here to try other food stalls!

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=QpfNGJ9G6SLeHtGrejyiig', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/jlkYDaKBkW1JMTCT9dgwYQ/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/jlkYDaKBkW1JMTCT9dgwYQ/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/jlkYDaKBkW1JMTCT9dgwYQ/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/jlkYDaKBkW1JMTCT9dgwYQ/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/jlkYDaKBkW1JMTCT9dgwYQ/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/jlkYDaKBkW1JMTCT9dgwYQ/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Janet M.', 'displayLocation': 'Ann Arbor, MI', 'altText': 'Janet M.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=QpfNGJ9G6SLeHtGrejyiig', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 184, 'photoCount': 158, 'reviewCount': 119, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Had really good roti paratha here. Not sure of the name of the hawker. The curries that came with the paratha were all delicious. <br><br>Satay from stall 8 was pretty good, nothing to write home about, not sure what the hype is. Lady there tried to up-sell by giving me a more expensive menu with bigger sets..ask for smaller set menu if you don&#39;t want to eat 30 sticks of satay. <br><br>Def try the fish ball soup here. By far one of the best soups I had while in Singapore. <br><br>Laksa was alright as well.

We absolutely loved Lau Pa Sat... it&#39;s a hawker centre, so don&#39;t expect frills, and has been refurbed...<br><br>The food is simply amazing here - you can pretty much get whatever you want...  we opted for Indian Vegeterian, some fresh juices and some amazing pastries...<br><br>Three Ganga&#39;s Onion Rava Masala Dosa is absolutely delicious! :-)<br><br>All fabulous - highly recommended... ignore the drivel that people have posted saying it&#39;s a tourist trap - whilst it is becoming more touristy, we wouldn&#39;t go as far as to say to avoid it and it&#39;s a tourist trap... you will love it...

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/aAU0hBT4eqsdFgCo0KFHHg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=Zclij09E_3s2FxnjAtgUFA&select=aAU0hBT4eqsdFgCo0KFHHg', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore. Indonesian food', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Indonesian food'}]
text: This is a great place.  Street food, but without the cramped and smelly atmosphere oaf underground food courts. I really loved the Indonesian food, but many other options that did look just as good.<br><br>Beautiful outdoor setting under a historic cast iron roof makes it a nice place to even stay for an extensive evening meal.

text: Five stars for the best satay I&#39;ve ever had, the price, the super casual and relaxing atmosphere, and the amazing view of Singapore skyline. The option to choose the number of satay sticks allows you to eat based on your appetite for that night. Stall #8 and stall #4 pretty much have the same type and quality of meat. However, I liked #4 better because of the spicy sauce.

The taxi driver recommended this hawker center to us and I totally loved it! The later you get here, the more crowded it gets. At around 9PM, there are tons of skewers stands outside and the delicious smell just drifts throughout the street. Too bad I cannot try everything since all of the food look so good. This is a must go to place if you visit Singapore. Don&#39;t forget to get the freshly crushed sugar cane juice, it is delicious and refreshing.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Gsu8TjkXUrO1WaYS_XKtxA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=8gXvNnCS2LfHNDwLZ1_nSg&select=Gsu8TjkXUrO1WaYS_XKtxA', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/eJUbwVLsY8d0LDMOGJ_BYA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=8gXvNnCS2LfHNDwLZ1_nSg&select=eJUbwVLsY8d0LDMOGJ_BYA', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/kFg969RLY44x8Jj6Ga4o2A/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=8gXvNnCS2LfHNDwLZ1_nSg&select=kFg969RLY44x8Jj6Ga4o2A', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: Lau Pa Sat is one of the places I can never leave Singapore without visiting. Well known for its satay and hawker type eateries, you can find plenty of traditional local food and it will be hard to choose what to have! This time around I had chicken hor fun, a pork bun (which hubby said was the best he&#39;d ever eaten) and a shark fin dumpling. Loved loved loved my chicken hor fun. <br>We then ventured outside for satay and prawns, and managed to negotiate for only a 5 sticks instead of the minimum 10 since we were already full from noodles and dumplings. It was the first time hubby had been and he loved the atmosphere there, and enjoyed the food there more so than the food courts we&#39;d been to on touristy Orchard Rd.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/OcpmIk2uwnLjo5ZbzIiiHw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=g_F9WJJpRFB40oPJdoD2uA&select=OcpmIk2uwnLjo5ZbzIiiHw', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/IuuGNA59XtKsxC7J0K3PIw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=g_F9WJJpRFB40oPJdoD2uA&select=IuuGNA59XtKsxC7J0K3PIw', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: Lau Pa Sat is one of the Singapore&#39;s attraction that is worth your while to visit when you are in town.<br><br>It is used to be call Telok ayer Market. I found the most interesting element of the structure itself is the architecture design: octagonal, cast-iron structure was shipped out from Glasgow back in the 1894. The design is very Victorian<br><br>Next time when you visit Lau Pat Sat, while you chowing down food from the numerous food stalls, just look up at the ceiling and take a moment to admire this wonderful work of design...<br><br>A little piece history of Singapore!<br><br>Tips: don&#39;t come looking for food in the middle of the night..as a lot of the food stalls are closed....

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=kszt8vOPh4xos8OtOqmr5Q', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/tmyoWoJ_Lde0TKkO65eBCA/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/tmyoWoJ_Lde0TKkO65eBCA/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/tmyoWoJ_Lde0TKkO65eBCA/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/tmyoWoJ_Lde0TKkO65eBCA/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/tmyoWoJ_Lde0TKkO65eBCA/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/tmyoWoJ_Lde0TKkO65eBCA/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Maria T.', 'displayLocation': 'Tanglin, Singapore, Singapore', 'altText': 'Maria T.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=kszt8vOPh4xos8OtOqmr5Q', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 61, 'photoCount': 153, 'reviewCount': 59, 'eliteYear': None}
photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/I5aOwKhJcoRbYmR4BZyWig/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=Dh6kB451xGb4__8r7KEmvQ&select=I5aOwKhJcoRbYmR4BZyWig', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore. Sashimi bowl (S$8.90) from Japanese Yakitori &amp; Teppan Azmaya stall at lau pa sat', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Sashimi bowl (S$8.90) from Japanese Yakitori & Teppan Azmaya stall at lau pa sat'}]
text: When I went here a couple of times in May-June, the free wifi worked just fine. But I went there again yesterday (in July) I found that the wifi no longer works.<br><br>Regardless I&#39;d still very much recommend lau pa sat as a place to bring your tourist friends here. Lots of options for local food. The seating area in lau pa sat is clean, and there&#39;s an interesting history behind this octagonal structure building. Not to mention, location wise it&#39;s very strategic. There are 3 MRT stations nearby (downtown station, telok ayer station, and raffles place station). <br><br>I also love stopping by at some cafes along telok ayer street afterwards just to chill :)<br><br>My favorite at lau pa sat is still the japanese yakitori &amp; teppan azmaya stall by the satay place. Try their sashimi bowl for S$8.90 and you&#39;d get what I mean. I know I know that it&#39;s not truly a Singaporean local food, but seriously, I don&#39;t think you would be able to get such standard for sashimi bowl at a price below S$10 anywhere else in Singapore..

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=je2yT6SLxPKfMjwf_OPNCw', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/_Y_uMQ0gc3CgI47tkMN92A/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/_Y_uMQ0gc3CgI47tkMN92A/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/_Y_uMQ0gc3CgI47tkMN92A/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/_Y_uMQ0gc3CgI47tkMN92A/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/_Y_uMQ0gc3CgI47tkMN92A/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/_Y_uMQ0gc3CgI47tkMN92A/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Nel S.', 'displayLocation': 'Downtown, Los Angeles, CA', 'altText': 'Nel S.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=je2yT6SLxPKfMjwf_OPNCw', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 5, 'eliteYear': None}
text: It was our first time. Walked here after a very tiring day. What a disappointing way to end the day. We were greeted by a woman who spoke Pilipino who presented us with a menu. Being overwhelmed by her and since my husband and I were exhausted and hungry we went with what she offered. Yang chow fried rice, crispy Baby squid, chicken satay and one chili crab. The food was good. However, it cost us S$77. Not that we don&#39;t pay that price for a decent meal but with the ambiance, the plastic spoon and fork, and open table, I think it was a lot to pay. Also, after we were served, the woman disappeared and never even offered or show us where to buy water and soda. <br>One time experience is enough for this place.

This place is my jam, no lie.  It&#39;s my favorite hawker center for a few reasons.  <br><br>One, it&#39;s close to my house, and waking distance to my office.  Two, is is clean AF.  Three, the amount and variety of food here is ridiculous.  <br><br>I visit at least 2X a week, and have sampled quite a bit of the stuff.  The BBQ seafood place is pretty good with a chili crab that made fire come out of my ears.  There&#39;s a dim sum place that I can&#39;t seem to stay away from.  The scallop and prawn dumplings, I could eat 123 of those little babies.  The Indian places I have tried I wan&#39;t super impressed with.  Congee place is legit, and some of the Ramen I&#39;ve had is really good.  The only place I didn&#39;t like was the cold dessert stand in the middle.  There is a chick there that hates her life, and sneers at me every time I try and get a lychee slushie.  Seriously, she is R-ude.  The beer stand ($5) rounds things out for me, with plenty of outdoor seating and people watching.  Oh bring napkins, and tissues to save yourself a seat.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/9SYvldXLZz-qx3YDicFQ4w/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/lau-pa-sat-singapore-2?reviewid=vIRltHx9pylvSYM7hNSYTA&select=9SYvldXLZz-qx3YDicFQ4w', 'altText': 'Photo of Lau Pa Sat - Singapore, Singapore. Laksa', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Laksa'}]
text: A lot of good food options and cheap eats. I really liked the idea of it and was looking forward to eating a lot of good food during my layover in Singapore. When we arrived, however, it was off-set by the fact that it didn&#39;t have any aircon... This is, of course, something I am already aware of before heading to Lau Pa Sat. However, I underestimated the heat. With Singapore being super humid and hot during the summer, it was miserable having laksa in the sweltering heat. Otherwise, I believe this would be a great place during the evening. The food was good. I really enjoyed it. I did get food poisoning afterwards, but not sure if it was from here. I would come back, but not in the summer. I will be searching for a place with aircon in the summer.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=tqoZpEebw8REQQGTXHqdVg', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/LqV_LHb8iSO1sN7o7kK8hQ/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/LqV_LHb8iSO1sN7o7kK8hQ/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/LqV_LHb8iSO1sN7o7kK8hQ/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/LqV_LHb8iSO1sN7o7kK8hQ/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/LqV_LHb8iSO1sN7o7kK8hQ/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/LqV_LHb8iSO1sN7o7kK8hQ/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Jim T.', 'displayLocation': 'Hilversum, The Netherlands', 'altText': 'Jim T.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=tqoZpEebw8REQQGTXHqdVg', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': 19, 'reviewCount': 27, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Honestly, if I wasn&#39;t trying to connect with friends living in Singapore, I&#39;d have gone to Maxwell or one of the other hawker centers - it&#39;s seriously far too touristy now. We sat out in front, amid all the saté vendors, and it was quite difficult to have a conversation without people constantly pushing in to sell us something (generally, wet-naps). Combined with the half-overcooked saté, the inability to get a beer without having to almost physically grab a waitress, and the waves of wet-nap shillers -- yeah, it&#39;s not worth it anymore. Tourism has killed this place...choose better.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=lPg2eOUYOw2z-OpiQtRxzA', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/6R3MB9KN0w6wHeDMRebJRw/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/6R3MB9KN0w6wHeDMRebJRw/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/6R3MB9KN0w6wHeDMRebJRw/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/6R3MB9KN0w6wHeDMRebJRw/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/6R3MB9KN0w6wHeDMRebJRw/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/6R3MB9KN0w6wHeDMRebJRw/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Min S.', 'displayLocation': 'Notre Dame, IN', 'altText': 'Min S.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=lPg2eOUYOw2z-OpiQtRxzA', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 31, 'photoCount': 10, 'reviewCount': 6, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Tried all kinds of food, laksa, char kway teow, bak kut teh...<br>The food there is cheap but every time I spent like S$10 to take a uber to get there lol.<br>By the way, there are a lot of stalls set up in the evening. They serve fried chicken and beef and lamb meat. The sauce is more sweet than spicy. And these are expensive, about S$40 for a small set.

Great hawker center right in the middle of CBD. Always crowded, especially during lunch but hey, go join in a shared table and chat with your fellow mates. Huge variety of stalls so you will be spoilt for choice.

Excellent place to bring out of town guests or meet friends for a beer. It&#39;s cash only and they do have ATM&#39;s but the lines are typically long. Wide variety of food options and most of the food moves quickly, no heat lamp leftovers.

There are a bunch of food here but I&#39;m just here for the satay skewers soo.. <br><br>First of all, DO NOT FOLLOW the annoying sales person from the &#34;other&#34; satay stands besides the red shirt stall 7 &amp; 8.  There will be ppl around the area trying to pull u to their stall because the &#34;best satay&#34; don&#39;t need that type of pressure to have ppl eat there.  They have a simple set with shrimp, beef, chicken and mutton satay skewers.   The different sets are just varies quantities of the skewers.  Hands down best i had and highly recommend everyone who travels to singapore to try this place.

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=h8pthOnqCxV94D8-JkZXCQ', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/9-m-EhdG_epGP_iC1VRgHw/60s.jpg', 'srcSet': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/9-m-EhdG_epGP_iC1VRgHw/ms.jpg 1.67x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/9-m-EhdG_epGP_iC1VRgHw/120s.jpg 2.00x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/9-m-EhdG_epGP_iC1VRgHw/90s.jpg 1.50x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/9-m-EhdG_epGP_iC1VRgHw/168s.jpg 2.80x,https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/photo/9-m-EhdG_epGP_iC1VRgHw/180s.jpg 3.00x', 'markupDisplayName': 'Cecilia S.', 'displayLocation': 'San Diego, CA', 'altText': 'Cecilia S.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=h8pthOnqCxV94D8-JkZXCQ', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 1055, 'photoCount': 785, 'reviewCount': 793, 'eliteYear': None}
text: I&#39;ve heard so many good things about this hawker centre, but unfortunately I was highly disappointed.  It&#39;s a very large hawker center and the choices appear endless.  Skewers seem to be the number one seller - I&#39;m talking a tray of 50-60 skewers with shrimp, chicken, beef, lamb, and pork (if you go to the Chinese sellers).  It looked amazing, but I was really irritated by people trying to sell us their food or to go to their stall.  I enjoy perusing for what to eat in peace and not rushed, thank you.  <br><br>Also, as a Westerner, I expect certain things when I eat - like napkins and a clean eating space.  Nope, they don&#39;t exist.  Once you order your food, they are gone and they won&#39;t look twice at you again.  <br><br>Tables aren&#39;t the cleanest.  Eh, I don&#39;t think I&#39;ll be coming back.
