Upstairs area', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Upstairs area'}]
text: People love taking selfies AND drinking coffee so why not put the two together? And so Selfie Coffee was born!<br><br>Located on Haji Lane, Selfie Coffee definitely fits the hipster bill of the area - besides the hashtag in the name, the cute nature-print theme of the outside continues inside and upstairs where there are many spots for photo opportunities and that perfect Instagram pic. Surprisingly when we came on a Saturday morning there were no other customers so we had the top level and our choice of the upstairs seating to ourselves. <br><br>While they offer both hot and cold drinks as well as desserts, the main attraction is the selfie coffee. You can only do the selfie coffee with the cold drinks, so we went for a basic iced Americano. They have you use a provided phone to take a selfie on the spot to print onto your drink, then give you a buzzer so you can wait outside or upstairs. <br><br>When it was ready (voila!), our photo was presented on top of a thick layer of foam/cream...until we poked our straws through our faces, that is! It&#39;s a cool concept and a fun thing to try with friends or your significant other. The coffee was also not bad. Good for the novelty and the selfie aspect definitely draws you in, but for the price, a return visit is probably not necessary (especially since the woman who served us was not particularly friendly either...).

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/5wxxFs-XlxxUxxvWa4YX8g/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/selfie-coffee-singapore?reviewid=g1KwDKFDUsRe3-9G4eCtMA&select=5wxxFs-XlxxUxxvWa4YX8g', 'altText': 'Photo of Selfie Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': None}]
text: Selfie Coffee is a fun idea but financially, it&#39;s not doable for an everyday pick-me-up. The coffees are expensive but they&#39;re delicious. The photos come out well. The staff are a bit unfriendly and messed up my order of two coffees with different photos and instead used both of the same photo. Other than that, this is a great one time spot for tourists.

Came across this cute cafe at Haji lane. It is cozy, upbeat, and very touristy! They have amazinggg coffees and cakes. Loved, loved, loved their selfie coffee concept. Definitely an instagrammable place. So the process is pretty straight forward: You place an order, take your selfie and they brew your coffee with your face on it :D <br><br>As you climb the stairs, you will find more seating and also the wall art is pretty cute. Washrooms are located upstairs as well. Little disappointed as they had no hand soap and toilet roll. Whats up with that?  :O<br><br>I liked the service, mainly because they were patient as I kept doing re-takes of my selfie. They handle each customer patiently and professionally (at least in non crowded situation). Must try! But can&#39;t afford to get coffee regularly :)

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/tnz7vu-dtmJh2E9XmQLzjA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/selfie-coffee-singapore?reviewid=cLT2-_cI_CJGkgfR_NuWIA&select=tnz7vu-dtmJh2E9XmQLzjA', 'altText': 'Photo of Selfie Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/hSgOIKLzQSxU6B4tB2V7BA/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/selfie-coffee-singapore?reviewid=cLT2-_cI_CJGkgfR_NuWIA&select=hSgOIKLzQSxU6B4tB2V7BA', 'altText': 'Photo of Selfie Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/iPgZ_oQsobq9ttOAHBDhuQ/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/selfie-coffee-singapore?reviewid=cLT2-_cI_CJGkgfR_NuWIA&select=iPgZ_oQsobq9ttOAHBDhuQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Selfie Coffee - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': None}]
text: Most fun coffee shop in the world!  There are obviously less expensive more tasty coffee options around but where else can you drink your face off?  Literally. <br><br>You go in, pay 5-7 bucks, order a Cold Coffee (hot doesn&#39;t work so they warn you), then you take a selfie.  The outcome is your selfie in the actual drink!  Not on some plastic lid but actually in your coffee.  What voodoo is this?  The coffee itself was just ok. I&#39;ve had coffee all over the world so I&#39;m a bougie snob but who knew my face would taste so damn just Ok!  <br><br>One of those places in the world you must come once, take a picture/video, lick your face, then call it a day.  <br><br>Tip: Please don&#39;t BATHE in cologne or perfume.  Seating is very limited, cramped, and itimate.  Don&#39;t be that guy who smells and over compensates with scented oils or whatever the heck that was.

Nice enough place.  I was gonna give this place a &#34;3&#34; for the location and the coffee.  However, one incident changed all that.  First, the bathroom stinks to high heaven.  And second, when I mentioned that there was no paper and toilet paper in the bathroom to the male employee; he just shrugged his shoulder and pretended that he didn&#39;t hear what I said.  Really disappointing.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/nOnNXC7rWVD9EbEyDNCjpQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/selfie-coffee-singapore?reviewid=geglcvm_I-Rl9u5Rph2qZA&select=nOnNXC7rWVD9EbEyDNCjpQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Selfie Coffee - Singapore, Singapore. Get a Polaroid of your selfie printed out for an additional $1.50!', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Get a Polaroid of your selfie printed out for an additional $1.50!'}]
text: Coffee? Good by my standards, although the layer of foam was a little thick for me.<br><br>Ambience? Great! Love the picture frames and forest theme on the second floor. Remember that they do not have toilet paper or soap in the restroom so be prepared with some sanitizer!<br><br>Price? Little pricey at around $10 per item, but they include the picture printed on your coffee &amp; compared to American branded coffee sold in Singapore (Starbucks, Peets) it seemed pretty reasonable.<br><br>Location? Cool alleyway, a little difficult to find the place unless you&#39;re actively looking for it though.<br><br>Overall? I thought it was great, but really a one time thing. Nothing really calls me to return unless one of my friends wants to try it. Super cool idea though &amp; I&#39;ll be sure to tell my friends to visit if they&#39;re ever in town!

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/NoZq20nTAjLmYZdrrm5Ogg/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/selfie-coffee-singapore?reviewid=EUkum_RTef5RaAYay1HfVQ&select=NoZq20nTAjLmYZdrrm5Ogg', 'altText': 'Photo of Selfie Coffee - Singapore, Singapore. Me and Miguel M&#39;s #selfie coffee', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': "Me and Miguel M's #selfie coffee"}]
text: Yes, this is a thing.<br><br>We now live in a world where you can take a selife, have it printed on coffee foam and presented to you in about 10 minutes or so. And yes, the selfie foam is edible! I have no idea how they do it, but it never fails to impress me. I&#39;ve only had the iced/frappe styles, but each time I thought they tasted pretty good.<br><br>However, I have to deduct 2 stars because of their bathroom situation. I noticed there was no toilet paper left so I went down and alerted them, only for the employee to say: &#34;Oh, we don&#39;t supply toilet paper.&#34;<br><br>So... you&#39;re not going to even try to remedy the situation? I just found it a bit odd, considering they charge over $8 for these coffees, they&#39;re running their AC at a comfortable temperature, and they probably pay heaps of rent as they&#39;re on popular Haji Lane. There are no excuses for not having toilet paper on the premises.<br><br>Thank goodness for 7-Eleven next door, which had tissues I could buy. Because when you desperately have to take the Browns to the Super Bowl, you&#39;ll do whatever it takes! (Yes, I went there.)
Very creative and fun selfie-on-coffee concept! The upstairs zoo theme is unique too. Only suggestion would be to open the windows/shutters upstairs for natural light.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Dun1C-zPTaXuKOXyrk5r_A/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/selfie-coffee-singapore?reviewid=NBxRiPwruzzBwH6Qbe6C5g&select=Dun1C-zPTaXuKOXyrk5r_A', 'altText': 'Photo of Selfie Coffee - Singapore, Singapore. I pierced my nose', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'I pierced my nose'}]
text: Gimmicky!!! But perfect for selfie whores, I mean, fanatics! <br><br>At $8, you can have your selfie &#39;imprinted&#39; onto your coffee. Yup. That&#39;s right. It&#39;s organic and safe and void of coloring, they claim. And you know what, mine was an iced signature coffee (without sugar syrup upon my request), the coffee wasn&#39;t half bad. Rather good actually!! <br><br>I genuinely poking a straw through my face (nose to be more exact) and sipping the coffee, and watching my selfie sink and warp in my cup. Hahahahaha!<br><br>Novelty but at least the coffee was better than Starbucks!

text: Gorgeous coffee!!! Worth the stop for tourism sake, but the coffee is just okay. Super fast and really cool photos, though!!

text: Simple and cool while in Singapore. Take a picture, have it printed on top of your latte, and then drink your selfie.

text: Hot and cold drinks, desserts and savory pies. A bit expensive and slow to make on the &#34;selfies&#34; drinks but fun! Drinks with selfies on the surface of your drink, what a concept.

A very cute two story café with a nice ambience. First of all, why people come here? To have their face printed on a drink. I must admit I&#39;m one of them. But it is a very unique experience that ill remember- drinking myself. I ordered a honey milk which is nice! ( I like honey and milk) <br>The most unique drink experience ever (But quite a one time experience for me)<br>If you have not been there before, I recommend trying it for yourself!!!<br>Honey milk- 7/10

How cool is this??? How awesome to see your selfie picture on top of a cup of coffee? I absolutely love this shop. Too awesome and cute to miss when visiting Singapore. This shop is located on a long street full of bars and souvenir shops. There is so much to see here. The walls on the building has lots of cool graffiti artworks to take pictures too. This shop is very small but it have two floors. A must stop for all tourists when visiting in Singapore.

text: Short for Watanabe Cafe. A Japanese Cafe. Great service! Was attended to by Mr Gopi within 5 minutes of sitting at our table, even though they were short of staff on a Sunday afternoon. They worked fast and efficient. <br><br>The coffee came quick but we were warned by Mr Gopi that the parfait could take up to 15 minutes of waiting. With the free and strong wifi, we waited. It was a treat when it came. Good things come for those who wait. <br><br>If you wanna drop by after a day of shopping, I recommend this joint for its ambience, desserts.

Neapolitan pasta', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Neapolitan pasta'}]
text: Decided to drop by here and dine with a friend on a Sunday night at around 5.30pm. I arrived here around 3.30pm and it was not too crowded at that time hence I managed to get a good seating with a better lighting.<br><br>Since I was there early, decided to get some munchies - fries with truffle salts and melon soda float. For the fries, they were thin cuts and it was crispy on the sides. The truffle salts were a little salty for my liking. For the melon soda float, it was extremely better than expected. I was expecting it to be diluted with ice but surprisingly it was not. Before ordering, I was debating whether to get melon soda or ramune and I am glad I went with the &#34;crowd favorite&#34;. The ice cream melted nicely on the glass of green colored liquid. You could either eat the ice cream on its own or stir it up with the melon soda. I tried both methods and it was amazing. <br><br>Before coming here, I was eyeing on the Omu Rice (rice dish with omelette on top) or the Neapolitan Pasta. My friend decided to get the Omu Rice and I ordered the pasta. The dishes came in less than 10 minutes of preparation. For the pasta, I was not fond of the ingredients and the tomato sauce. I&#39;ll probably try the cream pasta option another time. My friend enjoyed her dish and commented that she made a good choice in ordering.<br><br>Service was pretty fast here and the prices are pretty reasonable. This store is located near to the Downtown Line of the Chinatown MRT station, pretty easy to spot as it is located opposite Uniqlo. Will try out their Tonkatsu and different kind of pasta soon.

text: I used to hang out at China Town Point from time to time since it&#39;s quite close to where I live and there is a Wa Cafe in the basement.  I quite like how this cafe looks - very dark wood that reminds me of a typical japanese cafe.  The menu is also typical of a Japanese cafe - pasta, curry rice and rice wrapped in an omlette.  I do like their pasta and on my last visit they were doing some promotion on dried oysters from Japan so I tried the creamy pasta with dried oyster and it was delicious.  In the past, I have only had dried oysters in Chinese dish but turns out that it goes quite nicely with pasta in a cream based sauce.  The other thing I really liked about Wa Cafe is their cakes, you will like them if you like Japanese style cakes - light and fluffly and not so sweet.  Their coffee is pretty decent too.  If you find yourself in China Town Point, it&#39;s a nice alternative to all the other Chinese food options.<br><br>One additional observation - they recently offered this hokkaido milk soft ice cream in a waffle cone (think they also offer green tea ice cream).  I tried one at their Orchard branch, it&#39;s disappointing. The ice cream started melting the moment I was handed the cone, somehow the ice cream was very watery and didn&#39;t feel creamy at all - where&#39;s the hokkaido milk??  It&#39;s not cheap either so really, don&#39;t bother.

text: This row of shophouses is balestier is pretty well-known for being home to the various &#34;best tau sar piahs&#34; in Singapore. I have tried all the tau sar piahs in this row of shophouses and have concluded that Loong Fatt Tau Sar Piah is my favourite. <br><br>The tau sar piahs they sell are made fresh in house everyday. One is greeted with the amazing smell of freshly baked pastries upon entering the shop and i often catch a glimpse of the family in the back, rolling out the pastry dough. I like the way the shop takes you back in time with its traditional ways.<br><br>The tau sar piah from this stall is extremely aromatic. The smell of the tau sar is simply alluring. The pastry has a nice bite, yet it crumbles and seems to melt away in my mouth. It is pretty cheap at 60cents a piece too.

text: The place was well known for its Tau Sar Piah but it also offers other old school cake items such as Custard Puff, Butter Cake, and Banana Cake.<br>Love the butter cake which was very buttery and moist.

text: When my friends brought in a box of these, the first thing someone commented, &#34;Wah! You braved the queue ah?!&#34; Apparently infamous for their tau sar piah is this traditional old school shop at balestier!<br><br>Even though they were 4 hours old, they were still flaky, as you can see all the flaky bits at the bottom of the box. I have never been a fan of these sweet snacks but now I am! <br><br>As you bite in, you feel like you are biting into a char Siew soh! It is so flaky yet crispy! And inside is the sweet paste! And it is not too sweet that would make you feel heaty either! It is perfect! I will need to get my hands on another dozen of these sweet treat! Anyone young or old would love these!

Poster of the fat dragon eating house', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Poster of the fat dragon eating house'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/719lHT2HZZxHW08ITx-u-Q/180s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/loong-fatt-tau-sar-piah-singapore?reviewid=Jx2dVBGvayVWY8Sx5Acxow&select=719lHT2HZZxHW08ITx-u-Q', 'altText': 'Photo of Loong Fatt Tau Sar Piah - Singapore, Singapore. The line goes along one side of the coffee shop.', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'The line goes along one side of the coffee shop.'}]
text: Located at the corner of the whole row of shophouses in balestier, Loong Fatt Tau Sar Piah sure sells great, flaky and tasty tau sar piahs. This shop has an open concept kitchen, thus you can see the bakers hand-making those fresh pastries and be greeted with the delicious smell of them. The filling is not too sweet nor salty, hence appealing to the tastebuds of everyone in the family.<br>The ventilation is better than other old, traditional shops and the fans are quite strong, so the place is not very stuffy. Although the queue took about an hour or so, the wait was definitely worthwhile. Plus, there are many seats in the shop, so if you patronize the shop in a group, you may take turns to queue up and sit down to take a sip of coffee. <br>The price of each tau sar piah is reasonable, at 70 cents each. If you buy 5 to 6 tau sar piahs, you will get a small box. The bigger box holds up to 10. If you buy less than 5, they will put them in a plastic bag. Both sweet and salty are good, but the pastry is what makes it excellent. Thumbs up for their effort!

My grandmother has a soft spot for these little flaky pastries so I would always traipse my way down to grab a couple of boxes once in a while. You probably wouldn&#39;t have any difficulty spotting this shop from afar - the shopfront has two signboards stacked upon each other screaming the exact same message, seemingly afraid nobody would see that there is some seriously good piah up for grabs. <br><br>There are two standard flavours: salty and sweet. I must admit that I always return to the store a tad confused about my preference - probably because both are pretty similar. You can differentiate visually between the two by the sesame seeds sprinkled atop the sweet piahs that distinguish them from the salty ones. Perhaps my taste-buds have not made much of a progression since I was younger, but I am still insistent that the salty piahs taste pretty much the same as the sweet piahs with the identical flavour differing only by a slight hint of saltiness coming through. Whatever it is, light feathery layers of pastry encasing slightly chewy bean paste makes the perfect accompaniment to a cup of tea in the afternoon. The Singaporean version of scones, perhaps?

text: have you gotten your shots yet?<br><br>the worldwide pandemic has dragged on way too long.<br>so, we all need some shots! <br><br>have you gotten your first shot even?<br><br>talks of it becoming an endemic but with constant flip flops. <br>so, we all need double shots! <br><br>have you gotten your second shot? <br><br>the ever changing variants, ever changing lockdown rules! <br><br>so, maybe we&#39;ll need yet another additional shot!? <br><br>this is a great place for me to get away from the crowd in a remote corner of the CBD. <br>where I can get single origins in default double shots! <br>no real cheap parking options, so the best mode of transport might well be to bike, bus and/or walk. <br>but a great crew awaits, ever ready and friendly, to pull your shots. <br>a simple hole in the wall with no indoors seating whatsoever. <br>just chill outdoors on makeshift kungfu wooden benches, friendly for your shots with dogs. <br><br>so, this is a public service announcement, don&#39;t wait, delay no more, go get your shots! :)

text: Great variety of fusion food<br><br>Beef rice - 5/5 quality of meat is great and sauce tastes good<br><br>Soy sweet potato fries- 4/5: sauce a little too sweet for me<br><br>Chicken rice risotto 4/5 - The combination is divine... but sadly, I personally can&#39;t take a lot of diary/creamy food, so I wouldn&#39;t order an entire dish for myself.<br><br>Lemongrass chamomile 1/5 - very sweet.. reminds me of Apple tea, I was expecting something a little lighter and less sweet from the name

text: Hipster cafe, great for Instagram-ready fusion--style brunches, as well as cosy date nights. I went there on a Saturday night after 8pm and there was plenty of seats. You order at the main counter, serve yourself water and cutlery, and they bring your food to you. <br><br>We had the mentaiko salmon pasta, the salmon pho and the salted egg mochi w ice cream. For the price, portions of the mains aren&#39;t particularly large, but maybe the restaurant&#39;s strategy is to leave room for dessert! <br><br>The mentaiko salmon pasta was done perfectly. Al dente pasta, al dente salmon and creamy mentaiko. Mmm mmm mmm! The salmon pho, is a completely different dish. The broth and noodles are delicate, but the salmon was a tad overdone. Otherwise, it&#39;s a really nice dish. The salted egg mochi was ah-mazing! I dont know if any other restaurants do it, but it&#39;s definitley a heart stopper. They also give 3 mochis, so be prepared to fight if sharing between an even number of people!

Classic Honey Toast', 'width': 180, 'height': 180, 'caption': 'Classic Honey Toast'}]
text: A cafe located along Bali Lane, with 2 levels for dining in. The place is dim in lighting and popular with the younger generation. It is known for its thick toast and waffle.<br><br>Classic Honey Toast ($12.90)<br>butter &amp; honey baked pain de mie, honey yogurt ice-cream, berries<br>The thick toast is served thick and crispy. Just nice with the honey and ice-cream. The sour taste of the berries is balanced by the sweet honey and ice cream. Overall not bad except for the raspberry which tastes frozen.<br><br>Blackcurrent Lemonade ($4.90)<br>It looks quite cloudy when served. When fully mixed, I could not taste the lemonade in the drink. It tastes more like a soda drink. None of the grape flavour too.<br><br>Overall not bad. The place is a bit dim in lighting, so difficult to take photos even when sitting by the window.

text: - Cute, modern style cafe. <br>- A few items on the menu weren&#39;t seasonal, but weren&#39;t available. <br>- The Staff seemed like they didn&#39;t care, we had to go to the front desk to ask any time wanted something. And the whole staff was eating while we were eating. This should have been done prior to opening. <br>- 2nd floor didn&#39;t open up until 2nd floor was full. <br>- 1 bathroom available. <br>- Don&#39;t sit below the flowers where the fan blows. We were constantly getting flowers blown in our drinks.

Red velvet waffle', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Red velvet waffle'}]
text: Love the feel of this cafe. It one of those cafes that gives you Brooklyn-feels, those that everyone thinks the Haji lane area is all about. If you want to get a nicely coloured shot for Instagram, you&#39;ll want to sit outside. <br><br>Today was my second time here, and both times I got their red velvet waffles.<br>During my first time there though while trying to order a latte, they reportedly ran out of coffee beans ... which was a little appalling to me. But anyway the waffle saved the day.<br><br>Personally I felt like the waffle deserved a thumbs up for being nicely crisp, though to be honest i couldn&#39;t exactly tell it was a &#34;red-velvet&#34; one by its taste. Pleasantly decorated with mini meringues, frozen raspberries and dollops of cream cheese (on my first time it was generously drizzled across the waffle instead - i think what you get depends on the chef), this is an interesting first. <br><br>Only thing though, it&#39;s pretty pricey at 14.90 for a waffle with ice cream.

text: Given what I went through to get Sunday brunch in Kampong Glam, Stateland deserves 5 stars.<br><br>Initially, hubby and I went to Maison Ikkoku, but they were already fully booked by 10 AM. Trusty Yelp app pointed us to Working Title, where apparently the chef was running late which meant the sole person running the F&amp;B portion was unable to cook breakfast.<br><br>Almost ready to quit and just eat something at Bugis, I decided to give it one more try and check out Stateland.<br><br>Available seating? Yes.<br>Fully functional cafe with chefs eager to cook breakfast-y items at 10:15 AM on Sunday? Yes.<br>Pitchers of water available for water guzzlers like my hubby so the waitstaff won&#39;t be bothered? Yes.<br><br>Migs ordered the French Toast, which was covered in a berry compote of sorts. Looks too sweet in the picture, but trust me, it was perfect. I decided last minute to go the savoury route and had the waffle with the bacon and onion cream sauce. It sounds really weird and looks crazy but it actually turned out being wonderful. The waffle was firm enough to hold the sauce, but not burnt or overcooked. The bacon and cream sauce was balanced out perfectly with the sweet sauteed onions. <br><br>Throw in some decent cappuccinos and brunch near Arab St was saved. Stateland, if you keep this service up, I&#39;ll love you long time.

text: Cool ambiance, ok-only food. <br><br>We stumbled upon Stateland while trying to find the famous Bugis Village. Stateland Cafe presents  a cool, inviting and hipster interior. The pictures of desserts on their menu looked pretty promising so we stepped in to try it out. <br><br>Unfortunately, the pictures looked much better than the way the food tasted. We ordered a watermelon shaved ice dessert and an earl grey donuts with soft serve. The earl grey donuts had a very fragile and light taste to it, and the soft serve also had a light creamy taste that vaguely reminded me of Momofuku milk bar in NYC. The watermelon shaved ice dessert looked smaller in reality compared to its glorious pictures on the menu. But, there was more flavor in it, and tasted like a frozen watermelon smoothie. <br><br>Stateland Cafe&#39;s got the cool vibe. All it has to do is give a little more punch in its food and it&#39;ll provide a much better experience.

Bacon and eggs waffle', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Bacon and eggs waffle'}, {'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/iP-a8K5iDBR-Ttc9H6Xabw/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/stateland-cafe-singapore?reviewid=0YQEFd99ajLZGbegJtHMqw&select=iP-a8K5iDBR-Ttc9H6Xabw', 'altText': 'Photo of Stateland Cafe - Singapore, Singapore. Red velvet waffle', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': 'Red velvet waffle'}]
text: We went to Stateland Cafe yesterday after reading Ladyironchef&#39;s post about the best waffles in Singapore. <br><br>Stateland&#39;s ambience is pretty similar to most of the small &#34;hipster&#34; cafes in Singapore - dim lighting, uncovered ceilings, eclectic decorations that seemed to be randomly put together to give a rustic, simple vibe. <br><br>The menu was more interesting. There were not many things on the menu, but the choices sounded delicious. I was intrigued by the unique waffle flavours and opted for the Red Velvet Waffle. My partner took the Bacon and Eggs Waffle.<br><br>The Red Velvet Waffle looked impressive, with a scoop of vanilla ice cream and raspberries set atop drizzles of cream cheese frosting and dark chocolate sauce on a red waffle base. The first few bites were confusing. I couldn&#39;t recognise the taste at all. The waffle had a yeasty, metallic taste that had me doubting my choice. A few more bites into it helped to ease my concerns as the familiar bitter and savoury taste took over. It helped to combine all components in one bite to fully savour the waffle. It was good, but I would try other things on the menu next time.<br><br>I prefer the Bacon and Eggs Waffle. It had a good, earthy taste that kept me wanting more. The scrambled eggs were fluffy and the onion cream sauce, infused with the smoky bacon aroma, added another dimension to the flavour. Two thumbs up.<br><br>The prices were a little on the high side, though I wouldn&#39;t call them expensive. At $14.90 for a waffle dish, it&#39;s higher than most other waffle places, but the flavours are definitely unique.

Simple yet satisfying menu. The highlight for most will be the mochi balls with surprise runny filling inside, however, the savory items are worth a try too! <br><br>The opening hours on a Saturday was surprisingly late at noon, but I&#39;m glad my sister and I waited for its opening. There was no wait and we got promptly seated. The menu consists of 5 major components - risotto (rice), pasta, waffles, dessert and drinks. You pick your favorite and then head on over to order at the counter. <br><br>We tried the mentaiko prawn pasta, that comes with a free drink. The mentaiko flavor was hit the right spot, the pasta was cooked al dente and the prawns were bouncy and chewy. The lemongrass chamomile tea I chose to go along was strong and intense with lemongrass, so might not be suitable for folks who are sensitive to its taste. The truffle fries was not anything special - freezer fries, thinly cut. The truffle smell is good but did not have much truffle flavor, as in many other restaurants. <br><br>The highlight of the meal is the dessert! We got the salted egg yolk mochi balls and cookie butter ice cream. The delicious cornflakes gave amazing texture to the smooth ice cream. I would say the salted egg yolk could be saltier and the cookie butter ice cream was sweet enough without honey. <br><br>I enjoyed the mentaiko pasta but it&#39;s quite small a portion, good for customers with small appetite. My favorite was the mochi salted egg yolk balls and I would be back to have more! <br><br>My sister and I really enjoyed the industrial design and benches in the restaurant. Cozy and rustic. I would say the two person seat near the door was a little stuffy so try to sit closer to the inner restaurant.

photos: [{'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/xGsznYfh8DOw5IFB_zxSWQ/300s.jpg', 'link': '/biz_photos/stateland-cafe-singapore?reviewid=HHNPexiGFkqjFQ_70R6yLQ&select=xGsznYfh8DOw5IFB_zxSWQ', 'altText': 'Photo of Stateland Cafe - Singapore, Singapore', 'width': 300, 'height': 300, 'caption': ''}]
text: Kampong Glam has always been a hot hit with people going there to shop, eat or just walk around. Cafes here are quite common as well in the area, such as La Marelle, CAD Cafe, and even the recently opened Elffin &amp;amp; Elffin. Stateland Cafe has become the newest addition to this area. Also operating a online macaroons business called Flag &amp;amp; Sac, this place serves all-day breakfasts, pastas and desserts.<br><br>The menu here is rather simple, and reasonably priced.<br><br>The coffees here are made using the Terra Firma blends from Papa Palheta. The Macchiato ($3.90) provides a single shot of espresso, which has a slightly acidic and bitter taste.<br><br>The Latte ($4.70) tasted strong and firm with the right amount of milk added.<br><br>The Belgium Waffles ($10.90) comes with a chocolate ice cream, fresh fruits and Stateland&#39;s waffle sauce. This is possibly one of the best waffles coming from a cafe. Crusty on the outside, soft and moist on the inside, this goes well especially with the chocolate ice cream.<br><br>This place is a great place to come to for their coffee and food after some shopping within the area, so if you are around the Kampong Glam area, this should not be missed!

userinfo: {'link': '/user_details?userid=7rIFoaj7INPYsCoxAguV9A', 'src': 'https://s3-media0.fl.yelpcdn.com/assets/srv0/yelp_styleguide/514f6997a318/assets/img/default_avatars/user_60_square.png', 'srcSet': None, 'markupDisplayName': 'S P.', 'displayLocation': 'Cupertino, CA', 'altText': 'S P.', 'userUrl': '/user_details?userid=7rIFoaj7INPYsCoxAguV9A', 'partnerAlias': None, 'friendCount': 0, 'photoCount': None, 'reviewCount': 25, 'eliteYear': None}
text: Cute and cozy rest stop (tucked away on a small side street) that serves cafe style food and desserts- nice place to re-energize after walking the Bugis street market and then Haji lane. A little hipster like but good music and industrial ambiance. The soft serve taro ice cream was smooth and creamy and the earl gray mochi balls were nice and chewy - nice compliment to the ice cream. Take a bite into a mochi ball to get warm oozy filling burst out...yum. Only question is why they call it earl gray mochi balls when the filling they gave me is creamy chocolate (a la Lava cake) - sooo rich and  good but not sure where the earl gray comes in..... : )
